{"uri": "8139546639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:12:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:12:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:12:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://ksltv.com/649323/tornado-devastates-iowa-town-killing-multiple-people-as-powerful-storms-rip-through-midwest/", "title": "Deadly tornado devastates Iowa town; powerful storms rip Midwest", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Multiple people were killed and at least a dozen were injured Tuesday as a tornado devastates a small Iowa town. It carved a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nDevastating tornadoes flatten homes in Nebraska and Iowa as storm threat grows 'dangerous' for millions\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nVideo: The KSL Archive: A tornado devastates Salt Lake City\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep (1.83 meters deep) hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.", "source": {"uri": "ksltv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KSLTV.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8139487514", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "02:01:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T02:01:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:00:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/multiple-deaths-confirmed-from-a-tornado-in-iowa-state-patrol-says/article_8396dabe-23f7-5abe-a1d3-24b831826a1d.html", "title": "Multiple deaths confirmed from a tornado in Iowa, state patrol says", "body": "Damage is seen after a tornado moved through Greenfield, Iowa, Tuesday, May 21, 2024.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- The Iowa State Patrol has confirmed multiple deaths from a tornado and at least a dozen injuries in storms Tuesday, but it has not released specific numbers.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number.\n\nPowerful storms that rolled through the Midwest spun up multiple tornadoes, including a fierce twister that smashed through the small Iowa town of Greenfield, with a population of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister carved a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars and widely strewn debris.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nPeople are also reading... All Bloomington-Normal Catholic churches to stay, three priests to move in diocese reorganization Jack's Cafe serves up 'consistent' and 'delicious' offerings in Tremont Cameron Barnes commits to Illinois State basketball Red Lobster abruptly closes dozens of restaurants across US. See the full list Bloomington's new hockey team is getting an NHL affiliate Bloomington couple denied pretrial release in armed robbery case Flick Fact: When 'Young Sheldon' ends tonight, why think of a B-N address? 2 men convicted in 2020 Bloomington murder Bloomington moves forward with proposed TIF district Leo Anthony Keith Egbers Flick Fact: The guy who invented YouTube in his Central Illinois dorm room? Flick Fact: Why Bloomington and Normal aren't one city? Heartland Community College grads ready to step into new careers Forensic scientists testify on firearm, fingerprint evidence in Bloomington murder trial Bloomington zoning board recommends permit for senior living facility\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76 meters) wind turbines. Des Moines, Iowa, television station KCCI-TV showed at least three wind turbines that were toppled by an apparent tornado in southwest Iowa, and at least one was in flames with black smoke pluming from the bent structure.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe Adair County Health System hospital in Greenfield was damaged in the storm, but Mercy One spokesman Todd Mizener said he had no further details. The hospital is affiliated with Mercy One, and officials were on their way to Greenfield to assess the damage.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep (1.83 meters deep) hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n-- -\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8139971523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "08:42:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T08:42:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T08:42:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.fox19.com/2024/05/21/live-storms-spin-up-tornadoes-iowa-that-topple-wind-turbines-cause-damage-least-one-town/", "title": "Tornado devastates Iowa town, killing multiple people as powerful storms rip through Midwest", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Multiple people died Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nThe Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot (15.24-centimeter) deep hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been updated to correct the conversion of a half-foot depth of hail to 15.24 centimeters, not 1.83 meters.\n\n___\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. "https://gray-wxix-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/U6YD57INXNHXPBUZQQUXJLWA6I.jpg?auth=88bede9c11cc43531b3f4576e9057e6e860e027a0dc370dbae36c5463b0d8946&width=1200&height=600&smart=true", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Greenfield, Iowa"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2, "wgt": 225, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-364007596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "02:35:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T02:35:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:22:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/tornado-devastates-iowa-town-killing-multiple-people-as-powerful-storms-rip-through-midwest/article_a829e49c-4009-5659-b60d-fab11246e3fc.html", "title": "Tornado devastates Iowa town, killing multiple people as powerful storms rip through Midwest", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Multiple people died Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep (1.83 meters deep) hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n-- -\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nNew sales workshop 'Extreme Business Growth' in Las Vegas Scottie Scheffler's Louisville court date postponed after arrest during PGA Championship Foundation for a Drug-Free World Reaches Out at the 79th Annual {"uri": "8139486111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "01:58:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T01:58:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T01:58:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/multiple-deaths-confirmed-from-a-tornado-in-iowa-state-patrol-says/article_e6d74192-0d92-5ce6-8436-c6fa37041778.html", "title": "Multiple deaths confirmed from a tornado in Iowa, state patrol says", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- The Iowa State Patrol has confirmed multiple deaths from a tornado and at least a dozen injuries in storms Tuesday, but it has not released specific numbers.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Powerful storms that rolled through the Midwest spun up multiple tornadoes, including a fierce twister that smashed through a small Iowa town Tuesday, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars and widely strewn debris.\n\nMultiple people were injured in Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, said Iowa State Patrol spokesman Sgt. Alex Dinkla. He didn't know the extent of the injuries.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76 meters) wind turbines. Des Moines, Iowa, television station KCCI-TV showed at least three wind turbines that were toppled by an apparent tornado in southwest Iowa, and at least one was in flames with black smoke pluming from the bent structure.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe Adair County Health System hospital in Greenfield was damaged in the storm, but Mercy One spokesman Todd Mizener said he had no further details. The hospital is affiliated with Mercy One, and officials were on their way to Greenfield to assess the damage.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep (1.83 meters deep) hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n-- -\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8140823341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "17:45:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T17:45:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T17:45:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.gpb.org/news/2024/05/22/search-and-rescue-efforts-continue-after-tornado-slams-iowa-killing-at-least-1", "title": "Search and rescue efforts continue after tornado slams Iowa, killing at least 1 person", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa -- Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, killing at least one.\n\nThe Adams County Sheriff's office said a woman died Tuesday when her vehicle was blown off the road during the storms about 3 miles north of Corning, Iowa, or about 30 miles southwest of Greenfield, where the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars.\n\nThe woman's name and age were not immediately released. She was the only occupant in the vehicle.\n\nOfficials did not immediately give details Wednesday morning of other deaths or injuries, saying they were still conducting search and rescue operations.\n\nThe tornado that tore through Greenfield also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the small town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles way from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.", "source": {"uri": "gpb.org", "dataType": "news", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Greenfield, Iowa"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8139757905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "06:21:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T06:21:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T06:20:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/05/22/us-news/iowa-tornado-kills-multiple-people-during-powerful-midwest-storm/", "title": "Tornado devastates Iowa town, killing multiple people as powerful...", "body": "Multiple people died Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nThe Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood.\n\nCars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves.\n\nResidents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa.\n\nSome of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph. They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak.\n\nFurther east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes.\n\nDes Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area.\n\nThe deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph and 45 mph hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people.\n\nThose storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather.\n\nThe total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out.\n\nHurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-364809185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:40:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:40:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/news/nation-world/weather/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_9a95a07f-bef2-5a75-8671-5c8e9e1ed1a0.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms tear through Midwest", "body": "Powerful storms that rolled through the Midwest spun up multiple tornadoes, including a fierce twister that smashed through a small Iowa town. In the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated.\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa -- An undisclosed number of people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa after a massive tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars and also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles east of Eau Claire, meteorologist Roy Eckberg said. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff will also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms last Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the weather service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nPhotos: Tornado devastates Greenfield as powerful storms sweep through Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere Weather Iowa\n\nSevere "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.4196078431372549, "wgt": 223, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8139532128", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "02:58:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T02:58:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:56:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-tornado-devastates-iowa-town-killing-multiple-people-as-powerful-storms-rip-through-midwest-5981747.html", "title": "World News | Tornado Devastates Iowa Town, Killing Multiple People as Powerful Storms Rip Through Midwest | LatestLY", "body": "Greenfield (US), May 22 (AP) Multiple people died on Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\nAlso Read | King Salman Health Update: Saudi Arabia's King Diagnosed With Lung Inflammation, Being Treated in Jeddah.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference on Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nAlso Read | Heatwave Warning in Pakistan: Schools Shut, Hospitals on Alert As Pakistan Sizzles at 50 Degrees Celsius in Some Areas.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city on Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the US Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimise the strain.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow\", Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbours help neighbours, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Centre, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Centre gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes.\n\nDes Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and cancelled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms on Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep (1.83 metres deep) hail on Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms on Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised on Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri. {"uri": "2024-05-363988540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "01:58:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T01:58:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T01:44:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/state-and-regional/missouri/multiple-deaths-confirmed-from-a-tornado-in-iowa-state-patrol-says/article_3e410809-c1d2-5856-9b9c-4ae36d3d7fdd.html", "title": "Multiple deaths confirmed from a tornado in Iowa, state patrol says", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- The Iowa State Patrol has confirmed multiple deaths from a tornado and at least a dozen injuries in storms Tuesday, but it has not released specific numbers.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number.\n\nPowerful storms that rolled through the Midwest spun up multiple tornadoes, including a fierce twister that smashed through the small Iowa town of Greenfield, with a population of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister carved a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars and widely strewn debris.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nHow the feds say they caught one of St. Louis' most prolific cocaine distributors TV Q&A: Where to find the 'Monk' movie Sonny Gray expected the manager to come get him. Oliver Marmol sent a different message. St. Charles County library branches may close, cut staff. Board to consider on Friday. Cardinals 'City Connect' uniforms: All you need to know, from new details to Nelly's role MLB's latest broadcast move yet again aggravates some Cardinals fans: Media Views Buck-Caray combo returns to Cardinals broadcast booth next week: Media Views Sultan: Why aren't more of us snacking on cicadas? Expect traffic snarls Sunday in downtown St. Louis with big parade, 2 sporting events Locals are buying Hoffmann properties in Defiance. 'We want to bring some positivity back.' Ken Smith, a SLU neurosurgeon who helped people die, dead at 91 MLB casts doubt on Bally Sports' bankruptcy plan after broadcast deal falls through Two St. Louis Catholic parishes win, one loses in appeals to Vatican to stay open St. Charles County library might close 3 branches, eliminate some jobs BenFred: As Cardinals and Red Sox clash, what should we make of Chaim Bloom's dud in Boston?\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76 meters) wind turbines. Des Moines, Iowa, television station KCCI-TV showed at least three wind turbines that were toppled by an apparent tornado in southwest Iowa, and at least one was in flames with black smoke pluming from the bent structure.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe Adair County Health System hospital in Greenfield was damaged in the storm, but Mercy One spokesman Todd Mizener said he had no further details. The hospital is affiliated with Mercy One, and officials were on their way to Greenfield to assess the damage.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep (1.83 meters deep) hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n-- -\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press.
