{"uri": "2024-05-364010023", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "02:40:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T02:40:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:34:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/tornado-devastates-iowa-town-killing-multiple-people-as-powerful-storms-rip-through-midwest/article_1759a668-3351-5bdd-882a-6eade427f555.html", "title": "Tornado devastates Iowa town, killing multiple people as powerful storms rip through Midwest", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Multiple people died Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nTree crushes pickup truck in Waterloo Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Traer man arrested in 106-mph chase through Waterloo-Cedar Falls My Waterloo Days schedule set for June 6-8 festival, including nationally known musical acts Bicycling child injured after being hit by car at Hudson, Greenhill Roads in Cedar Falls Man now charged with vandalizing mayor's, supervisor's vehicles Walmart lays off hundreds of employees, relocates most remote staff back to primary offices Waterloo man who allegedly left dog in hot car charged with animal's death Two arrested in Friday robbery UPDATED WITH ADDITIONAL ROADS: Black Hawk County announces road closures due to flooding Two people charged with submitting fake lottery tickets, accepting winnings Leadership changes at Bremer County Emergency Management More than 1,600 Waterloo homes without power due to MidAmerican outage Cedar Falls could take next steps to approve Boulder Tap House restaurant\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot deep (1.83 meters deep) hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n-- -\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8140836286", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "17:56:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T17:56:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T17:55:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/search-rescue-underway-tornado-slams-172812977.html", "title": "Search and rescue underway after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, killing at least one.\n\nThe Adams County Sheriff's Office said a woman died Tuesday when her vehicle was blown off the road during the storms about three miles north of Corning, Iowa, or about 30 miles southwest of Greenfield, where the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars.\n\nThe woman, whose name and age were not immediately released, was the only occupant in the vehicle. Officials did not release other figures of the dead and wounded.\n\nThe tornado that tore through Greenfield also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the town of 2,000 people.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, the storms moved east into Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers.\n\nRead more: How much worse will extreme heat get by 2050? New report outlines worrisome future\n\nThe U.S. is experiencing a historically bad season for tornadoes as climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the United States.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. This year's preliminary count of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Okla. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was damaged, meaning that at least a dozen people who were injured had to be taken elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly, we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nRead more: What is in-flight turbulence, and when does it become dangerous for passengers and crews?\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, about 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that the tornado carried from the town.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody. His house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day in Nebraska, residents to the west in Omaha awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nAssociated Press writer Fingerhut reported from Greenfield, McFetridge from Des Moines and Beck reported from Omaha. {"uri": "8140560978", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:43:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:43:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:42:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-iowa-as-powerful-storms-again-tear-through-midwest/articleshow/110339498.cms", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms again tear through Midwest", "body": "Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds plans to visit Greenfield after severe storms hit the area, causing fatalities and destruction. The Storm Prediction Center warned of severe weather in Iowa and Wisconsin.Multiple people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa and left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars, while the howling winds also twisted and toppled wind turbines. After devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 90 kilometers southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 89 kilometers east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 32 kilometers southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 113 kilometers per hour in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 76-meter wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://img.etimg.com/thumb/msid-110339518,width-1200,height-630,imgsize-172006,overlay-economictimes/photo.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", {"uri": "8139479952", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "01:49:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T01:49:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T01:49:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/state-regional/weather/storms-spin-up-tornadoes-in-iowa-that-cause-injuries-topple-wind-turbines/article_e76de6a2-c26f-5b78-8aec-d5a63ceba13e.html", "title": "Storms spin up tornadoes in Iowa that cause injuries, topple wind turbines", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa -- Powerful storms that rolled through the Midwest spun up multiple tornadoes, including a fierce twister that smashed through a small Iowa town Tuesday, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars and widely strewn debris.\n\nMultiple people were injured in Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, said Iowa State Patrol spokesman Sgt. Alex Dinkla. He didn't know the extent of the injuries.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nPeople are also reading... Tree crushes pickup truck in Waterloo Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Traer man arrested in 106-mph chase through Waterloo-Cedar Falls My Waterloo Days schedule set for June 6-8 festival, including nationally known musical acts Bicycling child injured after being hit by car at Hudson, Greenhill Roads in Cedar Falls Man now charged with vandalizing mayor's, supervisor's vehicles Walmart lays off hundreds of employees, relocates most remote staff back to primary offices Waterloo man who allegedly left dog in hot car charged with animal's death Two arrested in Friday robbery Two people charged with submitting fake lottery tickets, accepting winnings More than 1,600 Waterloo homes without power due to MidAmerican outage Leadership changes at Bremer County Emergency Management Cedar Falls could take next steps to approve Boulder Tap House restaurant Waterloo man, dog safe after Zachary Court house fire in Waterloo\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines. Des Moines, Iowa, television station KCCI-TV showed at least three wind turbines that were toppled by an apparent tornado in southwest Iowa, and at least one was in flames with black smoke pluming from the bent structure.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph. They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe Adair County Health System hospital in Greenfield was damaged in the storm, but Mercy One spokesman Todd Mizener said he had no further details. The hospital is affiliated with Mercy One, and officials were on their way to Greenfield to assess the damage.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds said her administration was monitoring the weather situation and maintaing contact with the Iowa Department of Homeland Security and Emergency Management. The State Emergency Operations Center was responding to needs in the affected areas, she said in a post on social media.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph and 45 mph hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Ap State Storms Flooding Winds Nebraska Omaha Iowa Climate And Environment Natural Disasters Storms Weather U.s. {"uri": "2024-05-364715569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:16:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:16:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:21:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.brproud.com/news/us-news/ap-us-news/ap-tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-iowa-as-powerful-storms-again-tear-through-midwest/", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms again tear through Midwest", "body": "by: HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK, Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Multiple people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa and left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars, while the howling winds also twisted and toppled wind turbines.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms last Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the weather service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n___\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "brproud.com", {"uri": "8140458805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "13:37:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T13:37:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:37:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/488669/Tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-Iowa-as-powerful-storms-again-tear-through-Midwest", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms again tear through Midwest - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press A woman and a child walk past damage after a tornado Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa. (AP Photo/Charlie Neibergall)\n\nMultiple people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa and left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars, while the howling winds also twisted and toppled wind turbines.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms last Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the weather service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "https://www.castanet.net/content/2024/5/2024052200050-664d6e5d855d7866fa2cf7a1jpeg_p3801624.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": null, {"uri": "8139637920", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:44:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:44:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:43:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/state-regional/weather/deadly-tornado-devastates-greenfield-as-powerful-storms-sweep-iowa/article_e76de6a2-c26f-5b78-8aec-d5a63ceba13e.html", "title": "Deadly tornado devastates Greenfield as powerful storms sweep Iowa", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa -- Multiple people died Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nPeople are also reading... Tree crushes pickup truck in Waterloo Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Traer man arrested in 106-mph chase through Waterloo-Cedar Falls My Waterloo Days schedule set for June 6-8 festival, including nationally known musical acts Bicycling child injured after being hit by car at Hudson, Greenhill Roads in Cedar Falls Man now charged with vandalizing mayor's, supervisor's vehicles UPDATED WITH ADDITIONAL ROADS: Black Hawk County announces road closures due to flooding Walmart lays off hundreds of employees, relocates most remote staff back to primary offices Waterloo man who allegedly left dog in hot car charged with animal's death Two arrested in Friday robbery Two people charged with submitting fake lottery tickets, accepting winnings More than 1,600 Waterloo homes without power due to MidAmerican outage Leadership changes at Bremer County Emergency Management Cedar Falls could take next steps to approve Boulder Tap House restaurant\n\nThe Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph. They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph and 45 mph hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nPhotos: Tornado devastates Greenfield as powerful storms sweep through Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Dcc Wire Ap State Storms Flooding Winds Nebraska Omaha Iowa Climate And Environment Natural Disasters Storms Weather U.s. {"uri": "8139676155", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:17:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:17:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:16:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/us-multiple-people-killed-as-tornado-wreaks-havoc-in-iowa-small-town-reduced-to-rubble-updates-2024-05-22-932715", "title": "US: Multiple people killed as tornado wreaks havoc in Iowa, small town reduced to rubble | VIDEO", "body": "Iowa: A powerful tornado ripped through a small town in Iowa on Tuesday, killing multiple people and leaving at least a dozen people injured, according to authorities. Sgt Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, confirmed multiple casualties and said the tornado devastated a good portion of Greenfield town, although the exact figures of the deceased were not known.\n\nImages from the town of Greenfield show a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled. At least a dozen people in the Iowa town of 2,000 people, were injured due to the tornado. People had to be transferred to facilities in nearby towns as the local hospital sustained damage in the storm.\n\nOther video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state. Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city on Tuesday night. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the grey and overcast sky.\n\n\"I've lived here all my life. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, told KCCI TV in an interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state. At least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire. Several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County. The National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the US Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimise the strain.\n\nGreenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbours help neighbours, according to its visitors' page. \"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" Camille Blair said of the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce. \"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Centre gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma. Another round of storms on Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska, covering Colorado's Yuma city into a blanket of hail.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service. He said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n(with inputs from agencies)", "source": {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 59}], "image": "https://resize.indiatvnews.com/en/resize/newbucket/1200_-/2024/05/iowa-1716354522.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Iowa"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, {"uri": "8140023343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "09:14:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T09:14:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T09:13:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://nptelegraph.com/news/state-and-regional/tornado-devastates-iowa-town-killing-multiple-people-as-powerful-storms-rip-through-midwest/article_f2aff665-2293-5e36-b1c4-e6f4c3b954db.html", "title": "Tornado devastates Iowa town, killing multiple people as powerful storms rip through Midwest", "body": "A woman and a child walk past damage after a tornado Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Multiple people died Tuesday and at least a dozen were injured when a powerful tornado tore through a small Iowa town, carving a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars, and widely strewn debris.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 around 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nPeople are also reading... Report: Auburn running back Brian Battie in critical condition after fatal shooting Will severe storms affect weekend plans in Nebraska? Stapleton man dies in semi-car collision south of Stapleton Tuesday Severe Thunderstorm Watch for much of Nebraska until 12 a.m. District 177 owners eye 2nd multiuse building; T.J. Maxx opens Sunday Great Plains Health to end contract with Medicare Advantage starting Jan. 1, 2025 Nebraska volleyball's Harper Murray releases statement in response to legal woes State Track: Four Telegraph-area athletes, one relay win gold at Burke Sutherland's Snyder wins shot put championship, St. Pat's Knisley breaks state and state meet record Fire fighters battle blaze south of Hershey Friday Trump wins in Nebraska, but results signal ongoing struggles to win over moderate voters North Platte man headed to jail after violating probation Lincoln man who sexually assaulted minor: 'I was doing her a favor' Severe storms continue to slam parts of Nebraska Tuesday North Platte City Council advances District 177's 2nd phase, awards Rec Center contract\n\nThe Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the gray and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air and continued to smolder hours later.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nThe town bills itself as \"the friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and \"the crack of the fireworks or twinkle of the lights\" on special holidays. Also touting itself as the \"perfect place to grow,\" Greenfield prides itself on being a town where business owners know your name and neighbors help neighbors, according to its visitors page.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm. She emerged from her home to describe widespread damage and scattered debris.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was already braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled all evening activities ahead of the storms.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the state's capital city of Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to weather sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters arriving to rescue people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms forced authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of between 35 mph (56 kph) and 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\n\"There is no visibility at times,\" state police posted on the social media platform X.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice. Front-end loaders were used to move half-foot (15.24-centimeter) deep hail Tuesday.\n\nLast week, deadly storms hit the Houston area in Texas, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving those Texans in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nTuesday's storms were expected to bring much of the same high winds, heavy rain and large hail to Minnesota and part of northern Missouri, said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service.\n\nHe said the system is expected to turn south on Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nThis story has been updated to correct the conversion of a half-foot depth of hail to 15.24 centimeters, not 1.83 meters.\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8140671771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:54:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:54:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:54:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/authorities-still-conducting-search-rescue-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_31475021-bf03-5032-86de-5ea9919ec434.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, killing at least one.\n\nThe Adams County Sheriff's office said a woman died Tuesday when her vehicle was blown off the road during the storms about 3 miles (5 kilometers) north of Corning, Iowa, or about 30 miles (48 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, where the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe woman's name and age were not immediately released. She was the only occupant in the vehicle.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOfficials did not immediately give details Wednesday morning of other deaths or injuries, saying they were still conducting search and rescue operations.\n\nThe tornado that tore through Greenfield also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the small town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\n___\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska.
