{"uri": "8140169392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "10:41:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T10:41:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T10:40:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/midwest-weather-tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-iowa-as-severe-storms-continue-101716373987317.html", "title": "Midwest weather: Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as severe storms continue", "body": "After devastating the town of 2,000 residents on Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to more than 130,000 customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for the town and said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nGreenfield bills itself on its website as a \"friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and as the \"perfect place to grow.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 46}], "image": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/ht-img/img/2024/05/22/1600x900/AP05-22-2024-000022B-0_1716374120467_1716374148040.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 200, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8140913619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "19:01:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T19:01:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T19:00:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_7108042b-d612-5a4c-ab80-50f5c17987fc.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "A man talks on his cell phone in front of a tornado damaged home, Wednesday, May 22, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa continued search and rescue efforts Wednesday while surviving residents picked through debris that had been their homes a day after a deadly tornado devastated the town of Greenfield and killed an undisclosed number of people there.\n\nThe tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes, splintered trees and crumpled cars in Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister also ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines several miles outside the town.\n\nGreenfield resident Kimberly Ergish and her husband dug through the debris field Wednesday that used to be their home, looking for family photos and other things that could be salvaged. There wasn't much left, she acknowledged.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\n\"Most of it's gone,\" she said. \"Most of it we can't save. But we're going to get what we can.\"\n\nThe reality of having her home destroyed in a matter of seconds hasn't really set in, she said.\n\n\"If it weren't for all the bumps and bruises and the achy bones, I would think that it didn't happen,\" she said.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road during the storms near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds and other officials held a news conference Wednesday morning but declined to give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris had made it difficult to be sure of those numbers.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday that initial surveys confirmed the damage in Greenfield indicated at least an EF-3 tornado, which would have wind speeds of 136 to 165 mph (219 to 265 kph). But those findings are preliminary and could change following additional damage assessment over the coming days, the weather service said.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa -- including the one in Greenfield -- and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that leveled Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nThe deadly tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers), he said, and the damage wrought by it was the worst he had seen since an EF-4 tornado -- with wind speeds between 166 and 200 mph (267 and 320 kph) -- hit Mayfield, Kentucky in December 2021.\n\nA mobile research radar in the area of the Greenfield tornado detected wind speeds higher than 200 mph (320 kph), which is the threshold for an EF-5 tornado, Porter said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"But that measurement was taken roughly 600 to 1,000 feet above the ground. It's the severity of damage on the ground documented during storm damage surveys that dictates the strength of a tornado,\" he said.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said Tuesday night. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school. The Adair County Health Department reported that a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nWhite House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said FEMA's administrator would head to to Iowa on Thursday and the White House was in touch with state and local officials.\n\n\"We are praying for those who tragically lost their lives as deadly tornados ripped through Iowa,\" she said. \"We are also wishing a speedy recovery to those who were injured.\"\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nThe tornado tore through houses on the southwest corner of Greenfield and traveled toward the hospital on the east side. Residential streets that on Monday were lined with old-growth trees and neatly-appointed ranch-style homes were, by Wednesday, a chaotic jumble of splintered and smashed remnants. Many of the homes' basements where residents sheltered lay exposed and front yards were littered with belongings from furniture to children's toys and Christmas decorations.\n\nErgish, 33, said she gathered her four kids and went into the basement when the sirens sounded \"and just kind of huddled in the corner.\" Seconds later, they were covered in the debris from their destroyed home.\n\n\"It was like 10 seconds of pure terror,\" she said. \"It felt like it lasted a lifetime.\"\n\nThe family, which has lived in Greenfield for eight years, escaped with minor injuries. Ergish said that as much as she loves the town, she's not sure whether they'll stay.\n\n\"It's kind of traumatizing at the moment,\" she said.\n\nThe tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines just southwest of the town. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Earlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg.\n\nWeather service staff also planned to assess storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-05-364129908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:38:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:38:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:33:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/state-and-regional/missouri/tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-iowa-as-powerful-storms-again-tear-through-midwest/article_717d124d-a447-59c9-b9fe-9d403099e952.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms again tear through Midwest", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Multiple people were killed when a tornado tore through Greenfield and left a wide swath of obliterated homes, crumpled cars and splintered trees, while outside the small town, massive wind turbines were buckled and twisted to the ground by the howling winds.\n\nAfter devastating the town of 2,000 residents, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to more than 130,000 customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nHow the feds say they caught one of St. Louis' most prolific cocaine distributors TV Q&A: Where to find the 'Monk' movie Cardinals 'City Connect' uniforms: All you need to know, from new details to Nelly's role MLB's latest broadcast move yet again aggravates some Cardinals fans: Media Views Sultan: Why aren't more of us snacking on cicadas? St. Charles County library branches may close, cut staff. Board to consider on Friday. Expect traffic snarls Sunday in downtown St. Louis with big parade, 2 sporting events Ken Smith, a SLU neurosurgeon who helped people die, dead at 91 St. Charles County library might close 3 branches, eliminate some jobs BenFred: As Cardinals and Red Sox clash, what should we make of Chaim Bloom's dud in Boston? Critic, church mounted 'campaign' targeting St. Charles library employee, suit says Sonny Gray expected the manager to come get him. Oliver Marmol sent a different message. Neman: The legend of the Des Peres pickle jar continues to fascinate and delight Firm that accused ex-Mercy executive of bribery and extortion sues the health system University buys former Fields Foods store near Lafayette Square\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for the town and said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (89 kph). They also lock and feather their blades and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nGreenfield bills itself on its website as a \"friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and as the \"perfect place to grow.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIn southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Farther east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled evening activities.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the capital, Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of up to 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines and Beck reported from Omaha. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. He said authorities were still determining the total number.\n\nPowerful storms that rolled through the US Midwest spun up multiple tornadoes, including a fierce tornado that smashed through the small Iowa town of Greenfield, with a population of about 2,000 around 55 miles southwest of Des Moines.\n\nThe tornado carved a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars and widely strewn debris.\n\nMounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood.\n\nResidents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings from mounds of debris or from homes barely left standing.\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 76-metre wind turbines.\n\nDes Moines, Iowa, television station KCCI-TV showed at least three wind turbines that were toppled by an apparent tornado in southwest Iowa, and at least one was in flames with black smoke pluming from the bent structure.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the US Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph.\n\nThey also lock and feather their blades, and turn into the wind, to minimise the strain.\n\nThe hospital is affiliated with Mercy One, and officials were on their way to Greenfield to assess the damage.\n\nIn far southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Further east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Centre, among others.\n\nThe storms and {"uri": "8139668102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:10:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:10:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:10:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://qctimes.com/news/state-regional/iowa/tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-iowa-as-powerful-storms-again-tear-through-midwest/article_63416433-ab19-5ebf-a1e0-49f379d9a4f0.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms again tear through Midwest", "body": "This image taken from video provided by JJ Unger, shows hail damage to a window of vehicle, Monday night, May 20, 2024, in Yuma, Colo. Residents in the small city in northeastern Colorado were cleaning up Tuesday after hail the size of baseballs and golf balls pounded the community, with heavy construction equipment and snow shovels being used to clear hail that had piled up knee-deep the night before.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Officials said multiple people were killed Tuesday when a tornado ripped through a small town in Iowa, decimating homes and damaging businesses.\n\nThe town of Greenfield's hospital was among the buildings damaged -- which meant that at least a dozen people hurt had to be taken to hospitals elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nPeople are also reading... Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Wolfe It Down, Azteca 3 and more 'Worst decision they ever made;' Residents hit hard by Hy-Vee's plan to close Rockingham Road store Meta named as company considering Davenport for data center; state board OKs incentives Man receives life-threatening injuries in officer-involved shooting in East Moline Friday; task force investigating Azteca 3 in Bettendorf to shutter its doors this year Five men involved in shootings during Davenport riots in 2020 convicted of racketeering Orion School Board hears complaints of book being removed from curriculum Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Davenport man arrested for May 5 Moline double homicide Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds signs bill capping THC product potency, despite concerns Davenport West's Thomas wins school's first state track title since 1995 Quad City Bank & Trust CEO John Anderson to retire New food truck Wolfe It Down Pizza popping up this summer Fired employee sues Scott County, alleging retaliation for complaints against sheriff, wife Spartans juniors break Iowa high school state record\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of the town of 2,000 located around 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for the town and said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (89 kph). They also lock and feather their blades and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nGreenfield bills itself on its website as a \"friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and as the \"perfect place to grow.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIn southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Farther east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nIowa was braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled evening activities.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the capital, Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of up to 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines and Beck reported from Omaha. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8140638106", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:32:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:32:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:31:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/nation-world/weather/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_564855eb-25ca-597f-aebf-cc76f730a9ec.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms tear through Midwest", "body": "Firefighters walks among tornado-damaged homes, Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK, Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa -- An undisclosed number of people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa after a massive tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars and also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... All Bloomington-Normal Catholic churches to stay, three priests to move in diocese reorganization Bloomington's new hockey team is getting an NHL affiliate Cameron Barnes commits to Illinois State basketball Storms, blowing dust threaten Central Illinois Bloomington couple denied pretrial release in armed robbery case Flick Fact: When 'Young Sheldon' ends tonight, why think of a B-N address? 2 men convicted in 2020 Bloomington murder Jack's Cafe serves up 'consistent' and 'delicious' offerings in Tremont Leo Anthony Keith Egbers Normal OKs uptown underpass agreement; construction slated for fall Flick Fact: The guy who invented YouTube in his Central Illinois dorm room? Red Lobster abruptly closes dozens of restaurants across US. See the full list Heartland Community College grads ready to step into new careers Police investigating shots fired in Normal Severe storms likely in Illinois Tuesday | Here's where they are expected first\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles east of Eau Claire, meteorologist Roy Eckberg said. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff will also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms last Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the weather service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nPhotos: Tornado devastates Greenfield as powerful storms sweep through Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/64/564855eb-25ca-597f-aebf-cc76f730a9ec/664e0d088b0d5.preview.jpg?crop=1757%2C922%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", {"uri": "8141008485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "20:29:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T20:29:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T20:28:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://muscatinejournal.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/authorities-still-conducting-search-rescue-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_6c624287-c995-5421-97ae-c57939e5f3a4.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "A man talks on his cell phone in front of a tornado damaged home, Wednesday, May 22, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa continued search and rescue efforts Wednesday while surviving residents picked through debris that had been their homes a day after a deadly tornado devastated the town of Greenfield and killed an undisclosed number of people there.\n\nThe tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes, splintered trees and crumpled cars in Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister also ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines several miles outside the town.\n\nGreenfield resident Kimberly Ergish and her husband dug through the debris field Wednesday that used to be their home, looking for family photos and other things that could be salvaged. There wasn't much left, she acknowledged.\n\n\"Most of it's gone,\" she said. \"Most of it we can't save. But we're going to get what we can.\"\n\nThe reality of having her home destroyed in a matter of seconds hasn't really set in, she said.\n\n\"If it weren't for all the bumps and bruises and the achy bones, I would think that it didn't happen,\" she said.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road during the storms near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds and other officials held a news conference Wednesday morning but declined to give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris had made it difficult to be sure of those numbers.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states. The severe weather was expected to turn south on Wednesday, and the National Weather Service issued a tornado watch for the midsection of Texas -- including Dallas -- until 8 p.m.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday that initial surveys confirmed the damage in Greenfield indicated at least an EF-3 tornado, which would have wind speeds of 136 to 165 mph (219 to 265 kph). But those findings are preliminary and could show a more powerful tornado following additional damage assessment over the coming days, the weather service said.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa -- including the one in Greenfield -- and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that leveled Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nThe tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers), he said, and the damage wrought by it was the worst he had seen since an EF-4 tornado -- with wind speeds between 166 and 200 mph (267 and 320 kph) -- hit Mayfield, Kentucky in December 2021.\n\nA mobile research radar in the area of the Greenfield tornado detected wind speeds higher than 200 mph (320 kph), which is the threshold for an EF-5 tornado, Porter said.\n\n\"But that measurement was taken roughly 600 to 1,000 feet above the ground. It's the severity of damage on the ground documented during storm damage surveys that dictates the strength of a tornado,\" he said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nGreenfield's 25-bed hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, and at least a dozen people who were hurt were taken to facilities elsewhere. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school, and a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nWhite House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said FEMA's administrator would head to to Iowa on Thursday and that the White House was in touch with state and local officials.\n\n\"We are praying for those who tragically lost their lives as deadly tornados ripped through Iowa,\" she said. \"We are also wishing a speedy recovery to those who were injured.\"\n\nPeople as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos on Facebook of ripped family photos, yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the tornado.\n\nThe tornado tore through houses on the southwest corner of Greenfield and traveled toward the hospital on the east side. Residential streets that on Monday were lined with old-growth trees and neatly-appointed ranch-style homes were, by Wednesday, a chaotic jumble of splintered and smashed remnants. Many of the homes' basements where residents sheltered lay exposed and front yards were littered with belongings from furniture to children's toys and Christmas decorations.\n\nErgish, 33, said she gathered her four kids and went into the basement when the sirens sounded \"and just kind of huddled in the corner.\" Seconds later, they were covered in the debris from their destroyed home.\n\n\"It was like 10 seconds of pure terror,\" she said. \"It felt like it lasted a lifetime.\"\n\nDwight Lahey, a 70-year-old retired truck driver, drove from his home in suburban Des Moines back to his hometown of Greenfield to help his 98-year-old mother whose home was destroyed. She took refuge from the twister in her basement, then walked out through her destroyed garage to a nearby convenience store, Lahey said.\n\n\"I don't know how she got through that mess,\" he said. His mom was staying in a hotel, uncertain about where she'll end up, he said.\n\nRoseann Freeland, 67, waited until the last minute to rush with her husband to a concrete room her basement. Seconds later, her husband opened the door to the room \"and you could just see daylight,\" Freeland said. \"I just lost it. I just totally lost it.\"\n\nThe tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines just southwest of the town. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nThe tornado directly hit and collapsed six MidAmerican Energy wind turbines, the utility said. Several of the turbines' sensors registered wind speeds over 100 mph (160 kph) as the tornado approached.\n\n\"This was an unprecedented impact on our wind fleet, and we have operated wind farms since 2004,\" a statement from MidAmerican read. \"We have experienced only one other instance of a wind turbine collapse, which was also caused by a tornado.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nTuesday's destructive weather also saw flooding and power outages in Nebraska, damage from tornadoes in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and dust storms in Illinois that forced two interstates to be closed.\n\nThe devastation in Iowa followed days of extreme weather that ravaged much of the middle section of the country, including Oklahoma and Kansas. Last week, deadly storms hit the Houston area, killing at least seven and knocking out power to hundreds of thousands.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "muscatinejournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Muscatine Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@muscatinejournal.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "hannah_fingerhut@muscatinejournal.com", "name": "Hannah Fingerhut", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "margery_a_beck@muscatinejournal.com", "name": "Margery A. {"uri": "8140194730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "10:56:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T10:56:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T10:55:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/chicago-power-outages-comed-outage-map-severe-weather-metra-cta-downed-power-lines-delays/3443650/", "title": "Power outages: More than 17k Chicago area customers without power following severe weather; downed trees and power lines causing transit issues", "body": "Chicago area power outages continued Wednesday morning after a system of severe weather Tuesday brought deadly tornadoes to Iowa and downed trees, strong winds and dust storms to Illinois.\n\nWhile much of the Chicago area managed to avoid the severe weather outbreak, as of 5 a.m. Wednesday, more than 17,500 ComEd customers were without power across Northern Illinois, according to ComEd's outage map.\n\nMore than 4,000 of those outages were in Cook County, the outage map showed. Power outages affecting 2,000 people or more were also reported in Lake and DuPage Counties, according to the map.\n\nWest of Rockford, in Stephenson County, more than 3,000 ComEd customers were without power, the map showed.\n\nIn several suburbs including Niles and Bartlett, downed powerlines were causing road closures, as well as delays and transit isues on the CTA Yellow Line and Metra Milwaukee North Line.\n\nIn Elgin, NBC 5 reported Lisa Chavarria reported downed trees and smashed car windows due to flying debris overnight.\n\n\"We continue to track the severe storms with strong wind gusts in our area,\" a statement posted to ComEd's website read. \"We will provide updated information as often as possible. Our crews are in the field ready to make repairs and restore power as needed.\"\n\nAccording to the NBC 5 Storm Team, Wednesday and Thursday were expected to remain mild dry in the Chicago area, with storms and shows returning Friday morning and late afternoon and continuing through the evening hours.\n\nShowers and storms were also in the forecast Sunday, NBC 5 Meteorologist Alicia Roman said.\n\nIn Iowa, the severe weather outbreak was deadly for some parts, and crews from the National Weather Service were expected to survey at least three areas to survey damage and officially determine how many tornadoes touched down.\n\nMultiple people were killed when a tornado tore through Greenfield and left a wide swath of obliterated homes, crumpled cars and splintered trees, while outside the small Iowa town, massive wind turbines were buckled and twisted to the ground by the howling winds.\n\nAfter devastating the town of 2,000 residents on Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to more than 130,000 customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for the town and said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nGreenfield bills itself on its website as a \"friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and as the \"perfect place to grow.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC {"uri": "8140711744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:22:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:22:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:21:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/authorities-still-conducting-search-rescue-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_36f8f81a-4c08-5658-860b-4825fbe1b41a.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, killing at least one.\n\nThe Adams County Sheriff's office said a woman died Tuesday when her vehicle was blown off the road during the storms about 3 miles (5 kilometers) north of Corning, Iowa, or about 30 miles (48 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, where the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe woman's name and age were not immediately released. She was the only occupant in the vehicle.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOfficials did not immediately give details Wednesday morning of other deaths or injuries, saying they were still conducting search and rescue operations.\n\nThe tornado that tore through Greenfield also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the small town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\n___\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", {"uri": "8140714060", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:24:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:24:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:23:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://brudirect.com/news.php?id=187591", "title": "Several Dead In Iowa As Storms Batter Midwest", "body": "Reuters | Damage is seen outside of the Adair County Health System hospital which was evacuated after a tornado struck the day prior, in Greenfield, Iowa\n\nA tornado killed multiple people in a small Iowa town as powerful storms swept through the Midwest.\n\nHomes and businesses in Greenfield were destroyed, cars smashed and debris strewn across the landscape.\n\nIowa police confirmed the fatalities at a news briefing on Tuesday night, but were unable to say how many.\n\nNebraska, Illinois and Wisconsin were also hit by tornadoes, heavy rain and power cuts.\n\nVideo footage showing the devastation across Iowa depicted flattened buildings, overturned cars and broken wind turbines.\n\nGreenfield, a town of 2,000 people about 55 miles from Des Moines, endured the deadliest tornado of all.\n\nMary Long rode out the storm inside her Greenfield business and told the Associated Press: \"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done.\"\n\nMs Long's business was not severely damaged but she said other parts of town were not as lucky.\n\nThe town's hospital was among the buildings damaged, forcing the dozen people who were injured to go elsewhere.\n\nA \"good portion\" of Greenfield is devastated, Iowa State Patrol Sgt Alex Dinkla told reporters on Tuesday night.\n\nThe death toll was unknown, he said, adding: \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nEveryone who lives in the town seems to be accounted for, he said.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds would not confirm the number of fatalities during a press conference in Greenfield on Wednesday,.\n\n\"This is a search and rescue mission and it will continue to be throughout the day,\" she said.\n\nIn an earlier statement, she had noted that other Iowa communities were hit by tornadoes \"just a few weeks ago\".\n\n\"And it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said.\n\nIf you have any stories or news that you would like to share with the global online community, please feel free to share it with us by
