{"uri": "8140758376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:55:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:55:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:54:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/ia/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_55e31959-9c0a-5372-85f2-09400c611914.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "Brian Gutmann, of Creston, Iowa, looks over tornado-damaged property, Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, devastating the town of Greenfield and killing an undisclosed number of people there.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road during the storms near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nIn Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars and had earlier ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines.\n\n\"It's horrific,\" Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said Wednesday at a news conference just outside the devastated town. \"It's hard to describe.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Gerrard-Hoeschler Realtors sold, NOM Sips & Eats to open Tuesday downtown Steve Cahalan: Circle K to build its first gas station in Coulee Region Suspicious death in Trempealeau County now considered a homicide Commercial garage in La Crosse sustains heavy fire and smoke damage from Thursday blaze Race against time: La Crosse man makes dire fight for Social Security Disability Insurance 79-year-old Ferryville woman dead after UTV crash New La Crosse School Board members question $53M building referendum approved for November ballots Severe weather warnings expire in region after Altura tornado confirmed For man who found body in chimney 35 years ago, positive ID offers 'sense of closure' No one injured as blaze causes extensive fire, smoke damage to South Side La Crosse home Tuesday Kyle Larry Dahl Brian T. Morrissey Suspicious death in Ettrick under investigation by Trempealeau County Sheriff's Office Onalaska man arrested for drug overdose death in Jackson County WIAA Division 1 track and field regionals: Holmen advances in 32 events\n\nShe and other officials declined to give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris had made it difficult to be sure of those numbers.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa -- including the one in Greenfield -- and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that leveled Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nThe deadly tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers , he said, and the damage wrought by it was the worst he had seen since an EF-4 tornado -- with wind speeds between 166 and 200 mph (267 and 320 kph) -- hit Mayfield, Kentucky in December 2021.\n\nA mobile research radar in the area of the Greenfield tornado detected wind speeds higher than 200 mph (320 kph), which is the threshold for an EF-5 tornado, Porter said.\n\n\"But that measurement was taken roughly 600 to 1,000 feet above the ground. It's the severity of damage on the ground documented during storm damage surveys that dictates the strength of a tornado,\" he said.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said Tuesday night. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school. The Adair County Health Department reported that a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\nIn the aftermath of the Greenfield tornado, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines just southwest of the town. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Earlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/lacrossetribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/5e/55e31959-9c0a-5372-85f2-09400c611914/664e0d0458e2e.preview.jpg?crop=1757%2C922%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-21", "textStart": 2964, "textEnd": 2970}], "sentiment": -0.3803921568627451, "wgt": 189, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-364816139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:47:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:47:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:38:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://qctimes.com/news/state-regional/illinois/authorities-still-conducting-search-rescue-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_63416433-ab19-5ebf-a1e0-49f379d9a4f0.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, killing at least one.\n\nThe Adams County Sheriff's office said a woman died Tuesday when her vehicle was blown off the road during the storms about 3 miles (5 kilometers) north of Corning, Iowa, or about 30 miles (48 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, where the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars.\n\nThe woman's name and age were not immediately released. She was the only occupant in the vehicle.\n\nOfficials did not immediately give details Wednesday morning of other deaths or injuries, saying they were still conducting search and rescue operations.\n\nThe tornado that tore through Greenfield also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the small town.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nQuad-Cities business openings, closings: Wolfe It Down, Azteca 3 and more 'Worst decision they ever made;' Residents hit hard by Hy-Vee's plan to close Rockingham Road store Meta named as company considering Davenport for data center; state board OKs incentives Man receives life-threatening injuries in officer-involved shooting in East Moline Friday; task force investigating Azteca 3 in Bettendorf to shutter its doors this year Orion School Board hears complaints of book being removed from curriculum Five men involved in shootings during Davenport riots in 2020 convicted of racketeering Davenport man arrested for May 5 Moline double homicide Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Weather blog: Tornado watch expires for Quad-Cities area Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds signs bill capping THC product potency, despite concerns Davenport West's Thomas wins school's first state track title since 1995 Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Quad City Bank & Trust CEO John Anderson to retire Fired employee sues Scott County, alleging retaliation for complaints against sheriff, wife\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Alex Dinkla said.\n\nImages shared to Facebook by a Greenfield resident saw entire homes reduced to rubble and turned into scattered debris, while brick walls were also flattened by the force of the twister.\n\nHeavy cleanup crews have been spotted across the state, with unaffected counties including Guthrie and Madison reportedly enlisted to help clear damage in Greenfield.\n\nEarly reports said multiple tornadoes were also reported in Montgomery County, and Meteorologists warned that the storm system across the Midwest may generate several more catastrophic-strength tornadoes.\n\nIn total across the Midwest, over 25 million people were under at least a Level 3 severe thunderstorm warnings on Tuesday evening.\n\nTrees were shredded to their roots by the force of the twisters, with meteorologists predicting more may be generated that could exceed speeds of 111mph\n\nResidents reported widespread damage to homes and businesses, although much of the early destruction struck rural areas of Iowa\n\nPower lines were downed across the state (pictured in Nevada, Iowa) that left tens of thousands without power\n\nAlthough much of the early damage was contained to rural Iowa, officials warned that several large cities and population centers could find themselves in the storm's path.\n\nChicago and Milwaukee are both at risk of being hit by destructive storms, and Des Moines International Airport closed its runways in anticipation of tornadoes potentially landing late Tuesday.\n\nMultiple regions have also seen flash flooding due to the storms, with heavy rainfall warnings instated across the Midwest.\n\nThrough Tuesday night, the Storm Prediction Center launched a rare 'potentially dangerous situation' tornado watch spanning Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Illinois.\n\nThe tornado watch is only used when experts believe there is a high chance for multiple, long-lasting tornadoes registering at EF2 or stronger, meaning speeds of at least 111mph.\n\nSeveral areas were hit with flash flooding after the storm system swept through the Midwest\n\nHeavy cleanup crews have been spotted across the state, with unaffected counties including {"uri": "8140644911", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:36:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:36:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:36:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/nation-world/weather/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_55e31959-9c0a-5372-85f2-09400c611914.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms tear through Midwest", "body": "Firefighters walks among tornado-damaged homes, Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK, Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa -- An undisclosed number of people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa after a massive tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars and also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Gerrard-Hoeschler Realtors sold, NOM Sips & Eats to open Tuesday downtown Steve Cahalan: Circle K to build its first gas station in Coulee Region Suspicious death in Trempealeau County now considered a homicide Commercial garage in La Crosse sustains heavy fire and smoke damage from Thursday blaze Race against time: La Crosse man makes dire fight for Social Security Disability Insurance 79-year-old Ferryville woman dead after UTV crash New La Crosse School Board members question $53M building referendum approved for November ballots Severe weather warnings expire in region after Altura tornado confirmed For man who found body in chimney 35 years ago, positive ID offers 'sense of closure' No one injured as blaze causes extensive fire, smoke damage to South Side La Crosse home Tuesday Kyle Larry Dahl Brian T. Morrissey Suspicious death in Ettrick under investigation by Trempealeau County Sheriff's Office Onalaska man arrested for drug overdose death in Jackson County WIAA Division 1 track and field regionals: Holmen advances in 32 events\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles east of Eau Claire, meteorologist Roy Eckberg said. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff will also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms last Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the weather service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nPhotos: Tornado devastates Greenfield as powerful storms sweep through Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8139661982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:05:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:05:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:05:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-iowa-as-powerful-storms-again-tear-through-midwest/article_36f8f81a-4c08-5658-860b-4825fbe1b41a.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms again tear through Midwest", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Officials said multiple people were killed Tuesday when a tornado ripped through a small town in Iowa, decimating homes and damaging businesses.\n\nThe town of Greenfield's hospital was among the buildings damaged -- which meant that at least a dozen people hurt had to be taken to hospitals elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of the town of 2,000 located around 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for the town and said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nMultiple tornadoes were reported throughout the state, and one also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air.\n\nWind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, turbines are designed to shut off when winds exceed certain thresholds, typically around 55 mph (89 kph). They also lock and feather their blades and turn into the wind, to minimize the strain.\n\nGreenfield bills itself on its website as a \"friendly wave as you walk\" type of place with tree-lined streets -- before the storm -- and as the \"perfect place to grow.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIn southwestern Iowa, video posted to social media showed a tornado just northwest of Red Oak. Farther east and north, the National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIowa was braced for severe weather after the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. Des Moines public schools ended classes two hours early and canceled evening activities.\n\nThe storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin Tuesday evening and night, including a warning for the capital, Madison.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility. Winds gusts of up to 45 mph (74 kph) hit the McLean area, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Chuck Schaffer.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. The total of deaths was raised Tuesday from seven to include a man who died from carbon monoxide poisoning while running a generator after his power went out. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\n___\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines and Beck reported from Omaha. {"uri": "8140478073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "13:49:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T13:49:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:49:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/us-news/multiple-dead-huge-tornado-tears-32868214", "title": "Multiple dead as huge tornado tears through towns leaving trail of devastation", "body": "Workers search through the remains of tornado-damaged property, Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa\n\nA devastating tornado has left multiple people dead and at least a dozen injured after it ripped through the state of Iowa, leaving a trail of destruction in its wake.\n\nThe town of Greenfield, home to around 2,000 residents and located approximately 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, was left in ruins after the twister struck amid a spate of severe weather that included giant hail and heavy rain across several states. Homes and businesses were flattened and destroyed, trees shredded and cars smashed.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" confirmed Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla during a press briefing on Tuesday night. While the exact number of deaths is still being ascertained, officials believe they have accounted for all residents.\n\nREAD MORE: Floods leave 7 dead as severe thunderstorms bring terrifying 'derecho storm' to Texas\n\nThe tornado wreaked havoc in Greenfield, causing extensive damage including at the local hospital, where patients were forced to evacuate and seek medical attention in neighbouring cities. Authorities have imposed strict access restrictions on Greenfield, only allowing residents to enter until Wednesday morning and instructing media to vacate the city by Tuesday night. The storm's aftermath has left parts of Greenfield in ruins, with debris from homes, trees, and vehicles scattered across the landscape.\n\nAmidst the wreckage, community members are coming together to help one another recover belongings and secure what remains of their homes. Rogue Paxton recounted his experience to WOI-TV, taking refuge in his basement as the storm passed, initially fearing his house was destroyed. \"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton shared.\n\nHe observed the solidarity among residents, saying: \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nThe state suffered multiple tornadoes, with one even toppling several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa, some of which caught fire and continued to burn for hours. Wind farms are engineered to endure tornadoes, hurricanes and other intense winds. The US Department of Energy states that turbines are programmed to shut down when wind speeds surpass certain limits, usually around 55 mph (88.5 kph). They also secure and feather their blades, and align with the wind, to reduce stress.\n\nGreenfield is a town that prides itself on its friendly atmosphere, with tree-lined streets - prior to the storm - and special holiday celebrations marked by fireworks or twinkling lights. It's also known as the \"perfect place to grow,\" where business owners recognise you and neighbours assist each other, according to its visitor's page.\n\nMary Long, who owns Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, weathered the storm at her business located in the community's historic town square, which was largely unscathed. She reported extensive damage on the east and south sides of town. \"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she recounted.\n\nFor all the latest news, politics, sports, and showbiz from the USA, go to The Mirror US\n\nCamille Blair, who works at the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office, said the office closed around 2pm before the storm hit. After the storm, she emerged from her home to witness widespread destruction and debris scattered everywhere.\n\n\"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she observed. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nIn the far southwest of Iowa, a tornado was captured on video just northwest of Red Oak. The National Weather Service issued multiple tornado warnings for areas near the towns of Griswold, Corning, Fontanelle and Guthrie Center, among others.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "https://i2-prod.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/article32868205.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/0_severe-weather-iowa-24143082973788.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": {"uri": "8140661175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:47:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:47:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:47:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/state-and-regional/mn/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_55e31959-9c0a-5372-85f2-09400c611914.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "Brian Gutmann, of Creston, Iowa, looks over tornado-damaged property, Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nBy HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, killing at least one.\n\nThe Adams County Sheriff's office said a woman died Tuesday when her vehicle was blown off the road during the storms about 3 miles (5 kilometers) north of Corning, Iowa, or about 30 miles (48 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, where the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars.\n\nThe woman's name and age were not immediately released. She was the only occupant in the vehicle.\n\nOfficials did not immediately give details Wednesday morning of other deaths or injuries, saying they were still conducting search and rescue operations.\n\nThe tornado that tore through Greenfield also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the small town.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Gerrard-Hoeschler Realtors sold, NOM Sips & Eats to open Tuesday downtown Steve Cahalan: Circle K to build its first gas station in Coulee Region Suspicious death in Trempealeau County now considered a homicide Commercial garage in La Crosse sustains heavy fire and smoke damage from Thursday blaze Race against time: La Crosse man makes dire fight for Social Security Disability Insurance 79-year-old Ferryville woman dead after UTV crash New La Crosse School Board members question $53M building referendum approved for November ballots Severe weather warnings expire in region after Altura tornado confirmed For man who found body in chimney 35 years ago, positive ID offers 'sense of closure' No one injured as blaze causes extensive fire, smoke damage to South Side La Crosse home Tuesday Kyle Larry Dahl Brian T. Morrissey Suspicious death in Ettrick under investigation by Trempealeau County Sheriff's Office Onalaska man arrested for drug overdose death in Jackson County WIAA Division 1 track and field regionals: Holmen advances in 32 events\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-21", "textStart": 2776, "textEnd": {"uri": "8141032149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "20:52:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T20:52:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T20:52:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/authorities-still-search-for-survivors-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_f05ca122-2a75-55ea-ae79-cdca5b6ab63f.html", "title": "Authorities still search for survivors after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "GREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa continued search and rescue efforts Wednesday while surviving residents picked through the debris strewn on the land where their homes had stood a day after a deadly tornado devastated the town of Greenfield and killed an undisclosed number of people.\n\nThe tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes, splintered trees and crumpled cars in Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister also ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines several miles outside the town.\n\nGreenfield resident Kimberly Ergish and her husband dug through the debris field Wednesday that used to be their home, looking for family photos and other salvageable items. There wasn't much left, she acknowledged.\n\n\"Most of it we can't save,\" she said. \"But we're going to get what we can.\"\n\nThe reality of having her house destroyed in a matter of seconds hasn't really set in, she said.\n\n\"If it weren't for all the bumps and bruises and the achy bones, I would think that it didn't happen,\" she said.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds and other officials held a news conference Wednesday morning but declined to give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris made it difficult to be sure.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states. The severe weather was expected to turn south on Wednesday, and the National Weather Service issued a tornado watch for the midsection of Texas -- including Dallas -- until 8 p.m.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday that initial surveys confirmed the damage in Greenfield indicated at least an EF-3 tornado, which would have wind speeds of 136 to 165 mph (219 to 265 kph). But additional damage assessment could show a more powerful tornado.\n\nThe deadly twister spawned during a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S., at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second-highest number of tornadoes on record in the country.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 859 confirmed tornadoes this year, 27% more than the U.S. sees on average, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. So far, Iowa's had the most, with 81 confirmed twisters.\n\nOn Tuesday alone, the National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports, with most in Iowa and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that decimated parts of Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nPeople as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos on Facebook of ripped family photos, yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the tornado.\n\nAbout 90 miles away from Greenfield, in Ames, Iowa, Nicole Banner found a yellowed page declaring \"This Book is the Property of the Greenfield Community School District\" stuck to her garage door like a Post-It note after the storm passed.\n\n\"We just couldn't believe it had traveled that far,\" she said.\n\nThe tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers), Porter said. A satellite photo taken by a BlackSky Technology shows where the twister gouged a nearly straight path of destruction through the town, just south of Greenfield's center square.\n\nWhite House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said FEMA's administrator would head to Iowa on Thursday and that the White House was in touch with state and local officials. She said they were \"praying for those who tragically lost their lives\" and wished those injured a \"speedy recovery.\"\n\nGreenfield's 25-bed hospital was among the buildings damaged, and at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school, and a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nResidential streets that on Monday were lined with old-growth trees and neatly-appointed ranch-style homes were a chaotic jumble of splintered and smashed remnants by Wednesday. Many of the homes' basements where residents sheltered lay exposed and front yards were littered with belongings from furniture to children's toys and Christmas decorations.\n\nErgish, 33, said she gathered her four kids and huddled in a corner of her basement when the sirens sounded. Seconds later, they were covered in the debris from their destroyed home.\n\n\"It was like 10 seconds of pure terror,\" she said. \"It felt like it lasted a lifetime.\"\n\nDwight Lahey, a 70-year-old retired truck driver, drove from suburban Des Moines to Greenfield to help his 98-year-old mother. She had taken refuge from the twister in her basement, then walked out through her destroyed garage to a nearby convenience store, Lahey said.\n\n\"I don't know how she got through that mess,\" he said. His mom was staying in a hotel, uncertain about where she'll end up with her home destroyed, he said.\n\nRoseann Freeland, 67, waited until the last minute to rush with her husband to a concrete room her basement. Seconds later, her husband opened the door \"and you could just see daylight,\" Freeland said. \"I just lost it. I just totally lost it.\"\n\nThe tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines just southwest of the town. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMidAmerican Energy said six of its turbines collapses, and several registered wind speeds over 100 mph (160 kph) as the tornado approached.\n\n\"This was an unprecedented impact on our wind fleet, and we have operated wind farms since 2004,\" a statement from MidAmerican read. \"We have experienced only one other instance of a wind turbine collapse, which was also caused by a tornado.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nTuesday's destructive weather also saw flooding and power outages in Nebraska, damage from tornadoes in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and dust storms in Illinois that forced two interstates to be closed.\n\nThe devastation in Iowa followed days of extreme weather that ravaged much of the middle section of the country, including Oklahoma and Kansas. Last week, deadly storms hit the Houston area, killing at least seven and knocking out power to hundreds of thousands.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@ktbs.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "margery_a_beck@ktbs.com", "name": "Margery A. "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/ktbs.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/8/36/83624cd9-ed71-550e-a404-b31f0fbe58f4/664d57f3e2268.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.207843137254902, "wgt": 185, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8140699298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:13:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:13:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:12:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/nation-world/weather/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_717d124d-a447-59c9-b9fe-9d403099e952.html", "title": "Authorities still conducting search, rescue after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK, Associated Press By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK, Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa -- Authorities in Iowa were continuing search and rescue efforts Wednesday, a day after a deadly tornado slammed the state, killing at least one.\n\nThe Adams County Sheriff's office said a woman died Tuesday when her vehicle was blown off the road during the storms about 3 miles north of Corning, Iowa, or about 30 miles southwest of Greenfield, where the tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars.\n\nThe woman's name and age were not immediately released. She was the only occupant in the vehicle.\n\nOfficials did not immediately give details Wednesday morning of other deaths or injuries, saying they were still conducting search and rescue operations.\n\nThe tornado that tore through Greenfield also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the small town.\n\nHow the feds say they caught one of St. Louis' most prolific cocaine distributors TV Q&A: Where to find the 'Monk' movie Cardinals 'City Connect' uniforms: All you need to know, from new details to Nelly's role MLB's latest broadcast move yet again aggravates some Cardinals fans: Media Views Sultan: Why aren't more of us snacking on cicadas? St. Charles County library branches may close, cut staff. Board to consider on Friday. Expect traffic snarls Sunday in downtown St. Louis with big parade, 2 sporting events Ken Smith, a SLU neurosurgeon who helped people die, dead at 91 Neman: The legend of the Des Peres pickle jar continues to fascinate and delight St. Charles County library might close 3 branches, eliminate some jobs Cardinals game suspended in the 6th; they'll wrap series against Orioles on Wednesday Critic, church mounted 'campaign' targeting St. Charles library employee, suit says BenFred: As Cardinals and Red Sox clash, what should we make of Chaim Bloom's dud in Boston? How a small gesture revealed ace Sonny Gray's big faith in Cardinals bullpen and manager Sonny Gray expected the manager to come get him. Oliver Marmol sent a different message.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that hit Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar-confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.\n\n0 Comments Tags Lee-national", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@stltoday.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "scott_mcfetridge@stltoday.com", "name": "Scott McFETRIDGE", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "margery_a_beck@stltoday.com", "name": "Margery A.
