multiple people in a small Iowa town as powerful storms swept through the Midwest.\n\nHomes and businesses in Greenfield were destroyed, cars smashed and debris strewn across the landscape.\n\nIowa police confirmed the fatalities at a news briefing on Tuesday night, but were unable to say how many.\n\nNebraska, Illinois and Wisconsin were also hit by tornados, heavy rain and power cuts.\n\nVideo footage showing the devastation across Iowa depicted flattened buildings, overturned cars and broken wind turbines.\n\nGreenfield, a town of 2,000 people about 55 miles from Des Moines, endured the deadliest tornado of all.\n\nThe town's hospital was among the buildings damaged, forcing the dozen people who were injured to go elsewhere.\n\nA \"good portion\" of Greenfield is devastated, Iowa State Patrol Sgt Alex Dinkla told reporters on Tuesday night.\n\nThe death toll was unknown, he said, adding: \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nEveryone who lives in the town seems to be {"uri": "2024-05-364716502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:17:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:17:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:08:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://eu.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/2024/05/22/greenfield-iowa-tornado-fatalities-what-we-know/73800145007/", "title": "Where is Greenfield, Iowa? Here's what we know about the deadly tornado", "body": "Colton and Shaye Newberry explain the terrifying moments when a powerful tornado struck the town of Greenfield, Iowa, obliterating the house where they were taking shelter.\n\nMultiple residents were killed, and at least a dozen others injured, after a tornado hit the small town of Greenfield on May 21.\n\nThe destruction comes after multiple rounds of storms plagued the state Tuesday, and nearly a month after at least 24 tornadoes swept through the state and devastated the western town of Minden.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds announced she would visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning to assess the damage with local officials in a statement made Tuesday night.\n\nSgt. Alex Dinkla, spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, confirmed the deaths at a news conference Tuesday night and estimated at least a dozen people were hospitalized. He did not know the exact number of those killed or injured. Dinkla did not think people were still missing as of Tuesday evening, but searches were still underway to confirm.\n\nDinkla did tell the Register on Wednesday that the town square and Wilson Opera House were spared.\n\nStructures in the path of the tornado are now rubble, as evidenced by drone video posted to social media.\n\nDamage also extends to the Adair County Health System hospital. The hospital was evacuated, a MercyOne spokesperson told the Des Moines Register.\n\nWhat is the population of Greenfield, Iowa?\n\nThe total population of the town located in Adair County about 2,000 people, according to the U.S Census Bureau.\n\nHow far is Greenfield, Iowa to Des Moines, Iowa? Where is Greenfield?\n\nGreenfield is the county seat of Adair County. It's about 60 miles southwest of Des Moines, or about an hour drive, according to Google Maps.\n\nWhat is the Greenfield, Iowa tornado rating?\n\nInformation is not yet available about the Greenfield tornado, but meteorologists have described the May 21 tornado as a \"dangerous tornado.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Des Moines will send three survey crews across the state to search for tornado damage on Wednesday. One team will be focused on just the Greenfield area.\n\nWhat is the history of Greenfield, Iowa?\n\nGreenfield became a settlement in 1854, according to the Greenfield Chamber Main Street.\n\nIt's home to the Iowa Aviation Museum and Hall of Fame and the Warren Cultural Center -- composed of the 1896 Warren Opera House and adjoining Hetherington and Taylor buildings, according to Greenfield Chamber.\n\nThe Warren Opera House block and Hetherington block is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Another National Register of Historic Places listing for Greenfield is Hotel Greenfield, which was built in 1919 for about $65,000, according to the hotel. The hotel was refurbished after it was purchased in 2010 to ADCO Enterprises, according to the hotel.\n\nWill Greenfield, Iowa tornado change RAGBRAI 2024 route?\n\nGreenfield is supposed to host Register's Annual Great Bicycle Ride Across Iowa this July as a Day 3 meetup town. Red Oak, which also experienced tornado damage on Tuesday, is the Day 1 overnight town.\n\nAnne Lawrie, director of the cycling division of Ventures Endurance, the subsidiary of Register owner Gannett that operates the weeklong ride, said RAGBRAI had no comment as of early Wednesday morning on how the ride might be affected.\n\nDes Moines Register reporters Kyle Werner and Lee Rood contributed to {"uri": "8141117011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "22:23:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T22:23:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T22:22:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/authorities-searching-for-survivors-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_40e2767c-7867-526f-a227-a6c3ac96c087.html", "title": "Authorities searching for survivors after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Crews moved methodically Wednesday through a small Iowa town devastated by a powerful tornado, searching through mounds of debris to be sure no victims remained buried in the rubble, but authorities would not say how many were killed or injured in the storm.\n\nThe tornado Tuesday afternoon left a wide swath of obliterated homes, splintered trees and crumpled cars in Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister also ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines several miles outside the town.\n\n\"It's still a search mission as far as we're looking to be sure all residents are accounted for,\" said Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Tree crushes pickup truck in Waterloo UPDATED WITH ADDITIONAL ROADS: Black Hawk County announces road closures due to flooding Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Traer man arrested in 106-mph chase through Waterloo-Cedar Falls My Waterloo Days schedule set for June 6-8 festival, including nationally known musical acts Bicycling child injured after being hit by car at Hudson, Greenhill Roads in Cedar Falls Man now charged with vandalizing mayor's, supervisor's vehicles MasterBrand will acquire Bertch parent company Supreme Cabinetry Brands Waterloo man who allegedly left dog in hot car charged with animal's death Two arrested in Friday robbery More than 1,600 Waterloo homes without power due to MidAmerican outage Two people charged with submitting fake lottery tickets, accepting winnings Leadership changes at Bremer County Emergency Management Cedar Falls could take next steps to approve Boulder Tap House restaurant\n\nGreenfield resident Kimberly Ergish, 33, and her husband dug through the debris field Wednesday that used to be their home, looking for family photos and other salvageable items. There wasn't much left, she acknowledged.\n\n\"Most of it we can't save,\" she said. \"But we're going to get what we can.\"\n\nThe reality of having her house destroyed in seconds hasn't really set in, she said.\n\n\"If it weren't for all the bumps and bruises and the achy bones, I would think that it didn't happen,\" she said.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nAt a news conference Wednesday, neither Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds nor other officials would give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris made it difficult to be sure.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states. The severe weather was expected to turn south on Wednesday, and the National Weather Service issued a tornado watch for the midsection of Texas -- including Dallas -- until 8 p.m.\n\nThe National Weather Service said initial surveys indicated at least an EF-3 tornado in Greenfield, but additional damage assessment could lead to a more powerful ranking.\n\nThe tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers), AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said. A satellite photo taken by a BlackSky Technology shows where the twister gouged a nearly straight path of destruction through the town, just south of Greenfield's center square.\n\nThe deadly twister was spawned during a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S., at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second-highest number of tornadoes on record in the country.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 859 confirmed tornadoes this year, 27% more than the U.S. sees on average, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. So far, Iowa's had the most, with 81 confirmed twisters.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOn Tuesday alone, the National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports, with most in Iowa and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that decimated parts of Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nPeople as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos on Facebook of ripped family photos, yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the tornado.\n\nAbout 90 miles away, in Ames, Iowa, Nicole Banner found a yellowed page declaring \"This Book is the Property of the Greenfield Community School District\" stuck to her garage door like a Post-It note after the storm passed.\n\n\"We just couldn't believe it had traveled that far,\" she said.\n\nWhite House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said FEMA's administrator would head to Iowa on Thursday and that the White House was in touch with state and local officials. She said they were \"praying for those who tragically lost their lives\" and wished those injured a \"speedy recovery.\"\n\nGreenfield's 25-bed hospital was among the buildings damaged, and at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school, and a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nResidential streets that on Monday were lined with old-growth trees and neatly-appointed ranch-style homes were a chaotic jumble of splintered and smashed remnants by Wednesday. Many of the homes' basements where residents sheltered lay exposed and front yards were littered with belongings from furniture to children's toys and Christmas decorations.\n\nDwight Lahey, a 70-year-old retired truck driver, drove from suburban Des Moines to Greenfield to help his 98-year-old mother. She had taken refuge from the twister in her basement, then walked out through her destroyed garage to a nearby convenience store, Lahey said.\n\n\"I don't know how she got through that mess,\" he said. His mom was staying in a hotel, uncertain about where she'll end up with her home gone, he said.\n\nRoseann Freeland, 67, waited until the last minute to rush with her husband to a concrete room in her basement. Seconds later, her husband opened the door \"and you could just see daylight,\" Freeland said. \"I just lost it. I just totally lost it.\"\n\nTuesday's destructive weather also saw flooding and power outages in Nebraska, damage from tornadoes in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and dust storms in Illinois that forced two interstates to be closed.\n\nThe devastation in Iowa followed days of extreme weather that ravaged much of the middle section of the country, including Oklahoma and Kansas. Last week, deadly storms hit the Houston area, killing at least seven and knocking out power to hundreds of thousands.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 94}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/wcfcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/2a/72a9085f-f8c3-581e-83a8-183a8d29f23a/664d59d858855.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9588360", "eventUri": "eng-9588360", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-06", "dateEnd": "2024-06-08", "textStart": 1205, "textEnd": 1213}], "sentiment": -0.2470588235294118, "wgt": 175, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8141051719", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "21:11:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T21:11:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T21:11:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/state-and-regional/nebraska/authorities-still-search-for-survivors-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_3e2809b0-17ea-5d6e-9060-90e4e4dc0f41.html", "title": "Authorities still search for survivors after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa continued search and rescue efforts Wednesday while surviving residents picked through the debris strewn on the land where their homes had stood a day after a deadly tornado devastated the town of Greenfield and killed an undisclosed number of people.\n\nThe tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes, splintered trees and crumpled cars in Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister also ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines several miles outside the town.\n\nGreenfield resident Kimberly Ergish and her husband dug through the debris field Wednesday that used to be their home, looking for family photos and other salvageable items. There wasn't much left, she acknowledged.\n\nPeople are also reading... South Sioux City senior who has been homeless, finds home at school UPDATED: West Middle assistant principal keeps job after Sioux City School Board vote Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Wells gives $1 million to Le Mars daycare center Man linked to missing Nebraska girl faces federal charges in Sioux City Hinton denies coaches, administrators knew about wrestling abuses How a Sioux City landlord is recouping cost of bridal shop bankruptcy with liquidation sale UPDATED: Sioux City officers doubted fatal shooting suspect was intoxicated Sergeant Bluff-Luton proposing three-phased bond plan for new facilities 2 students, driver hurt in Le Mars school bus crash Sioux City man found guilty of sexually assaulting 13-year-old girl Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for May 20, 2024 Morningside Days Parade kickstarts summer with focus on community Column: Even track & field's individual champions lean on teammates Live updates: Omaha metro floods, power outages close schools, businesses\n\n\"Most of it we can't save,\" she said. \"But we're going to get what we can.\"\n\nThe reality of having her house destroyed in a matter of seconds hasn't really set in, she said.\n\n\"If it weren't for all the bumps and bruises and the achy bones, I would think that it didn't happen,\" she said.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds and other officials held a news conference Wednesday morning but declined to give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris made it difficult to be sure.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states. The severe weather was expected to turn south on Wednesday, and the National Weather Service issued a tornado watch for the midsection of Texas -- including Dallas -- until 8 p.m.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday that initial surveys confirmed the damage in Greenfield indicated at least an EF-3 tornado, which would have wind speeds of 136 to 165 mph (219 to 265 kph). But additional damage assessment could show a more powerful tornado.\n\nThe deadly twister spawned during a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S., at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second-highest number of tornadoes on record in the country.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 859 confirmed tornadoes this year, 27% more than the U.S. sees on average, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. So far, Iowa's had the most, with 81 confirmed twisters.\n\nOn Tuesday alone, the National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports, with most in Iowa and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that decimated parts of Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nPeople as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos on Facebook of ripped family photos, yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the tornado.\n\nAbout 90 miles away from Greenfield, in Ames, Iowa, Nicole Banner found a yellowed page declaring \"This Book is the Property of the Greenfield Community School District\" stuck to her garage door like a Post-It note after the storm passed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"We just couldn't believe it had traveled that far,\" she said.\n\nThe tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers), Porter said. A satellite photo taken by a BlackSky Technology shows where the twister gouged a nearly straight path of destruction through the town, just south of Greenfield's center square.\n\nWhite House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said FEMA's administrator would head to Iowa on Thursday and that the White House was in touch with state and local officials. She said they were \"praying for those who tragically lost their lives\" and wished those injured a \"speedy recovery.\"\n\nGreenfield's 25-bed hospital was among the buildings damaged, and at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school, and a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nResidential streets that on Monday were lined with old-growth trees and neatly-appointed ranch-style homes were a chaotic jumble of splintered and smashed remnants by Wednesday. Many of the homes' basements where residents sheltered lay exposed and front yards were littered with belongings from furniture to children's toys and Christmas decorations.\n\nErgish, 33, said she gathered her four kids and huddled in a corner of her basement when the sirens sounded. Seconds later, they were covered in the debris from their destroyed home.\n\n\"It was like 10 seconds of pure terror,\" she said. \"It felt like it lasted a lifetime.\"\n\nDwight Lahey, a 70-year-old retired truck driver, drove from suburban Des Moines to Greenfield to help his 98-year-old mother. She had taken refuge from the twister in her basement, then walked out through her destroyed garage to a nearby convenience store, Lahey said.\n\n\"I don't know how she got through that mess,\" he said. His mom was staying in a hotel, uncertain about where she'll end up with her home destroyed, he said.\n\nRoseann Freeland, 67, waited until the last minute to rush with her husband to a concrete room her basement. Seconds later, her husband opened the door \"and you could just see daylight,\" Freeland said. \"I just lost it. I just totally lost it.\"\n\nThe tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines just southwest of the town. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMidAmerican Energy said six of its turbines collapses, and several registered wind speeds over 100 mph (160 kph) as the tornado approached.\n\n\"This was an unprecedented impact on our wind fleet, and we have operated wind farms since 2004,\" a statement from MidAmerican read. \"We have experienced only one other instance of a wind turbine collapse, which was also caused by a tornado.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nTuesday's destructive weather also saw flooding and power outages in Nebraska, damage from tornadoes in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and dust storms in Illinois that forced two interstates to be closed.\n\nThe devastation in Iowa followed days of extreme weather that ravaged much of the middle section of the country, including Oklahoma and Kansas. Last week, deadly storms hit the Houston area, killing at least seven and knocking out power to hundreds of thousands.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8139912922", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "08:06:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T08:06:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T08:05:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2024/05/22/3090737/iowa-tornado-kills-people-in-small-town-reduced-to-rubble", "title": "Iowa Tornado Kills People in Small Town Reduced to Rubble - Other Media news - Tasnim News Agency", "body": "TEHRAN (Tasnim) - A powerful tornado ripped through a small Iowa town on May 21, killing multiple people and leaving at least a dozen injured, authorities said.\n\nImages from the town of Greenfield show a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled.\n\n\"This tornado has devastated a good portion of this town,\" said Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, during an evening press conference in Greenfield.\n\n\"We can confirm there have been multiple fatalities with this tornado.\"\n\nAt least a dozen people in Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 people, were injured in the twister, Dinkla said. Because the local hospital sustained damage in the storm, those people had to be transferred to facilities in nearby towns.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe {"uri": "2024-05-364017296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "02:55:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T02:55:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-21T22:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-05-21/fatal-storms-pummel-iowa-reducing-parts-of-one-town-to-rubble", "title": "Iowa Tornado Kills 'Multiple' People in Small Town Reduced to Rubble", "body": "(Reuters) -A powerful tornado ripped through a small Iowa town on Tuesday, killing multiple people and leaving at least a dozen injured, authorities said.\n\nImages from the town of Greenfield show a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled.\n\n\"This tornado has devastated a good portion of this town,\" said Sgt. Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, during an evening press conference in Greenfield.\n\n\"We can confirm there have been multiple fatalities with this tornado.\"\n\nDinkla did not provide a death toll, but said it may not be before Wednesday that figures could be provided.\n\nAt least a dozen people in Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 people, were injured in the twister, Dinkla said. Because the local hospital sustained damage in the storm, those people had to be transferred to facilities in nearby towns.\n\n\"I've lived here all my life. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, told CBS affiliate KCCI TV in an interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nOther video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nAt least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAlso in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. It said several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin.\n\nEarlier in the day, the weather service confirmed at least one tornado over Rollingstone, Minnesota.\n\n(Reporting by Brad Brooks in Longmont, Colorado, and Steve Gorman in Los Angeles; Editing by Sonali Paul and Michael Perry)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, {"uri": "8141106150", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "22:10:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T22:10:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T22:09:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/state-and-regional/iowa/authorities-searching-for-survivors-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_3e2809b0-17ea-5d6e-9060-90e4e4dc0f41.html", "title": "Authorities searching for survivors after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Crews moved methodically Wednesday through a small Iowa town devastated by a powerful tornado, searching through mounds of debris to be sure no victims remained buried in the rubble, but authorities would not say how many were killed or injured in the storm.\n\nThe tornado Tuesday afternoon left a wide swath of obliterated homes, splintered trees and crumpled cars in Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister also ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines several miles outside the town.\n\n\"It's still a search mission as far as we're looking to be sure all residents are accounted for,\" said Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\nPeople are also reading... South Sioux City senior who has been homeless, finds home at school UPDATED: West Middle assistant principal keeps job after Sioux City School Board vote Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Wells gives $1 million to Le Mars daycare center Man linked to missing Nebraska girl faces federal charges in Sioux City Hinton denies coaches, administrators knew about wrestling abuses How a Sioux City landlord is recouping cost of bridal shop bankruptcy with liquidation sale UPDATED: Sioux City officers doubted fatal shooting suspect was intoxicated Sergeant Bluff-Luton proposing three-phased bond plan for new facilities 2 students, driver hurt in Le Mars school bus crash Sioux City man found guilty of sexually assaulting 13-year-old girl Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for May 20, 2024 Morningside Days Parade kickstarts summer with focus on community Column: Even track & field's individual champions lean on teammates Live updates: Omaha metro floods, power outages close schools, businesses\n\nGreenfield resident Kimberly Ergish, 33, and her husband dug through the debris field Wednesday that used to be their home, looking for family photos and other salvageable items. There wasn't much left, she acknowledged.\n\n\"Most of it we can't save,\" she said. \"But we're going to get what we can.\"\n\nThe reality of having her house destroyed in seconds hasn't really set in, she said.\n\n\"If it weren't for all the bumps and bruises and the achy bones, I would think that it didn't happen,\" she said.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nAt a news conference Wednesday, neither Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds nor other officials would give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris made it difficult to be sure.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states. The severe weather was expected to turn south on Wednesday, and the National Weather Service issued a tornado watch for the midsection of Texas -- including Dallas -- until 8 p.m.\n\nThe National Weather Service said initial surveys indicated at least an EF-3 tornado in Greenfield, but additional damage assessment could lead to a more powerful ranking.\n\nThe tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers), AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said. A satellite photo taken by a BlackSky Technology shows where the twister gouged a nearly straight path of destruction through the town, just south of Greenfield's center square.\n\nThe deadly twister was spawned during a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S., at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second-highest number of tornadoes on record in the country.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 859 confirmed tornadoes this year, 27% more than the U.S. sees on average, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. So far, Iowa's had the most, with 81 confirmed twisters.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOn Tuesday alone, the National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports, with most in Iowa and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that decimated parts of Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nPeople as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos on Facebook of ripped family photos, yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the tornado.\n\nAbout 90 miles away, in Ames, Iowa, Nicole Banner found a yellowed page declaring \"This Book is the Property of the Greenfield Community School District\" stuck to her garage door like a Post-It note after the storm passed.\n\n\"We just couldn't believe it had traveled that far,\" she said.\n\nWhite House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said FEMA's administrator would head to Iowa on Thursday and that the White House was in touch with state and local officials. She said they were \"praying for those who tragically lost their lives\" and wished those injured a \"speedy recovery.\"\n\nGreenfield's 25-bed hospital was among the buildings damaged, and at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school, and a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nResidential streets that on Monday were lined with old-growth trees and neatly-appointed ranch-style homes were a chaotic jumble of splintered and smashed remnants by Wednesday. Many of the homes' basements where residents sheltered lay exposed and front yards were littered with belongings from furniture to children's toys and Christmas decorations.\n\nDwight Lahey, a 70-year-old retired truck driver, drove from suburban Des Moines to Greenfield to help his 98-year-old mother. She had taken refuge from the twister in her basement, then walked out through her destroyed garage to a nearby convenience store, Lahey said.\n\n\"I don't know how she got through that mess,\" he said. His mom was staying in a hotel, uncertain about where she'll end up with her home gone, he said.\n\nRoseann Freeland, 67, waited until the last minute to rush with her husband to a concrete room in her basement. Seconds later, her husband opened the door \"and you could just see daylight,\" Freeland said. \"I just lost it. I just totally lost it.\"\n\nTuesday's destructive weather also saw flooding and power outages in Nebraska, damage from tornadoes in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and dust storms in Illinois that forced two interstates to be closed.\n\nThe devastation in Iowa followed days of extreme weather that ravaged much of the middle section of the country, including Oklahoma and Kansas. Last week, deadly storms hit the Houston area, killing at least seven and knocking out power to hundreds of thousands.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8140643157", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:35:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:35:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:34:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_717d124d-a447-59c9-b9fe-9d403099e952.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms again tear through Midwest", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- An undisclosed number of people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa, leaving a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars and also twisting and toppling wind turbines outside of the town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nThe deadly twister that slammed Iowa came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nHow the feds say they caught one of St. Louis' most prolific cocaine distributors TV Q&A: Where to find the 'Monk' movie Cardinals 'City Connect' uniforms: All you need to know, from new details to Nelly's role MLB's latest broadcast move yet again aggravates some Cardinals fans: Media Views Sultan: Why aren't more of us snacking on cicadas? St. Charles County library branches may close, cut staff. Board to consider on Friday. Expect traffic snarls Sunday in downtown St. Louis with big parade, 2 sporting events Ken Smith, a SLU neurosurgeon who helped people die, dead at 91 Neman: The legend of the Des Peres pickle jar continues to fascinate and delight St. Charles County library might close 3 branches, eliminate some jobs BenFred: As Cardinals and Red Sox clash, what should we make of Chaim Bloom's dud in Boston? Critic, church mounted 'campaign' targeting St. Charles library employee, suit says Sonny Gray expected the manager to come get him. Oliver Marmol sent a different message. How a small gesture revealed ace Sonny Gray's big faith in Cardinals bullpen and manager Firm that accused ex-Mercy executive of bribery and extortion sues the health system\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nDinkla said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nOn Facebook, people as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos of ripped family photos, check stubs, damp yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the Greenfield tornado.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles (89 kilometers) east of Eau Claire, said meteorologist Roy Eckberg. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles (32 kilometers) southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph (113 kilometers per hour) in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff would also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms last Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the weather service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nMcFetridge reported from Des Moines, Iowa, and Beck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis, Josh Funk in Omaha, Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8141038005", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "20:59:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T20:59:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T20:58:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/state-and-regional/authorities-still-search-for-survivors-after-tornado-slams-iowa-at-least-1-dead/article_40e2767c-7867-526f-a227-a6c3ac96c087.html", "title": "Authorities still search for survivors after tornado slams Iowa; at least 1 dead", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT and MARGERY A. BECK - Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa (AP) -- Authorities in Iowa continued search and rescue efforts Wednesday while surviving residents picked through the debris strewn on the land where their homes had stood a day after a deadly tornado devastated the town of Greenfield and killed an undisclosed number of people.\n\nThe tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes, splintered trees and crumpled cars in Greenfield, a town of 2,000 about 55 miles (88.5 kilometers) southwest of Des Moines. The twister also ripped apart and crumpled massive power-producing wind turbines several miles outside the town.\n\nGreenfield resident Kimberly Ergish and her husband dug through the debris field Wednesday that used to be their home, looking for family photos and other salvageable items. There wasn't much left, she acknowledged.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase Tree crushes pickup truck in Waterloo UPDATED WITH ADDITIONAL ROADS: Black Hawk County announces road closures due to flooding Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Traer man arrested in 106-mph chase through Waterloo-Cedar Falls My Waterloo Days schedule set for June 6-8 festival, including nationally known musical acts Bicycling child injured after being hit by car at Hudson, Greenhill Roads in Cedar Falls Man now charged with vandalizing mayor's, supervisor's vehicles Waterloo man who allegedly left dog in hot car charged with animal's death MasterBrand will acquire Bertch parent company Supreme Cabinetry Brands Two arrested in Friday robbery More than 1,600 Waterloo homes without power due to MidAmerican outage Two people charged with submitting fake lottery tickets, accepting winnings Leadership changes at Bremer County Emergency Management Cedar Falls could take next steps to approve Boulder Tap House restaurant\n\n\"Most of it we can't save,\" she said. \"But we're going to get what we can.\"\n\nThe reality of having her house destroyed in a matter of seconds hasn't really set in, she said.\n\n\"If it weren't for all the bumps and bruises and the achy bones, I would think that it didn't happen,\" she said.\n\nAbout 25 miles (40 kilometers) southwest of Greenfield, a woman died Tuesday when the vehicle she was driving was blown off the road near Corning, Iowa, the Adams County Sheriff's office said. The woman's name and age were not immediately released.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds and other officials held a news conference Wednesday morning but declined to give details of the number of dead and missing in Greenfield, noting that the amount of devastation and debris made it difficult to be sure.\n\nLater Tuesday, the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states. The severe weather was expected to turn south on Wednesday, and the National Weather Service issued a tornado watch for the midsection of Texas -- including Dallas -- until 8 p.m.\n\nThe National Weather Service said Wednesday that initial surveys confirmed the damage in Greenfield indicated at least an EF-3 tornado, which would have wind speeds of 136 to 165 mph (219 to 265 kph). But additional damage assessment could show a more powerful tornado.\n\nThe deadly twister spawned during a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S., at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second-highest number of tornadoes on record in the country.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there have been 859 confirmed tornadoes this year, 27% more than the U.S. sees on average, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. So far, Iowa's had the most, with 81 confirmed twisters.\n\nOn Tuesday alone, the National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports, with most in Iowa and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe tornado that decimated parts of Greenfield brought to life the worst case scenario in Iowa that weather forecasters had feared, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"Debris was lifted thousands of feet in the air and ended up falling to the ground several counties away from Greenfield. That's evidence of just how intense and deadly this tornado was,\" Porter said.\n\nPeople as far as 100 miles (160 kilometers) away from Greenfield posted photos on Facebook of ripped family photos, yearbook pages and other items that were lifted into the sky by the tornado.\n\nAbout 90 miles away from Greenfield, in Ames, Iowa, Nicole Banner found a yellowed page declaring \"This Book is the Property of the Greenfield Community School District\" stuck to her garage door like a Post-It note after the storm passed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"We just couldn't believe it had traveled that far,\" she said.\n\nThe tornado appeared to have been on the ground for more than 40 miles (64 kilometers), Porter said. A satellite photo taken by a BlackSky Technology shows where the twister gouged a nearly straight path of destruction through the town, just south of Greenfield's center square.\n\nWhite House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said FEMA's administrator would head to Iowa on Thursday and that the White House was in touch with state and local officials. She said they were \"praying for those who tragically lost their lives\" and wished those injured a \"speedy recovery.\"\n\nGreenfield's 25-bed hospital was among the buildings damaged, and at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere. A triage center was set up for the injured at the Greenfield high school, and a Methodist Church also was being used to treat the injured.\n\nResidential streets that on Monday were lined with old-growth trees and neatly-appointed ranch-style homes were a chaotic jumble of splintered and smashed remnants by Wednesday. Many of the homes' basements where residents sheltered lay exposed and front yards were littered with belongings from furniture to children's toys and Christmas decorations.\n\nErgish, 33, said she gathered her four kids and huddled in a corner of her basement when the sirens sounded. Seconds later, they were covered in the debris from their destroyed home.\n\n\"It was like 10 seconds of pure terror,\" she said. \"It felt like it lasted a lifetime.\"\n\nDwight Lahey, a 70-year-old retired truck driver, drove from suburban Des Moines to Greenfield to help his 98-year-old mother. She had taken refuge from the twister in her basement, then walked out through her destroyed garage to a nearby convenience store, Lahey said.\n\n\"I don't know how she got through that mess,\" he said. His mom was staying in a hotel, uncertain about where she'll end up with her home destroyed, he said.\n\nRoseann Freeland, 67, waited until the last minute to rush with her husband to a concrete room her basement. Seconds later, her husband opened the door \"and you could just see daylight,\" Freeland said. \"I just lost it. I just totally lost it.\"\n\nThe tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot (76-meter) wind turbines just southwest of the town. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMidAmerican Energy said six of its turbines collapses, and several registered wind speeds over 100 mph (160 kph) as the tornado approached.\n\n\"This was an unprecedented impact on our wind fleet, and we have operated wind farms since 2004,\" a statement from MidAmerican read. \"We have experienced only one other instance of a wind turbine collapse, which was also caused by a tornado.\"\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nTuesday's destructive weather also saw flooding and power outages in Nebraska, damage from tornadoes in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and dust storms in Illinois that forced two interstates to be closed.\n\nThe devastation in Iowa followed days of extreme weather that ravaged much of the middle section of the country, including Oklahoma and Kansas. Last week, deadly storms hit the Houston area, killing at least seven and knocking out power to hundreds of thousands.\n\nBeck reported from Omaha, Nebraska. Associated Press writers Steve Karnowski in Minneapolis; Josh Funk in Omaha, Nebraska; Colleen Slevin in Denver and Juan Lozano in Houston contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. The tornado destroyed much of the small Iowa town of Greenfield. Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla says at least a dozen people were injured amid widespread devastation in Greenfield. Tuesday saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. {"uri": "8139626897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:33:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:33:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:32:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://todayheadline.co/multiple-people-are-killed-as-deadly-tornadoes-rip-through-iowa-15-counties-declared-disaster-zones-with-hospital-forced-to-evacuate-homes-toppled-and-25-million-under-severe-warnings/", "title": "Multiple people are killed as deadly tornadoes rip through Iowa: 15 counties declared disaster zones with hospital forced to evacuate, homes toppled and 25 million under severe warnings", "body": "Powerful tornadoes have ripped apart rural Iowa and left a trail of destruction across the state - killing multiple people and injuring dozens of blighted residents.\n\nEntire neighborhoods were flattened by the deadly twisters which gripped the region on Tuesday evening, with Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds placing 15 counties under disaster emergency proclamations.\n\nA local hospital was hit by the fierce tornadoes, forcing staff and patients to evacuate the ransacked buildings and set up field hospitals at nearby high schools.\n\nCarnage is expected to continue through the Midwest as a storm system develops overnight - with over 25 million people currently under severe weather warnings, stretching from Missouri to Wisconsin.\n\nIowa Police confirmed there have been multiple fatalities in the deadly weather front. One death occurred in Adams County, Iowa, around 90 miles southwest of Des Moines, when a woman was ejected from a vehicle during the brutal storm.\n\nFootage showed widespread damage hours after the tornadoes tore through rural Iowa, including entire trees being shredded from their roots.\n\nThe small town of Greenfield, around 40 miles from the death in Adams County, was among the hardest hit, and a tornado that developed around 5pm leveled hundreds of homes and left several people injured, Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt. Alex Dinkla said.\n\nAt a press conference, Dinkla estimated that over a dozen people were hospitalized, but could not offer an exact number. He added that all known residents were accounted for, but searches were still ongoing through the wreckage.\n\nImages shared to Facebook by a Greenfield resident saw entire homes reduced to rubble and turned into scattered debris, while brick walls were flattened by the force of the twister.\n\nMassive wind turbines were also destroyed by the gusts, with at least three turbines destroyed in Adams County, and MidAmerican Energy Company said it owned several more that were destroyed in Adair County.\n\nWhile aiding injured residents, the Adair County Memorial Hospital also 'sustained tornado damage', officials said, that forced it to transfer patients to other nearby medical centers.\n\nGreenfield instated a mandatory curfew from 10pm to 7am as the aftermath is surveyed, however officials said the true extent of the devastation may not be clear until daybreak.\n\nHeavy cleanup crews have been spotted across the state, with unaffected counties including Guthrie and Madison reportedly enlisted to help clear damage in Greenfield.\n\nEarly reports said multiple tornadoes were also reported in Montgomery County, and Meteorologists warned that the storm system across the Midwest may generate several more catastrophic-strength tornadoes.\n\nIn total across the Midwest, over 25 million people were under at least a Level 3 severe thunderstorm warnings on Tuesday evening.\n\nIt comes after a period of intense storms through the nation's heartland in recent days, including three minor tornadoes registered Monday in Minnesota, Nebraska and Colorado.\n\nAlthough much of the early damage was contained to rural Iowa, officials warned that several large cities and population centers could find themselves in the storm's path.\n\nChicago and Milwaukee are both at risk of being hit by destructive storms, and Des Moines International Airport closed its runways in anticipation of tornadoes potentially landing late Tuesday.\n\nMultiple regions have also seen flash flooding due to the storms, with heavy rainfall warnings instated across the Midwest.\n\nThrough Tuesday night, the Storm Prediction Center launched a rare 'potentially dangerous situation' tornado watch spanning Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Illinois.\n\nThe tornado watch is only used when experts believe there is a high chance for multiple, long-lasting tornadoes registering at EF2 or stronger, meaning speeds of at least 111mph.\n\nResidents in Greenfield described witnessing the devastation across their town, with Valerie Warrior telling KCCI she was our riding her bike when the storm descended.\n\n'There's houses down all over the place,' Warrior said, noting that she raced to her basement to wait out the tornado before emerging to find the town covered in debris.\n\n'Devastating,' she added.\n\nStunning images from storm chaser Nahel Belgherze focused on the damage seen in one Greenfield street, as a sleepy suburb was turned into rubble within hours.\n\nResident Donnell Griffith said despite the carnage, the small town of roughly 2,000 people will recover from the storms.\n\n'We're a small community, we're a tough community... we will rebuild this community together,' she said.", "source": {"uri": "todayheadline.co", "dataType": "news", "title": "TodayHeadline"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8139710050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "05:47:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T05:47:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:45:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/iowa-multiple-fatalities-as-tornadoes-ravage-midwest-severe-storms-leave-trail-of-destruction/2095983/", "title": "Iowa: Multiple fatalities as tornadoes ravage Midwest, severe storms leave trail of destruction", "body": "In the small city of Greenfield, Iowa, located approximately 50 miles southwest of Des Moines, a destructive storm unleashed a tornado shortly before 5 pm, causing extensive damage to numerous homes and structures, according to Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt Alex Dinkla. \"Sadly, we can confirm that there have been fatalities with this tornado,\" Dinkla stated during a subsequent news conference, though he refrained from providing further details on the casualties.\n\nResidents in Greenfield were also left injured, and a local hospital suffered tornado damage, prompting the transfer of patients to nearby medical facilities, Sgt Dinkla confirmed, according to CNN.\n\nFootage captured by CNN affiliate KCCI depicted the trail of destruction left by the tornado in Greenfield, showcasing decimated homes, flattened structures, heaps of debris, damaged vehicles, and countless uprooted trees. \"There is basically nothing left,\" remarked Clel Baudler, a former Iowa state representative residing half a mile from Greenfield, emphasising the tornado's devastating impact.\n\nTragically, another storm-related fatality occurred in Adams County, Iowa, approximately 90 miles southwest of Des Moines, as confirmed by county medical examiner Lisa Brown. While Brown was unable to provide additional details on the incident, she attributed the death to a tornado.\n\nThe potent line of thunderstorms that swept through the region on Tuesday prompted a rare \"potentially dangerous situation\" tornado watch for parts of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Illinois, according to the Storm Prediction Center. This special tornado watch is only issued when there is a high level of confidence in the potential for multiple long-lived and EF2 or stronger tornadoes.\n\nIn response to the storm outbreak, Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds authorized a proclamation of disaster emergency for 15 counties, enabling state resources to aid in response and recovery efforts. Governor Reynolds announced her intention to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning to assess the damage firsthand, vowing to provide the full support of the state.\n\nAs of late Tuesday evening, over 30,000 customers were without power in Iowa, according to Poweroutage.us.\n\nThe severe thunderstorm outbreak on Tuesday also posed other serious hazards, including destructive hurricane-strength wind gusts of up to 90 mph and softball-size hail. More than 25 million people across the region were under a Level 3 of 5 or Level 4 of 5 risk of severe thunderstorms, according to the SPC.\n\nThe largest area of concern for widespread, hazardous impacts centered on much of Iowa, northwest Illinois, southwest Wisconsin, and northern Missouri. Major population centers such as Chicago and Milwaukee were also at risk of damaging storms.\n\nThe Des Moines International Airport temporarily closed late Tuesday afternoon as dangerous storms approached the area, prompting tornado warnings. Emergency management officials in Montgomery County, Iowa, confirmed the occurrence of \"multiple tornadoes\" within the county, though no injuries were reported at the time. Damage assessments were underway, with officials working to clear roads for access to affected properties, as reported by CNN.\n\nIn addition to tornadoes, flash flooding triggered by heavy rainfall posed a threat for parts of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Nebraska, where flood and tornado watches were in effect. Rainfall totals of 1 to 3 inches were possible, with some areas expecting up to 5 inches.\n\nSevere storms were forecasted to peak in the Midwest through Tuesday night, with additional severe thunderstorms expected to develop on Wednesday across a 1,500-mile stretch from Texas to western New York. The possibility of damaging winds, hail, and a few tornadoes persisted, with the region bracing for further impact.\n\nThe recent onslaught of severe weather across the United States, including the devastating storm in Houston last Thursday, underscored the urgent need for preparedness and resilience in the face of unpredictable natural disasters, CNN reported. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number but thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents.\n\nDinkla said there were at least a dozen injuries amid widespread devastation in Greenfield, including at the community's small hospital. Patients there had to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nThe Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nAuthorities said they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning and ordered media {"uri": "8139631547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "04:38:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T04:38:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T04:36:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/international/2946085-iowa-multiple-fatalities-as-tornadoes-ravage-midwest-severe-storms-leave-trail-of-destruction", "title": "Iowa: Multiple fatalities as tornadoes ravage Midwest, severe storms leave trail of destruction | International", "body": "In the small city of Greenfield, Iowa, located approximately 50 miles southwest of Des Moines, a destructive storm unleashed a tornado shortly before 5 pm, causing extensive damage to numerous homes and structures, according to Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt Alex Dinkla.\n\nA series of devastating tornadoes wreaked havoc across western Iowa on Tuesday, resulting in multiple fatalities and widespread destruction in several communities, as severe storms continued to pummel the Midwest, CNN reported. In the small city of Greenfield, Iowa, located approximately 50 miles southwest of Des Moines, a destructive storm unleashed a tornado shortly before 5 pm, causing extensive damage to numerous homes and structures, according to Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt Alex Dinkla. \"Sadly, we can confirm that there have been fatalities with this tornado,\" Dinkla stated during a subsequent news conference, though he refrained from providing further details on the casualties.\n\nResidents in Greenfield were also left injured, and a local hospital suffered tornado damage, prompting the transfer of patients to nearby medical facilities, Sgt Dinkla confirmed, according to CNN. Footage captured by CNN affiliate KCCI depicted the trail of destruction left by the tornado in Greenfield, showcasing decimated homes, flattened structures, heaps of debris, damaged vehicles, and countless uprooted trees. \"There is basically nothing left,\" remarked Clel Baudler, a former Iowa state representative residing half a mile from Greenfield, emphasising the tornado's devastating impact.\n\nTragically, another storm-related fatality occurred in Adams County, Iowa, approximately 90 miles southwest of Des Moines, as confirmed by county medical examiner Lisa Brown. While Brown was unable to provide additional details on the incident, she attributed the death to a tornado. The potent line of thunderstorms that swept through the region on Tuesday prompted a rare \"potentially dangerous situation\" tornado watch for parts of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Illinois, according to the Storm Prediction Center. This special tornado watch is only issued when there is a high level of confidence in the potential for multiple long-lived and EF2 or stronger tornadoes.\n\nIn response to the storm outbreak, Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds authorized a proclamation of disaster emergency for 15 counties, enabling state resources to aid in response and recovery efforts. Governor Reynolds announced her intention to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning to assess the damage firsthand, vowing to provide the full support of the state. As of late Tuesday evening, over 30,000 customers were without power in Iowa, according to Poweroutage.us.\n\nThe severe thunderstorm outbreak on Tuesday also posed other serious hazards, including destructive hurricane-strength wind gusts of up to 90 mph and softball-size hail. More than 25 million people across the region were under a Level 3 of 5 or Level 4 of 5 risk of severe thunderstorms, according to the SPC. The largest area of concern for widespread, hazardous impacts centered on much of Iowa, northwest Illinois, southwest Wisconsin, and northern Missouri. Major population centers such as Chicago and Milwaukee were also at risk of damaging storms.\n\nThe Des Moines International Airport temporarily closed late Tuesday afternoon as dangerous storms approached the area, prompting tornado warnings. Emergency management officials in Montgomery County, Iowa, confirmed the occurrence of \"multiple tornadoes\" within the county, though no injuries were reported at the time. Damage assessments were underway, with officials working to clear roads for access to affected properties, as reported by CNN. In addition to tornadoes, flash flooding triggered by heavy rainfall posed a threat for parts of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Nebraska, where flood and tornado watches were in effect. Rainfall totals of 1 to 3 inches were possible, with some areas expecting up to 5 inches.\n\nSevere storms were forecasted to peak in the Midwest through Tuesday night, with additional severe thunderstorms expected to develop on Wednesday across a 1,500-mile stretch from Texas to western New York. The possibility of damaging winds, hail, and a few tornadoes persisted, with the region bracing for further impact. The recent onslaught of severe weather across the United States, including the devastating storm in Houston last Thursday, underscored the urgent need for preparedness and resilience in the face of unpredictable natural disasters, CNN reported. {"uri": "8140646058", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:37:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:37:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:36:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/nation-world/weather/iowa-tornadoes-severe-weather-storms/article_428fdef7-30a3-572d-8e05-45f9278ab2cd.html", "title": "Tornado kills multiple people in Iowa as powerful storms tear through Midwest", "body": "By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK, Associated Press By HANNAH FINGERHUT, SCOTT McFETRIDGE and MARGERY A. BECK, Associated Press\n\nGREENFIELD, Iowa -- An undisclosed number of people were killed when a tornado tore through a small town in Iowa after a massive tornado left a wide swath of obliterated homes and crumpled cars and also twisted and toppled wind turbines outside of the town.\n\nAfter devastating Greenfield, a town of 2,000, on Tuesday the storms moved eastward to pummel parts of Illinois and Wisconsin, knocking out power to tens of thousands of customers in the two states.\n\nGreenfield's hospital was among the buildings that were damaged in the town, which meant that at least a dozen people who were hurt had to be taken to facilities elsewhere, according to Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla.\n\n\"Sadly we can confirm that there have been fatalities,\" Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night, without specifying how many. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Horror film explores myths, legends of Napa's Partrick Road Napa Costco pre-construction underway; streets, model homes now open at RiverSound Oxbow School arts academy in Napa to close Rolling at Napa's last roller rink: The Wheelhouse made memories of disco, friends, fun in the 1970s and '80s Future of Napa's Monticello winery splits Corley siblings Eric Gallegos joins Yountville's Cliff Lede Vineyards John Legend, Jill Scott and Andr\u00e9 3000 to headline Black Radio Experience in Napa Napa County considers lodging project at old Capell Valley school Red Lobster abruptly closes dozens of restaurants across US. See the full list Accused drunken driver convicted of murder in fatal 2020 crash near Yountville Daughter of Hall of Fame baseball player, vineyard sued after Napa Valley crash Former Napa teacher accused of sexual assault tries to seal documents; reporter requests to intervene Two Napa Valley wine companies embroiled in lawsuit over $120,000 in grapes Biagi Bros. president keeps transportation company rolling BottleRock organizers break down closure, access details around Napa's new Festival La Onda\n\nHe said he thought they had accounted for all of the town's residents but that searches would continue if anyone was reported missing. The Adair County Health System said in a Facebook post Tuesday night that it had set up a triage center at the Greenfield high school and that people who need medical attention should go there.\n\nThe tornado destroyed much of Greenfield, which is located about 55 miles southwest of Des Moines, during a day that saw multiple tornadoes, giant hail and heavy rain in several states. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa, and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nIn Wisconsin, the weather service's Green Bay office dispatched a staffer Wednesday morning to survey storm damage near the village of Unity in western Marathon County after law enforcement received a report from the public about a tornado on the ground about 7:45 p.m. Tuesday in that community about 55 miles east of Eau Claire, meteorologist Roy Eckberg said. He said staffers would also be visiting Outagamie County near the city of Kaukauna, some 20 miles southwest of Green Bay, to investigate significant wind damage there.\n\nEckberg said high winds were reported Tuesday night across parts of central Wisconsin, with a wind gust of 70 mph in the city of Marshfield and with wind damage also reported to the northwest in the city of Wausau.\n\nWeather service staff will also be assessing storm damage Wednesday in southeastern Minnesota after radar indicated that a tornado touched down Tuesday night in Winona County, said Kate Abbott, a meteorologist with the agency's La Crosse, Wisconsin, office.\n\n\"With that one we did have a radar confirmed tornado, but we're going out and survey there to make sure the damage is consistent with a tornado,\" she said.\n\nAuthorities announced a mandatory curfew for Greenfield and said they would only allow residents to enter the town until Wednesday morning. They also ordered media representatives to leave the city Tuesday night.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, mounds of broken wood from homes, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Some trees still standing were stripped of their limbs and leaves. Residents helped each other salvage furniture and other belongings that were strewn in every direction.\n\nRogue Paxton said he sheltered in the basement of his home when the storm moved through. He told WOI-TV he thought the house was lost but said his family got lucky.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton said. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nA tornado also apparently took down several 250-foot wind turbines in southwest Iowa. Some of the turbines caught fire, sending plumes of smoke into the air. Wind farms are built to withstand tornadoes, hurricanes and other powerful winds.\n\nMary Long, the owner of Long's Market in downtown Greenfield, said she rode out the storm at her business in the community's historic town square, which largely escaped damage. Long said there appeared to be widespread damage on the east and south sides of town.\n\n\"I could hear this roaring, like the proverbial freight train, and then it was just done,\" she said.\n\nCamille Blair said the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce office where she works closed around 2 p.m. ahead of the storm.\n\n\"I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road,\" she said of the tornado.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said she planned to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" she said in a statement. \"Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\"\n\nIowa had braced for severe weather after the weather service's Storm Prediction Center gave most of the state a high chance of seeing severe thunderstorms with the potential for strong tornadoes. The storms and tornado warnings moved into Wisconsin on Tuesday evening and night.\n\nEarlier in the day, residents to the west in Omaha, Nebraska, awoke to sirens blaring and widespread power outages as torrential rain, high winds and large hail pummeled the area. The deluge flooded basements and submerged cars. Television station KETV showed firefighters rescuing people from vehicles.\n\nIn Illinois, dust storms led authorities to shut down stretches of two interstates due to low visibility.\n\nThe storms followed days of extreme weather that have ravaged much of the middle section of the country. Strong winds, large hail and tornadoes swept parts of Oklahoma and Kansas late Sunday, damaging homes and injuring two in Oklahoma.\n\nAnother round of storms Monday night raked Colorado and western Nebraska and saw the city of Yuma, Colorado, blanketed in hail the size of baseballs and golf balls, turning streets into rivers of water and ice.\n\nIn Texas, deadly storms hit the Houston area last week, killing at least eight people. Those storms last Thursday knocked out power to hundreds of thousands for days, leaving many in the dark and without air conditioning during hot and humid weather. Hurricane-force winds reduced businesses and other structures to debris and shattered glass in downtown skyscrapers.\n\nBob Oravec, lead forecaster with the weather service, said the system is expected to turn south Wednesday, bringing more severe weather to parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri.\n\nPhotos: Tornado devastates Greenfield as powerful storms sweep through Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa Severe Weather Iowa\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press.
