Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said law enforcement were still determining the total number of confirmed dead residents.\n\nDinkla stated that there were at least a dozen injuries in Greenfield, including at a small hospital. Patients at the hospital were forced to be transferred to other facilities in nearby cities.\n\nAdditionally, at least 18 tornadoes were reported in Iowa on Tuesday as other states in the Midwest saw hail and heavy rain.\n\nIn a Meta (Facebook) post on Tuesday night, the Adair County Health System announced that it had set up a triage center at Greenfield high school to be utilized as a sort of sanctuary for those who need medical care and other assistance.\n\nMeanwhile, law enforcement officials reported that they would only allow residents to enter Greenfield until Wednesday morning. Non-local media representatives were told to leave the city on Tuesday night.\n\nValerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, told reporters that she \"asked God to protect her home and her family\" during the devastation, according to station KCCI.\n\n\"I was in the furnace room and then I heard (the storm) like a train,\" she said. \"I heard it, and I knew it was hitting.\"\n\nWarrior said the damage was tragic to see, but she is still optimistic that the city will eventually bounce back and heal from this.\n\n\"They'll get through it. You already see people out helping each other, working together. And that's what they do, people come together when a tragedy happens. People come together to support and encourage each other.\"\n\n\"We'll rebuild,\" Warrior added. \"We'll rebuild.\"\n\nTornado reports have increased over the well-above average in recent weeks. There have been over 800 tornadoes reported so far this year, which makes it one of the most active years for twisters on record.\n\nOver 90,000 homes and businesses are without power across Iowa, Illinois, and Wisconsin as of Wednesday morning, according to PowerOutage.us. More outages are anticipated as storms roll through the East.\n\nCities like Nashville and Memphis in Tennessee, St. Louis in Missouri, Cleveland and Columbus in Ohio, and Tulsa in Oklahoma \"should be on storm watch,\" according to weather experts who spoke with the press.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds (R-Iowa) issued a disaster emergency proclamation on Tuesday for 15 counties in the Hawkeye State.\n\nStay informed! {"uri": "8140492542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "13:59:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T13:59:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:58:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/05/22/tornado-destroys-town-iowa/", "title": "Multiple People Killed, Dozens Injured After Tornado Destroys Small Town In Iowa", "body": "A tornado in Iowa destroyed homes and businesses in a small town, killing multiple people and injuring dozens, The Associated Press (AP) reported Wednesday.\n\nThe tornado, along with hail and heavy rain, felled trees, smashed cars and threw debris across much of Greenfield, a town of 2,000 southwest of Des Moines, according to The AP.\n\n\"Sadly, we can confirm that there have been fatalities with this tornado,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex. Dinkla said Tuesday night during a news conference. \"Also, injuries have been sustained by residents here in the Greenfield area.\" (RELATED: Another Day Of Tornadoes Hitting Multiple States)\n\nDinkla added in the press conference that authorities were still working on confirming the number of dead but said all the town's residents were likely accounted for.\n\nThe Adair County Health System announced on Facebook Tuesday night that a triage center had been set up at Greenfield High School for people needing medical attention.\n\nAuthorities ordered media out of the town Tuesday night and said only Greenfield residents would be allowed in until Wednesday morning, The AP reported.\n\nThe tornado left the town strewn with bent, leafless trees, broken wood, car parts and piles of debris where houses were destroyed, according to The AP.\n\nLocal resident Rogue Paxton said that he headed to the basement when the storm hit and that his house luckily was not ruined, The AP reported.\n\n\"But everyone else is not so much, like my brother Cody, his house just got wiped,\" Paxton told WOI-TV. \"Then you see all these people out here helping each other. ... Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nAnother local resident, Camille Blair, said, \"There's a pretty significant roof damage to several houses that I know will need whole new roofs,\" she said. \"And I can see from my house it kind of went in a straight line down the road.\"\n\nDeadly storms also hit Texas last week, killing at least eight people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power for days, The AP Local hospitals were damaged, forcing patient transfers. Governor Kim Reynolds declared a disaster emergency across 15 counties to facilitate state assistance.\n\nA powerful tornado ripped through a small Iowa town on Tuesday, killing multiple people and leaving at least a dozen injured, authorities said. Images from the town of Greenfield show a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled.\n\n\"This tornado has devastated a good portion of this town,\" said Sgt. Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, during an evening press conference in Greenfield. \"We can confirm there have been multiple fatalities with this tornado.\"\n\nDinkla did not provide a death toll, but said it may not be before Wednesday that figures could be provided. At least a dozen people in Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 people, were injured in the twister, Dinkla said. Because the local hospital sustained damage in the storm, those people had to be transferred to facilities in nearby towns.\n\n\"I've lived here all my life. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, told CBS affiliate KCCI TV in an interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\" Other video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nAt least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details. Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAlso in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. It said several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County. The National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin.\n\nEarlier in the day, the weather service confirmed at least one tornado over Rollingstone, Minnesota.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a {"uri": "8140728286", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:33:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:33:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:33:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1324253", "title": "20 tornadoes in 3 states wreak havoc, kill multiple people in Iowa", "body": "(NEW YORK) -- For the fourth straight day, residents of the Midwest and the Great Plains were bracing for dangerous tornado weather, a day after at least 20 twisters tore through three states, killing multiple people in Iowa, officials said.\n\nAs severe weather is forecast to move into the south and east and stretch from New York state to Texas on Wednesday, the town of Greenfield, Iowa, was left ripped to shreds with about half the town destroyed, officials said.\n\nA \"devastating\" tornado hit Greenfield, southwest of Des Moines, causing fatalities and injuries in the area, Sgt. Alex Dinkla of the Iowa State Patrol said at a news conference Tuesday night.\n\n\"It's just gut-wrenching. It's horrific. It's hard to describe until you can actually see it, the devastation,\" Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds said at a news conference in Greenfield Wednesday morning.\n\nReynolds said search-and-rescue crews are continuing to look for victims.\n\nThe number of people killed and injured and the amount of damage were still being tallied Wednesday morning.\n\n\"This is a search-and-rescue mission and it will continue to be throughout the day,\" said Reynolds, adding that officials don't want to give out any misinformation.\n\nShe said, however, that much of the town of Greenfield was flattened.\n\nAsked if dozens of homes were damaged in Greenfield and throughout the state, Reynolds said, \"That would be way underestimating.\"\n\nThe Adair County Memorial Hospital, which serves Greenfield, sustained tornado damage, Dinkla said, but still managed to treat patients and transport some to nearby hospitals for further care.\n\nState Rep. Ray Sorensen, who represents Greenfield, said he was painting at a church when the tornado struck around 3 p.m. Tuesday and rushed into town to find numerous homes damaged or completely demolished and nearly all the historic trees in Greenfield uprooted and stripped of limbs.\n\n\"It's a completely different town now,\" Sorensen said.\n\nBut he said that when he arrived at the scene of the devastation, people were already clearing the streets of debris to make way for emergency vehicles and helping those injured get medical attention at a makeshift triage center established at a lumber yard.\n\n\"Everybody became little makeshift ambulances,\" Sorensen said. \"We pulled a guy from the rubble and put him on a little makeshift stretcher that we made, threw him in the back of a truck of a guy that isn't even from Iowa and we just made our way to the lumber yard, which was the makeshift hospital.\"\n\nAt least 329 severe storms were reported Tuesday through the nation's midsection from Texas to Michigan, even up in New England. At least 20 tornadoes were confirmed in three states, including Iowa, Wisconsin and Minnesota. Most of the twisters swept across Iowa.\n\nMore severe weather is on the way. The highest threat for tornadoes, damaging winds and large hail will be in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana, including major cities such as Dallas, Waco, Abilene, Little Rock and Shreveport.\n\nSome damaging winds could also develop in Memphis and Nashville, Louisville, Cincinnati, Pittsburgh, Buffalo and Rochester, New York.\n\nSevere weather is also expected to stretch into Thursday as the Memorial Day weekend gets underway. Dangerous weather is expected on Thursday through large parts of the Heartland and parts of the South from South Dakota to Texas and east to Tennessee.\n\nOn Tuesday, the National Weather Service issued tornado watches for parts of Nebraska, Iowa, South Dakota, Missouri, Arkansas, Wisconsin, Illinois, Minnesota, Kansas and Oklahoma.\n\nNearly the entire state of Iowa was under a \"Particularly Dangerous Situation,\" according to the National Weather Service, which issued several tornado warnings before the town of Greenfield was slammed by a funnel cloud.\n\nGov. Reynolds authorized a proclamation of disaster emergency for 15 counties across the state. On Wednesday, she said the state will ask President Joe Biden to approve federal disaster relief.\n\nThe counties include Adair, Adams, Cass, Clay, Hardin, Harrison, Jasper, Kossuth, Marshall, Montgomery, Page, Palo Alto, Pottawattamie, Tama and Warren.\n\nGov. Reynolds authorized a proclamation of disaster emergency for 15 counties across the state. On Wednesday, she said the state will ask President Joe Biden to approve federal disaster relief.\n\nSeveral videos obtained by ABC affiliate station WOI-DT in Des Moines captured a large funnel cloud on the ground in Greenfield.\n\nOn Tuesday, WOI reporter Dana Searles, surveying the damage in Des Moines, said, \"This small community has a big chunk destroyed, but about half of it is still intact. From what I've seen, I'd estimate that maybe 75% of it is near to the ground right now.\"\n\nIn Yuma, in northeast Colorado, hail ranging from golf ball to softball size pummeled the area, causing damage to cars and buildings. At one point, the hail was so deep it caused multiple vehicles to get stuck, JJ Unger, a volunteer Yuma firefighter, told ABC News Tuesday.\n\n\"It was like a blizzard hitting for a half hour because of the hail,\" Unger said. \"That's the longest I've seen it hail like that.\"\n\nUnger said he and his fire crew were out spotting for possible tornadoes Monday evening when lightning struck.\n\n\"It was very intense,\" said Unger, adding that he and his crew had to pull over and seek shelter as visibility went to almost zero.\n\nUnger said that when the hail finally let up, a foot of hail was covering his fire engine and roads in the area.\n\nHe said the windshields of his pickup truck and his wife's vehicle were shattered.\n\n\"Almost every home in town has broken windows and I've heard that over a thousand cars were damaged,\" Unger said.\n\nIn Nebraska, hail measuring two inches in diameter fell in Dundy County in the southwest corner of the state, according to local emergency management officials. Winds of over 90 mph were also reported.\n\nMore than half a foot of rain was recorded in Omaha, Nebraska, on Tuesday, producing major flash flooding in the area.", "source": {"uri": "ktbb.com", {"uri": "8139519477", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "02:40:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T02:40:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:40:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://torontosun.com/news/world/multiple-deaths-confirmed-from-tornado-in-iowa-state-patrol-says", "title": "Multiple deaths confirmed from tornado in Iowa, state patrol says", "body": "\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference Tuesday night. He said authorities were still determining the total number.\n\nPowerful storms that rolled through the U.S. Midwest spun up multiple tornadoes, including a fierce twister that smashed through the small Iowa town of Greenfield, with a population of about 2,000 around 88.5 km southwest of Des Moines. The twister carved a bleak landscape of destroyed homes and businesses, shredded trees, smashed cars and widely strewn debris.\n\nIn the aftermath of the storm, parts of Greenfield appeared devastated. Mounds of broken wood, branches, car parts and other debris littered lots where homes once stood. Cars lay busted and bent while damaged houses sat skewed against the grey and overcast sky. Trees stood -- barely -- bereft of branches or leaves. While many areas suffered storm damage, no community was hit harder than the southwest Iowa town of Greenfield.\n\nThe fast-moving tornado tore through the small Iowa town on Tuesday, leaving a path of destruction behind it. Drone footage shows the clear path of the tornado as it made its way through the Adair County town yesterday.\n\nAt a press conference on Tuesday evening, the Iowa State Patrol confirmed the worst possible news. There were multiple casualties in Greenfield, according to KCCI. The State Patrol says that an official number won't be released until later today. While search efforts continue, officials believe everyone in the town of about 2,000 people is accounted for.\n\nKCCI reports that a mandatory curfew is in effect and likely will be for several more days. The State Patrol also says that no one will be allowed into the city unless they have a Greenfield address on their ID. A reunification point has been set up for survivors and is located at Nodoway Valley High School. It is also serving as a temporary shelter for Greenfield residents.\n\nCompounding issues is that the Adair County Health System hospital in Greenfield suffered damage in the storm. {"uri": "8140732516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:36:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:36:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:36:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.nydailynews.com/2024/05/22/tornado-greenfield-iowa-multiple-killed/", "title": "Tornado rips through Greenfield, Iowa, killing several people", "body": "Multiple people were killed when a tornado rampaged through an Iowa town Tuesday, authorities said.\n\n\"There have been fatalities,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla said Tuesday night at a press conference. \"We're still counting at this time.\"\n\nThe twister rolled through Greenfield, Iowa, about 45 miles southwest of Des Moines, around 3:30 p.m. Drone video captured by storm chaser Aaron Payzant showed the storm's path of destruction through the 2,000-person town.\n\nHouses were smashed to pieces, debris covered roadways and several trees were uprooted by the tornado. The storm's neat, direct path left some houses still standing next to others that were now piles of rubble.\n\n\"You see all these people out here helping each other,\" Greenfield resident Rogue Paxton told local ABC affiliate WOI. \"Everything's going to be fine because we have each other, but it's just going to be really, really rough. It is a mess.\"\n\nThe storm damaged Greenfield's local hospital, which was evacuated, according to the Des Moines Register. Wounded residents, who numbered at least a dozen, were transported out of town to other hospitals, Dinkla said.\n\nAuthorities enforced a 10 p.m. to 7 a.m. curfew to keep the streets clear as emergency responders worked to clear debris. Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds visited the town Wednesday morning.\n\nThe storm system that crushed Greenfield spawned an estimated 21 tornadoes across Iowa on Tuesday, one in Minnesota and one in Wisconsin, according to the National Weather Service. One of the Iowa twisters damaged a wind farm in the southwest part of the state.\n\nIllinois and Wisconsin bore the brunt of the system early Wednesday, as thunderstorms knocked out power for 36,000 {"uri": "2024-05-364327001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "08:52:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T08:52:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T07:08:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.aol.com/tornado-spawning-storms-left-multiple-054429042.html", "title": "Tornado-spawning storms left multiple people dead in Iowa and are now threatening cities from Texas to Vermont", "body": "Tornado-spawning storms left multiple people dead in Iowa and are now threatening cities from Texas to VermontElizabeth Wolfe, Robert Shackelford and Joe Sutton, CNNMay 22, 2024 at 9:08 AM\n\nSome Iowa communities will be waking up Wednesday to sift through the rubble of now-unrecognizable homes and mourn the deaths of neighbors who were killed by a series of tornado-spawning storms that tore through the Midwest yesterday and are now setting their sights on a much broader swath of the US.\n\nMultiple fatalities and some injuries have been reported in the small city of Greenfield, Iowa - about 50 miles southwest of Des Moines - after a tornado carved a devastating path through the community Tuesday evening, Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt. Alex Dinkla told CNN. Dinkla did not elaborate on the number or nature of the deaths.\n\n\"There is basically nothing left,\" Clel Baudler, a former Iowa state representative who lives a half mile from Greenfield, told CNN on Tuesday. Video taken by CNN affiliate KCCI shows homes and other structures have been obliterated and the community is blanketed with heaps of debris, tossed cars and uprooted trees.\n\nAt least 17 tornado reports were generated in Iowa Tuesday - part of a parade of storms that has been marching across the US this week, leaving widespread power outages, structural damage and some flooding in their wake.\n\nPower outages across Iowa, Wisconsin and Illinois left nearly 200,000 homes and businesses in the dark as of Tuesday night, according to PowerOutage.us. Even more outages are anticipated as Wednesday's storms roll through the East.\n\nOn Wednesday, the severe thunderstorm threat weakens slightly but is expected to unleash harsh winds, hail and some tornadoes along a sprawling 1,500-mile expanse from Texas to western Vermont.\n\n\"Severe thunderstorms posing a risk for damaging gusts and hail will be possible from central Texas into the Ohio Valley and lower Great Lakes area on Wednesday. The greatest threat of damaging hail and wind is forecast from north Texas across the Ozarks,\" the Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nA few tornadoes could strike from Texas to Arkansas, but hail and powerful winds are possible anywhere along the storms' path.\n\nThe strongest impacts will be felt from central Texas to southeast Oklahoma and central Arkansas, including in Dallas, Fort Worth and Little Rock. Hail larger than 2 inches in diameter, wind gusts up to 74 mph and some tornadoes could hit.\n\nThough under a less severe risk Wednesday, cities including Nashville, St. Louis, Memphis, Cleveland, Tulsa and Columbus should also be storm-aware.\n\nSome Iowa neighborhoods left in ruins\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds issued a disaster emergency proclamation Tuesday for 15 counties as a potent line of thunderstorms prompted rare, escalated levels of tornado watches across parts of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Illinois.\n\nWestern Iowa bore the brunt of the storms' catastrophic impacts. Violent winds and possible tornadoes flattened buildings in Greenfield, toppled a hulking wind turbine in Prescott and reduced several people's homes to mountains of jagged debris.\n\nIn addition to the fatalities reported in Greenfield, at least one other person was killed as storms passed through nearby Adams County, local officials said.\n\nMore than two dozen homes were damaged or destroyed in Montgomery County, including some \"critical public facilities,\" emergency management officials said. No injuries have been reported but damage assessments are still ongoing.\n\nValerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, pleaded with God to protect her home and her family before she rode out the storm in her basement, she told CNN affiliate KCCI.\n\n\"I was in the furnace room and then I heard (the storm) like a train,\" she said, describing insulation flying off of basement windows. \"I heard it and I knew it was hitting.\"\n\nWarrior said the scale of damage is \"devastating\" to see, but she is confident residents will pull each other through the crisis.\n\n\"They'll get through it. You already see people out helping each other, working together. And that's what they do, people come together when a tragedy happens. People come together to support and encourage each other.\"\n\nFighting back tears, Warrior looked out across a rubble-strewn lawn and tried to crack a smile.\n\n\"We'll rebuild, we'll rebuild.\"\n\nCNN's Jessica Jordan, Sara Smart and Amy Simonson contributed to this report.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": Homes crumbled, others were lifted from their foundations, cars were flipped and trees were shredded. The storms come just weeks after tornadoes tore through numerous other Iowa communities.\n\n\"It's hard to believe that it's happened again,\" said Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds (R) in a statement. She plans to visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning to assess the damage.\n\n\"Sadly, we can confirm there were fatalities and injuries within the community of Greenfield from this tornado,\" state police said in a statement Tuesday evening. There was no further information about the number of fatalities.\n\nIn addition to Greenfield, Tuesday's twisters also struck near the towns of Red Oak, Villisca, Brooks, Carbon and Corning. At least 20 tornadoes were reported Tuesday, largely in southwest Iowa. More may be confirmed across Minnesota and Wisconsin in the days ahead.\n\nOne woman died after being ejected from a vehicle during the storm near Corning in Adams County, about 70 miles southwest of Des Moines, according to Lisa Brown, the county medical examiner. Storm-chaser video from the area showed wind turbines flattened as the twisters swept by.\n\nDrone footage captured by storm chaser Reed Timmer from the tornado in Greenfield, about 50 miles from Des Moines, showed a violently spinning, massive funnel with smaller vortexes embedded within the primary twister's circulation. The Weather Service issued a warning for the twister 46 minutes before it touched down, giving residents time to shelter.\n\nAfter wreaking havoc in southwest Iowa, the storms raced through the state's central and eastern regions, northern Missouri, southern Minnesota and western and central Wisconsin, prompting dozens of severe thunderstorm and tornado warnings.\n\nTornado watches stretched A tornado \"devastated a good portion of this town and community,\" Sgt. Alex Dinkla of the Iowa State Patrol said Tuesday evening. More than one person in the city was killed in the storm, but the total number of deaths was unclear at midday Wednesday.\n\nDamaging winds and heavy rains affected other areas across the state, and multiple tornadoes were reported in southwest Iowa, as well as several north of Des Moines. {"uri": "8139527580", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:08:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:08:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:50:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/fatal-storms-pummel-iowa-reducing-023854622.html", "title": "Iowa tornado kills 'multiple' people in small town reduced to rubble", "body": "(Reuters) -A powerful tornado ripped through a small Iowa town on Tuesday, killing multiple people and leaving at least a dozen injured, authorities said.\n\nImages from the town of Greenfield show a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled.\n\n\"This tornado has devastated a good portion of this town,\" said Sgt. Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, during an evening press conference in Greenfield.\n\n\"We can confirm there have been multiple fatalities with this tornado.\"\n\nDinkla did not provide a death toll, but said it may not be before Wednesday that figures could be provided.\n\nAt least a dozen people in Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 people, were injured in the twister, Dinkla said. Because the local hospital sustained damage in the storm, those people had to be transferred to facilities in nearby towns.\n\n\"I've lived here all my life. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, told CBS affiliate KCCI TV in an interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nOther video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nAt least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAlso in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. It said several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin.\n\nEarlier in the day, the weather service confirmed at least one tornado over Rollingstone, Minnesota.\n\n(Reporting by Brad {"uri": "2024-05-364694149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:00:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:00:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:40:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://eu.fdlreporter.com/story/weather/2024/05/21/iowa-national-weather-service-severe-weather-outlook-des-moines-readar/73783200007/", "title": "Updates: Tornado, storm damage still being felt in Iowa as clean up begins", "body": "A tornado warning was issued for most of Iowa as powerful storms rolled through the area bringing strong winds and heavy rains.\n\nMultiple rounds of storms spread across Iowa on Tuesday, bringing repeated severe weather warnings to the Hawkeye State.\n\nA round of rain passed through central Iowa early on Tuesday morning and by mid-morning one round of severe thunderstorms passed through. Another round of storms, with multiple tornado warnings across the state appeared in the afternoon. By early evening, Iowans in western and central Iowa communities were trying to clean up and assess the damage.\n\nHere are the latest updates:\n\n8:36 a.m.: Two Des Moines schools cancel classes due to power outages\n\nStudents at Samuelson Elementary School in Des Moines won't have classes on Wednesday due to a power outage at the school, said district spokesperson Phil Roeder.\n\nWoodlawn Education Center also canceled its morning preschool session due to a power outage. The district has not made a decision about afternoon preschool yet.\n\n8:34 a.m.: Greenfield, Iowa tornado spares Warren Opera House\n\nSgt. Alex Dinkla, spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, said the tornado appeared to move through the southwest side of Greenfield. The historic town square, with the Warren Opera House and courthouse, appears to have been spared, he said.\n\n8:25 a.m.: Gov. Kim Reynolds begins tour of Greenfield, Iowa tornado damage\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds is in southwest Iowa touring damage from a tornado in Greenfield.\n\nShe said in a release Tuesday night, that she is \"committed to providing the full resources of the state to support the response and recovery effort.\"\n\nA media briefing is expected later Wednesday morning.\n\n8:20 a.m.: How much rain fell during severe storms in Iowa?\n\nMany Iowa communities experienced heavy rainfall on Tuesday, soaking already wet ground.\n\nDecorah, in northeast Iowa, recorded the most rain with 3.72 inches.\n\nIn central Iowa, Des Moines reported 1.52 inches and Ames reported 2.65 inches.\n\n7:15 a.m.: Iowa tornado map: where NWS survey teams are headed Wednesday\n\nThe National Weather Service in Des Moines said it would be sending three survey crews out into Iowa on Wednesday to search for tornado damage.\n\nThe first team will be searching in central Iowa, including in areas around Ankeny, Huxley and Nevada. One team will be focused just on the Greenfield area, where fatalities and large destruction have been confirmed, and a third team will head toward southwest Iowa around Clarinda, Creston and Corning.\n\nOmaha's NWS office, which covers western Iowa, will also have teams in the state. They'll be searching in far southwest Iowa in areas like Red Oak.\n\nOfficial confirmation of tornadoes and ratings for them may take several days.\n\n7:05 a.m.: Flood warnings in effect for multiple Iowa rivers following storms, heavy rain\n\nThe National Weather Service has issued multiple flood warnings across Iowa as rivers and creeks swell from recent rainfall.\n\nIn the Des Moines area, the Raccoon and Des Moines rivers are expected to flood.\n\nAs of 7 a.m., the Raccon River at Fleur Drive was at 13.1 feet, or 1.1 feet above its banks. It's expected to crest early Thursday morning at 14.7 feet and fall back below its banks by Saturday. Water could reach low areas of Water Works Park and George Flagg Parkway.\n\nThe Des Moines River at SE Sixth Street was at 24.05 feet as of 7 a.m. Monday, that's just barely over flood stage. It's expected to reach 25.8 feet early Thursday morning and remain out of its banks until Saturday. At 25.7 feet, water will reach the base of the Simon Estes Amphitheater.\n\nThe Iowa River at Marengo and the North Skunk River at Sigourney could reach moderate flood stages.\n\n6:45 a.m.: Traffic light damaged at major Grimes intersection on Iowa Highway 141\n\nTravelers should consider avoiding traveling on Iowa Highway 141 through Grimes on Wednesday, the Polk County Sheriff's Office said.\n\nThe traffic signals at SE Grimes Boulevard (Highway 141) and SE 37th Street sustained damaged during Tuesday's storms and are not working. Repairs are expected to be completed sometime on Wednesday.\n\nThe sheriff's office will have deputies at the intersection to help manage the flow of traffic during the morning commute, but delays are expected.\n\n6:40 a.m.: Power restored for many, but 10,000 power outages remain\n\nAt one point Tuesday night, more than 50,000 customers were without power in Iowa following rounds of severe thunderstorms and tornadoes.\n\nAs of Wednesday morning, MidAmerican Energy is reporting about 6,000 power outages, including 4,000 in the Des Moines and about 1,800 in Waterloo.\n\nMidAmerican said late Tuesday that it had nearly 70 crews working in the Des Moines area. Most remaining outages are expected to be restored on Wednesday, but isolated areas could take until Thursday.\n\nAlliant Energy reports about 2,000 power outages, down from nearly 17,000 on Tuesday night. The Iowa Association of Electric Cooperatives reported over 4,300 customers were without power, down from more than 7,000.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds to visit hard-hit Greenfield Wednesday\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds plans to visit Greenfield Wednesday morning, where multiple deaths and injuries were reported after a tornado ripped through the small city.\n\nIn a statement issued about 9 p.m. Tuesday, she said she and her husband, Kevin, were praying for \"all the communities and families impacted by today's severe weather, and especially those who tragically lost their lives in the Greenfield area. I am committed to providing the full resources of the state to support the response and recovery effort.\"\n\nThe statement went on to say: \"State and local officials are on the ground, assessing the situation and setting up temporary shelters for those whose homes were damaged or destroyed. First responders and health care providers are onsite caring for the injured. Utility crews are working to restore service to thousands without power, and the State Emergency Operations Center continues to coordinate missions to support local responders. While it's too soon to know the storm's full impact, answers will come in the hours and days ahead.\n\n\"It was just a few weeks ago that tornadoes hit several other Iowa communities, and it's hard to believe that it's happened again. Iowans are strong and resilient, and we will get through this together.\n\n\"I plan to visit Greenfield in the morning to assess the damage with local officials and start the recovery process.\"\n\nMidAmerican confirms wind turbines knocked over by Iowa tornadoes\n\nMidAmerican Energy's Geoff Greenwood said Tuesday the Des Moines utility was aware of several wind turbines in Adair County \"which took a direct hit by a large tornado\" and were damaged or destroyed. He said the company was continuing to assess losses in storm-damaged areas.\n\nA social media video, described as being taken near Greenfield, shows a tornado shredding one turbine after another. Another video shows crumpled turbines on fire near Prescott in Adams County, southwest of Adair County.\n\nGreenwood says it's hard to know exactly where the Adair County video was taken to determine if the turbines are MidAmerican. And it's not aware of significant damage to its wind turbines in Adams County.\n\nNevada woman searches for doll collection ripped from home\n\nA little over an hour had passed since a tornado hit June and Larry Handsacker's house off of 650th Avenue near Nevada, and their family was already on the scene, pulling valued possessions from the wreckage.\n\nWhich, in June Handsacker's case, are her dolls.\n\n\"All my dolls!\" she said, pointing to a nearly intact china cabinet just inches from where the tornado cleaved her home in half. \"And those were just the dolls I bought, not the ones I made.\"\n\nShe was in the dining room when the tornado passed through her home. She had left her husband in the basement for a moment to grab her phone when insulation came crashing down around her. They had to crawl over the debris to get out.\n\n\"I have over 100 porcelain dolls -- ceramic pieces I made,\" Handsacker said. \"We don't know where they are yet. It'll be a matter of getting in there.\"\n\nHer own grandparents lost their home in the five-tornado spree that touched down in Charles City in 1968, and her grandfather was trapped for three days in his car.\n\nShe said she and her husband know they're lucky they came away unscathed; they believe that God was looking out for them.\n\n\"It pays to teach Sunday school!,\" she said. \"Do you know how horrible those kids behave?\"\n\nReynolds issues emergency declaration for 15 counties after Iowa tornadoes\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds authorized a disaster emergency proclamation for 15 counties: Adair, Adams, Cass, Clay, Hardin, Harrison, Jasper, Kossuth, Marshall, Montgomery, Page, Palo Alto, Pottawattamie, Tama and Warren.\n\nWith the proclamation, the Iowa Individual Assistance Grant Program provides grants of up to $5,000 for households with incomes up to 200 percent of the federal poverty level. Grants are available for home or car repairs, replacement of clothing or food, and temporary housing expenses.\n\nThe Disaster Case Advocacy Program addresses serious needs related to disaster-related hardship, injury, or adverse conditions. There are no income eligibility requirements for this program; it closes 180 days from the date of the governor's proclamation.\n\n6:45 p.m.: Johnston High School cancels classes Wednesday after storm causes 'extensive' damage\n\nThere's no school at Johnston High School on Wednesday after Tuesday afternoon's storms caused \"extensive\" damage to the building, the Johnston Community School District announced on social media.\n\nThe senior awards ceremony that had been scheduled for Tuesday night was postponed due to the damage and staff were told not to come to the building on Wednesday for their safety.\n\nDistrict spokesperson Lynn Meadows told the Des Moines Register that the whole of the building has been affected, with glass shattered throughout the high school, damage to the roof, a shed that's been ripped apart and an overhead door that's been torn off.\n\nMeadows said Tuesday evening there's not yet been a decision made about classes at the high school for the rest of the week after Wednesday. Thursday was to be the last day of school for seniors.\n\nShe said the graduation ceremony scheduled for next week at the Knapp Center would not be affected.\n\n6:40 p.m.: No injuries reported after possible tornado in Red Oak, Iowa, but street department building destroyed\n\nRed Oak Mayor Shawnna Silvius, in a Facebook posting, said there were no reported injuries in an apparent tornado touchdown there, after a search and rescue operation.\n\nThe city street department's building \"is likely a loss\" and there were multiple downed powerlines. She said city street and wastewater employees who were present when the tornado touched down \"are shook up but all are safe.\"\n\n6:35 p.m.: Tornado warning issued for Vinton area in northeast area\n\nA tornado warning was issued for Independence, Vinton and Winthrop in northeast Iowa. The warning says it was issued for a radar-indicated tornado and the threat of quarter-sized hail. The warning expires at 7 p.m.\n\n6:30 p.m.: Where did tornadoes touchdowns reported in Iowa?\n\nNo tornadoes will officially be confirmed until the National Weather Service is able to send survey crews out into Iowa.\n\nUnofficial reports from trained weather spotters throughout Tuesday included: A cluster of sightings in southwest Iowa in Cromwell, Prescott, Corning, Carbon, Red Oak and Villisca. Greenfield in southwest Iowa also appeared to be particularly hard hit. In central Iowa there were unconfirmed reports in Nevada, rural Story County and southeast of Polk City.\n\n6:10 p.m.: Storm, tornado damage reports coming in to National Weather Service\n\nReports were pouring in from National Weather Service volunteer weather spotters around Iowa. Among the reports:\n\n6:05 p.m.: Story County asks people to stay away from tornado damage\n\nTornado damage was reported in rural parts of Story County, Melissa Spencer, the county's emergency management coordinator told the Ames Tribune.\n\nDamage was reported near Cambridge and on the south side of Nevada, Spencer said.\"We need people to stay away from the damaged areas,\" she said. \"We're getting a lot of people that are coming to look and see what happened.\"\n\n6 p.m.: Traffic limited in Greenfield after tornado hits, damages hospital\n\nFormer state Rep. Clel Baudler said the fast-moving tornado hit shortly after he arrived back home late Tuesday afternoon from a trip to Texas, caused extensive damage and injuries in Greenfield, and caused authorities to limit traffic in and out of the Adair County town of more than 2,000.\n\n\"Ambulances are running north and south like crazy,\" said Baudler, who left the Legislature in 2018. \"It's all rescue and recovery right now.\"\n\nMore details: Extensive damage in Greenfield, hit by tornado during string of dangerous storms in Iowa\n\nBaudler, a retired state trooper who lives on Highway 25 about a half mile north of Greenfield, said his mile-long farm wasn't damaged but there was debris from the tornado in a neighbor's yard. He was still without power at about 5:20 p.m.\n\nHe said the tornado ran \"cattywampus\" through town, exiting on the northeast side. He said he'd heard it damaged the Adair County Hospital at 609 SE Kent St. and the Greenfield Rehabilitation and Health Care Center at 615 SE Kent.\n\nA woman who answered the phone at the health care center confirmed it was hit, but said officials couldn't talk as it was an emergency.\n\nA MercyOne spokesperson previously confirmed to the Register that the hospital was damaged. The spokesperson told the Register shortly before 6 p.m. that the hospital had been evacuated. Further details were not immediately available.\n\nThe Adair County Sheriff also did not immediately return a phone call seeking comment.\n\n6:00 p.m.: Delays reported at Des Moines airport passengers had to shelter\n\nDes Moines International Airport spokesperson Kayla Kovarna said the airport halted flights as soon as a severe thunderstorm warning was issued for the area, and passengers and staff were escorted to storm-safe parts of the terminal.\n\nShe said Transportation Security Administration screening stations were in the process of reopening around 5:45 p.m. and that flights would resume shortly. She said some incoming flights were rerouted to other airports during the closure, but she didn't know how many had been affected.\n\n5:55 p.m.: Overturned semis cause backup on Interstate 35 near Elkhart\n\nTraffic is backed up for at least a mile on southbound Interstate 35 near Elkhart, Iowa.\n\nA Register reporter observed at least four overturned semitrailers on the side of the interstate. Emergency crews were on scene.\n\n5:06 p.m.: Tornado warning issued near I-80 for Newton\n\nA tornado warning has been issued in Newton, Colfax and Baxter until 5:30 p.m. Threats include a radar indicated tornado and possible pea sized hail.\n\n4:57 pm.: 'Damaging tornado' reported near Nevada\n\nA tornado warning has been issued for Nevada, Huxley and State Center until 5:30 p.m. Threats include a damaging tornado and possible quarter-sized hail.\n\n4:50 p.m.: Tornado warning issued for Iowa Falls area\n\nA tornado warning was issued for Iowa Falls, Alden and Radcliffe until 5:30 p.m. Threats include a radar indicated tornado and possible quarter sized hail.\n\n4:45 p.m.: Des Moines tornado warnings include 'observed tornadoes'\n\nA tornado warning has been issued to include Des Moines, Altoona and Norwalk until 5:15 p.m. Threats include a radar-indicated tornado and half dollar sized hail.\n\nIn an update at 4:45 p.m., the NWS said bot warnings in the Des Moines metro included observed tornadoes.\n\n4:20 p.m. Tornado warning includes Ankeny, Johnston and Waukee\n\nA radar-indicated tornado prompted a tornado warning for parts of the Des Moines metro area until 5 p.m. Quarter-sized hail is also possible.\n\nVideo shows heavy damage after tornado in Greenfield, Iowa\n\nJournalists with Des Moines TV station WHO are in Greenfield, Iowa, which appears to have been hit by a tornado earlier on Tuesday. Video posted to social media shows several damaged buildings in the town located at the intersection of Iowa Highways 25 and 92.\n\nThe Adair County Health System hospital in Greenfield was damaged, a MercyOne spokesperson told the Register.\n\nSevere thunderstorm warning issued for Des Moines metro as strong storms arrive\n\nA severe thunderstorm warning has been issued as a line of storms approaches the Des Moines metro area.\n\nThe entire metro area is included in the warning that stretches south of the metro and up north to Ames, Gilbert and Nevada. It includes Winterset on the western edge and through to MItchelville on the east side. It is in effect until 5:15 p.m.\n\nThreats include wind up to 60 mph as well as possible quarter-sized hail and tornadoes.\n\nTornado warning issued around Webster City\n\nA tornado warning has been issued to include Webster City, Jewell Junction and Stratford until 4:45 p.m.\n\nThe NWS warning is for a radar-indicated tornado and the risk of quarter-sized hail.\n\nWhat is a stovepipe tornado?\n\nA stovepipe tornado is one where the width of the tornado is about the same from when it meets the ground all the way up to where it connects to the base of the above thunderstorm, according to AccuWeather. Stormchasers have described some storms in western Iowa Tuesday as stovepipe tornadoes.\n\nIt is considered the cousin of a cone tornado, which is similar in size but tapers as it extends downward to the ground.\n\n3:55 p.m.: Flood warning issued for Fourmile Creek in Des Moines\n\nA flood warning has been issued for Fourmile Creek on the east side of Des Moines, according to the NWS.\n\nThe crest forecast is 13.9 feet, assuming Des Moines gets 0.75 inches of additional rain. At 13 feet the water threatens the dog park on Hubbell Avenue At 14 feet, widespread flooding occurs, NWS said, affecting lowland areas like the community center on Easton Boulevard.\n\n3:40 p.m. Tornado warning issued for Greenfield, Winterset, Earlham as storms move closer to Des Moines\n\nAs storms head east, they have begun to enter the Des Moines metro area.\n\nA tornado warning centered around Greenfield is in effect until 4:15 p.m.\n\nThe warning includes Stuart and stretches to Redfield in southwest Dallas County until 4:15 p.m.\n\nAnother warning includes Creston and stretches up toward Earlham and Winterset on the edges of the Des Moines metro. That warning goes until 4:30 p.m.\n\n3:14 p.m.: Tornado reported near Corning, Prescott\n\nAdditional tornado warnings continue to be issued in southwest Iowa.\n\nA warning for Corning, Orient and Prescott is in effect until 4 p.m. KCCI meteorologist Zane Satre was near Prescott with a live feed of a tornado on the ground.\n\nVideo captured by a storm chaser showed a tornado around 3 p.m. near Carbon, Iowa.\n\nA warning is also in effect for Guthrie Center, Panora and Exire until 4 p.m.\n\n3:05 p.m.: Damaging tornado reported in southwest Iowa:\n\nThe National Weather Service is continuing a warning for Fontanelle, Orient and Bridgewater until 3:45 p.m. The alert described it as a \"life-threatening situation\" with a damaging tornado reported.\n\n3 p.m.: Tornado reported in Red Oak, Iowa; warnings in southwest Iowa\n\nMeteorologists and storm chasers in western Iowa have reported a tornado on the ground in Red Oak. An emergency manager in the area said it was located near the Red Oak airport around 2:27 p.m.\n\nThe area is under a tornado warning until 3 p.m.\n\nA tornado warning is also in effect for areas around Essex, Hepburn, Stanton and Villisca until 3:30 p.m.\n\nThe NWS issued a new tornado warning at 2:57 p.m. for Fontanele, Orient and Bridgewater for a radar-indicated tornado and quarter-size hail possible. It expires at 3:45 p.m.\n\nTornado watches issued for all of Iowa ahead of next round of severe weather\n\nAll of Iowa is under a tornado watch for Tuesday afternoon.\n\nA tornado watch issued around 1:15 p.m. covers all of central and eastern Iowa and extends into portions of western Iowa. It will be in effect until 9 p.m. Tuesday.\n\nThe main threats are several strong tornadoes, scattered softball-size hail and wind gusts up to 90 mph, according to a post announcing the watch from the National Weather Service.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Omaha has issued several tornado warnings for eastern Nebraska and western Iowa for radar-indicated tornadoes as the storms develop in that area.\n\nAn earlier watch covers the remaining western Iowa counties until 5 p.m. Forecasters warned of winds up to 70 mph in those areas.\n\nWhen will more severe storms hit Iowa? NWS says this afternoon could be 'very dangerous'\n\nThe National Weather Service shared a graphic on social media showing the approximate timing for storms later today. In a comment on a Facebook post , the NWS said this afternoon's storms are \"expected to be very dangerous\"\n\nThunderstorms will likely start in west Iowa around 2 p.m., making their way to Des Moines and central Iowa around 4 p.m. At 7 p.m., the severe weather will be entering eastern Iowa.\n\nWhat's the difference between a severe weather watch and a severe weather warning?\n\nA watch is issued when conditions are favorable for severe weather to develop. They often cover large areas.\n\nWarnings are issued when severe weather is actually happening and Iowans need to take action.\n\nRead more: What's the difference between a severe weather watch and a warning?\n\n12:10 p.m.: Thousands without power after storms hit central Iowa\n\nCrews are working quickly to restore power to Iowans across the state. At one point, MidAmerican showed more than 7,000 people without power in Iowa as a result of Tuesday's storms.\n\nAs of 12:10 p.m., the number of customers without power in the Des Moines metro area was around 2,100. The Council Bluffs area was down to about 100 customers, after having more than 1,000 outages this morning.\n\nAlliant Energy was down to about 60 customers in the state without power.\n\n11:48 a.m.: Large hail reported in Waukee, Pella\n\nA severe thunderstorm moving through central Iowa produced large hail.\n\nTwo reports submitted to the National Weather Service around 11:20 a.m. listed 2 inch diameter hail near Pella.\n\nWaukee experienced hail ranging from the size of a nickel to as big as a quarter, at 9:07 a.m. according to a trained weather sportter. Wind gusts up to 55 mph were also reported.\n\nA warning issued for Pottawattamie County, home to Council Bluffs, until 7:30 a.m. warned of baseball size hail.\n\nHail that large is sometimes called \"gorilla\" hail for its large size and destructive power.\n\n11:28 a.m.: Metro schools dismissing early due to severe weather threat\n\nSeveral Des Moines metro school districts plan to dismiss classes early on Tuesday due to the threat of more severe storms this afternoon.\n\n11:18 a.m.: Storms dump nearly 3 inches of rain in central Iowa\n\nDes Moines has received just over an inch and a half of rain since severe weather entered Iowa early on Monday, with 1.07 inches since midnight.\n\nSome locations in the state are nearing three inches of rain since last night. Here are the highest rainfall totals as of 11 a.m Tuesday:\n\nAt least two roads in Des Moines are closed after a round of severe storms moved through the metro area.\n\nThe Des Moines Police Department received a small number of reports of power lines down and tree damage.\n\nThere are temporary lane closures at the 3300 block of Grand Avenue and the 3900 block of Urbandale Avenue. No significant damage or injury have been reported as of now, according to DMPD.\n\n9:28 a.m.: Severe thunderstorm warning extended in Polk County, to the east\n\nThe severe thunderstorm warning for parts of the Des Moines metro has been extended until 10:30 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nDallas County has been dropped from the warning, but it now extends into Jasper County and as far east as Grinnell and as far south as Pella.\n\nThreats include 60 mph winds and quarter-sized hail. The extended warning covers over 349,600 people.\n\n8:42 a.m.: Sirens sound in Des Moines as severe thunderstorm warning issued\n\nMuch of Dallas and Polk counties are under a severe thunderstorm warning until 9:45 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nStorm sirens began sounding just after 8:40 a.m. in the metro. Cities around Des Moines are at risk of winds up to 70 mph and quarter-sized hail.\n\nThe warning covers just north of Ankeny and as far south as Truro. It stretches to Redfield and Winterset in the west and Milo in the east.\n\nDallas and Polk counties both activate sirens for tornadoes or severe thunderstorms with winds over 70 mph. The warning meets that criteria, unlike a storm on Sunday night that activated the sirens in error.\n\nSirens do not sound continuously during a warning. They will sound for 3-5 minutes and then pause for 10-15 before repeating. There is not an all-clear sound when a warning expires.\n\nWhat does the Des Moines, Iowa doppler radar show?\n\nHere's a look at the current National Weather Service radar loop for central Iowa:\n\n8:10 a.m.: Severe thunderstorm warning issued on edge of Des Moines' western suburbs\n\nAreas around the Des Moines metro are under a severe thunderstorm warning until 9 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nThe warning extends from Dallas Center, down to Winterset and as far west as Adel. Possible threats include winds up to 70 mph and quarter-sized hail.\n\nJust over 34,000 people live within the warning area.\n\nWhat is Tuesday's severe weather outlook in Des Moines?\n\nThe National Weather Service upgraded the risk of severe weather for most of Iowa. A majority of the state it rated \"moderate\" risk, a level 4 on a scale of 1-5.\n\nMore: How much rain did Des Moines get so far? Here are the rainfall totals for Iowa through Monday morning\n\nMultiple rounds of storms are expected to continue through the morning. But, the strongest storms are expected to arrive in central Iowa between 3 p.m. and 8 p.m. Tuesday.\n\nDamaging winds, hail and flash flooding are the primary threats, according to the NWS. Tornadoes -- some strong -- are also possible.\n\nMore: How do tornadoes form? Explaining the severe weather after dozens of recent Iowa tornadoes\n\nSevere thunderstorm watch in effect for Iowa until 1 p.m.\n\nA large portion of central Iowa extending from the southern border to U.S. Highway 20 is under a severe thunderstorm watch until 1 p.m. Tuesday.\n\nThe main threats are ping-pong ball-sized hail and wind gusts that could reach 75 mph. Tornadoes are also possible.\n\nWhat should you do during a severe thunderstorm warning or tornado warning?\n\nDuring a severe weather warning, it's time to take action and follow your plan.\n\nNWS Adams County authorities have confirmed one person died in a weather-related incident.\n\nDinkla said officials believe everyone who was in Greenfield when that tornado struck is accounted for and they will confirmed the number of injuries and deaths later today.\n\n\"Obviously, this tornado has devastated a good portion of this town and community and with that much damage we want to make sure that we're doing our due diligence and making sure we cover that area extensively,\" Dinkla said.\n\nA 10 p.m. to 7 a.m. curfew is in effect in Greenfield. Dinkla said details about clean up and volunteer opportunities in Greenfield will be shared later today.\n\n\"The Greenfield community has a long road ahead of them,\" Dinkla said, \"but if their actions today are any indicator of what lies ahead, they will emerge stronger and more united than ever.\"\n\nGreenfield's hospital was hit and patients were transferred to other hospitals. The Nodaway High School in Greenfield is serving as a shelter for residents.\n\nClasses are cancelled today at Johnston High School due to extensive storm damage at the school. Governor Reynolds has issued a disaster declaration for 15 counties that were hit by yesterday's storms. In a written statement, Reynolds said she's committed to providing the full resources of the state to support response and recovery efforts. She plans to visit Greenfield today (Wednesday) to assess the damage in person.\n\nThe 15 counties included in the governor's disaster proclamation are Adair, Adams, Cass, Clay, Hardin, Harrison, Jasper, Kossuth, Marshall, Montgomery, Page, Palo Alto, Pottawattamie, Tama, and Warren.", "source": {"uri": "radioiowa.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Radio Iowa"}, "authors": [{"uri": "o_kay_henderson@radioiowa.com", "name": "O. {"uri": "8140540194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:33:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:33:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:28:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/where-greenfield-iowa-heres-know-140833428.html", "title": "Where is Greenfield, Iowa? Here's what we know about the deadly tornado", "body": "Multiple residents were killed, and at least a dozen others injured, after a tornado hit the small town of Greenfield on May 21.\n\nThe destruction comes after multiple rounds of storms plagued the state Tuesday, and nearly a month after at least 24 tornadoes swept through the state and devastated the western town of Minden.\n\nGov. Kim Reynolds announced she would visit Greenfield on Wednesday morning to assess the damage with local officials in a statement made Tuesday night.\n\nHere's what we know so far about Greenfield.\n\nSgt. Alex Dinkla, spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, confirmed the deaths at a news conference Tuesday night and estimated at least a dozen people were hospitalized. He did not know the exact number of those killed or injured. Dinkla did not think people were still missing as of Tuesday evening, but searches were still underway to confirm.\n\nDinkla did tell the Register on Wednesday that the town square and Wilson Opera House were spared.\n\nStructures in the path of the tornado are now rubble, as evidenced by drone video posted to social media.\n\nDamage also extends to the Adair County Health System hospital. The hospital was evacuated, a MercyOne spokesperson told the Des Moines Register.\n\nThe total population of the town located in Adair County about 2,000 people, according to the U.S Census Bureau.\n\nGreenfield is the county seat of Adair County. It's about 60 miles southwest of Des Moines, or about an hour drive, according to Google Maps.\n\nInformation is not yet available about the Greenfield tornado, but meteorologists have described the May 21 tornado as a \"dangerous tornado.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Des Moines will send three survey crews across the state to search for tornado damage on Wednesday. One team will be focused on just the Greenfield area.\n\nGreenfield became a settlement in 1854, according to the Greenfield Chamber Main Street.\n\nIt's home to the Iowa Aviation Museum and Hall of Fame and the Warren Cultural Center -- composed of the 1896 Warren Opera House and adjoining Hetherington and Taylor buildings, according to Greenfield Chamber.\n\nThe Warren Opera House block and Hetherington block is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Another National Register of Historic Places listing for Greenfield is Hotel Greenfield, which was built in 1919 for about $65,000, according to the hotel. The hotel was refurbished after it was purchased in 2010 to ADCO Enterprises, according to the hotel.\n\nGreenfield is supposed to host Register's Annual Great Bicycle Ride Across Iowa this July as a Day 3 meetup town. Red Oak, which also experienced tornado damage on Tuesday, is the Day 1 overnight town.\n\nAnne Lawrie, director of the cycling division of Ventures Endurance, the subsidiary of Register owner Gannett that operates the weeklong ride, said RAGBRAI had no comment as of early Wednesday morning on how the ride might be affected.\n\nDes Moines Register reporters Kyle Werner and Lee Rood contributed to this article.\n\nParis Barraza is a trending and general assignment reporter at the Des Moines Register. Reach her at pbarraza@registermedia.com. {"uri": "8139542876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:09:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:09:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T03:08:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/iowa-tornado-kills-multiple-people-in-small-town-reduced-to-rubble/article_1f40e2da-7ea2-52b6-847f-fb0ee1e869c6.html", "title": "Iowa tornado kills 'multiple' people in small town reduced to rubble", "body": "June Handsaker consoles his brother Larry Handsaker after a tornado damaged his house in Nevada, Iowa, U.S. May 21, 2024. Nirmalendu Majumdar/Ames Tribune/USA Today Network via REUTERS\n\nBy Brad Brooks and Steve Gorman\n\n(Reuters) -A powerful tornado ripped through a small Iowa town on Tuesday, killing multiple people and leaving at least a dozen injured, authorities said.\n\nImages from the town of Greenfield show a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled.\n\n\"This tornado has devastated a good portion of this town,\" said Sgt. Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, during an evening press conference in Greenfield.\n\n\"We can confirm there have been multiple fatalities with this tornado.\"\n\nDinkla did not provide a death toll, but said it may not be before Wednesday that figures could be provided.\n\nAt least a dozen people in Greenfield, a town of about 2,000 people, were injured in the twister, Dinkla said. Because the local hospital sustained damage in the storm, those people had to be transferred to facilities in nearby towns.\n\n\"I've lived here all my life. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, told CBS affiliate KCCI TV in an interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nOther video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nAt least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAlso in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. It said several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin.\n\nEarlier in the day, the weather service confirmed at least one tornado over Rollingstone, Minnesota.\n\n(Reporting by Brad Brooks in Longmont, Colorado, and Steve Gorman in Los Angeles; Editing by Sonali Paul and Michael Perry)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "2024-05-364779637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:13:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:13:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:03:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://eu.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/2024/05/22/greenfield-iowa-tornado-recovery-donations-volunteers-how-to-help/73800862007/", "title": "Here's how you can help Greenfield Iowa recover from Tuesday's tornado", "body": "Colton and Shaye Newberry explain the terrifying moments when a powerful tornado struck the town of Greenfield, Iowa, obliterating the house where they were taking shelter.\n\nUnimaginable damage is how the Adair County Sheriff's Department described the result of the tornado that hit Greenfield, Iowa, Tuesday evening. The city is collecting monetary donations and looking for equipment to help aid in the town's recovery.\n\nMultiple fatalities and at least a dozen injuries have been reported in Greenfield. It's not yet known how strong the tornado was or the full extent of the damage. But, much of the town of about 2,000 people has been damaged.\n\nBefore you offer a hand to Greenfield, the best thing you can do is follow the procedure. Here's how you can help Greenfield, Iowa, in the aftermath of the tornado.\n\nAccess to Greenfield, Iowa is limited after tornado\n\nThe Adair Sheriff's Department said in a Facebook post in the early hours of Wednesday morning that access to Greenfield must be limited to ensure aid can enter the town. Anyone trying to enter the town must provide identification and nonresidents may be turned away.\n\n\"In speaking with those who responded to the tornado that struck towns in western Iowa earlier this spring, these steps are needed to prevent a tremendous amount of nonessential people from slowing down the progress of those who are essential to clean up, especially utility crews trying to restore power to the city,\" according to the Facebook post.\n\nThere are state troopers at most entrances to Greenfield. The emergency proclmation also imposes a curfew for the city between 10 p.m. to 7 a.m. After those hours, you will need identification to prove you are essential help.\n\nMore: Where is Greenfield, Iowa? Here's what we know about the deadly tornado\n\nHow to get credentialed to enter Greenfield, Iowa following tornado\n\nBefore you can help on the grounds in Greenfield, you must be credentialed to easily enter city limits, according to the Adair Sheriff's Office.\n\nVisit the Iowa DOT Maintenance shed at 2313 State Highway 92, just east of Greenfield, for credentialing. The process began at 9 a.m. Wednesday. A large red Hy-Vee semi-trailer is expected to be the hub for credentialing, according to the Adair County Sheriff's Department.\n\nOnce you approach a checkpoint, you will need identification showing a Greenfield address or a specific location you are going to help. Be prepared to call someone at the address to verify where you are going, according to the Adair County Sheriff's Office.\n\nThe Adair County Sheriff's Office asked anyone willing to lend manpower or equipment for cleanup efforts to comment their contact information on a Facebook post made by the department on Tuesday. The department asked that volunteers refrain from calling the dispatch number because lines are busy.\n\nAnyone who doesn't want their direct number on the Facebook post can directly message the sheriff's office Facebook page, according to the post.\n\nWhere is the community shelter in Greenfield?\n\nThere is a community shelter in Greenfield at the Nodaway Valley Community High School at 410 NW. 2nd St. The American Red Cross sent a trailer of supplies including water and blankets Tuesday evening.\n\nIowa's American Red Cross Division posted to their Facebook that the agency is actively working with local emergency management in impacted areas from the severe weather on Tuesday. The American Red Cross is supporting the independent community shelter, according to the social media post.\n\nThe aid organization is still assessing the needs of the community to determine how to help.\n\nHow to make donations to Greenfield, Iowa tornado recovery\n\nFNB Bank and Union State Bank, two local banks in Greenfield, are accepting monetary donations for tornado damage from Tuesday.\n\nDonations can also be made to Greenfield's foundation at greenfieldiafoundation.org.\n\nThe Red Cross is also accepting donations at redcross.org/ia.\n\nWho to contact for assistance from severe weather in Iowa?\n\nThe red cross has a hotline for anyone in need of assistance from the severe weather, according to the organizations Facebook post.\n\nYou can call 1-800-RED-CROSS or 1-800-733-2767.\n\n\"We will continue to prove comfort and support to our fellow Iowans in the coming days and weeks,\" the Red Cross Facebook post stated.", "source": {"uri": "desmoinesregister.com", {"uri": "8140905163", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "18:53:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T18:53:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T18:52:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2947192-tornado-devastation-in-greenfield-iowa-town-struggles-to-recover", "title": "Tornado Devastation in Greenfield: Iowa Town Struggles to Recover | Science-Environment", "body": "Rescue teams in Greenfield, Iowa, are racing to find survivors after a deadly tornado ravaged the town, obliterating homes and buildings. Authorities are still assessing the damage and the number of casualties. Governor Kim Reynolds has declared a disaster emergency, seeking federal assistance for recovery efforts.\n\nRescue teams in Iowa searched through the ruins of homes and buildings in Greenfield on Wednesday, looking for survivors of a deadly tornado that tore through the town the day before.\n\nAuthorities were still determining how many people were killed, injured and displaced by the twister in the farming town of 2,000 located about 60 miles (97 km) west of Des Moines, Sergeant Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, told a news conference. \"It is still a search mission as far as we are looking to make sure all residents are accounted for,\" he said. \"When we have this many homes that have been destroyed, fully demolished, we want to make sure every person is accounted for.\"\n\nImages from Greenfield showed a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled. \"It's horrific. It's hard to describe,\" said Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds, who declared a disaster emergency for 15 counties.\n\nThe twister that touched down in Greenfield was among a swarm of tornadoes that were reported in southwestern Iowa on Tuesday evening. At least one person, a woman in nearby Adams County, was killed in the storms, the county's medical examiner said. Reynolds said state officials were working to send a request for President Joe Biden to approve a disaster declaration in order to get federal assistance for state residents.\n\nAmong the buildings damaged in Greenfield was a hospital, forcing authorities to create a makeshift medical care center at the lumberyard and send some of the injured to other area facilities. State Representative Ray Sorensen said several residents used their own vehicles to transport those who were injured to safety moments after the storm struck.\n\n\"We pulled a guy from the rubble and put him on a little makeshift stretcher we made and threw him in the back of a truck,\" he said. Tornadoes along with severe storms packing large hail and damaging winds were likely again on Wednesday across the Southern Plains as well as Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas, the National Weather Multiple wind turbines completely shredded, one on fire, power pole stumps left behind with entire poles gone. Strong strong tornado.\"\n\nThe raging storms pummeled Iowa on Tuesday, with 68 mph wind gusts noted at Waterloo Airport at 6:01 p.m., reported the National Weather Service (NWS).\n\nTwo tornado warnings were also issued for the Des Moines, Iowa, metro area around 4:45 p.m., the NWS said. Both warnings had \"observed tornadoes.\" The NWS also advised residents to \"seek shelter.\"\n\nCleanup is already underway in Greenfield, according to local WHO13 Sports Director Keith Murphy, who took to X on Tuesday night, saying: \"Clean-up has begun in Greenfield. @AndyFales on the scene and says it's just devastating.\"\n\nWHO13 Anchor Katie Kaplan also posted to X, sharing a video of the aftermath of the storm in Greenfield. Cinder block building gone.
