{"uri": "8140559918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:42:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:42:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:41:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13447709/Iowans-left-devastated-swarm-tornadoes-destroys-tiny-town.html", "title": "Iowans left devastated as swarm of tornadoes destroys tiny town", "body": "Iowans have been left devastated after a swarm of tornadoes destroyed a tiny town and left several dead on Tuesday. Hours after a tornado touched down in Greenfield, about 55 miles from Des Moines, aerial footage showed where the tornadoes tore through the town as homes were leveled and trees were shredded down to their stumps. Wendi Rae, a reporter from Greenfield, posted an emotional video and horrific pictures of the aftermath that has taken over her hometown.\n\n'This is the damage along Highway 25 in Greenfield. There are houses completely gone, so it's really devastating,' Rae said. 'Everybody's out right now just checking on each other- this town is full of a lot of really good-hearted people, so send us your prayers because there is a lot of devastation here right now.'\n\nIowa Police confirmed that multiple people died in the deadly weather front. One death occurred in Adams County, around 90 miles southwest of Des Moines, when a woman was ejected from a vehicle during the brutal storm. Rae's video showed the destruction in the small town with a population of a little more than 2,000 people. She explained that her family's house is 'relatively OK,' but that others in the area weren't as fortunate.\n\nAs she walked along the highway, residents were seen trying to start the massive clean up process. Piles of wood replaced houses, trees were seen sliced in half and furniture was scattered across the neighborhood. Rae also posted photos of the disastrous aftermath, as one showed a red car, covered in dust and dirt, flipped on its hood, as a seat cushion dangled from a nearby tree.\n\nAnother image showed the inside of a home with beat up walls, disheveled furniture and wood and branches breaking through the window. One image captured an American flag slanted, hanging off of a wooden post, as piles upon piles of debris surrounded it. 'Please pray for my hometown! The damage is absolutely devastating. There are no words,' Rae captioned the post.\n\nEntire neighborhoods were flattened by several deadly twisters that gripped the region as Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds placed 15 counties under disaster emergency proclamations. Carnage is expected to continue through the Midwest as a storm system develops - with over 25 million people currently under severe weather warnings, stretching from Missouri to Wisconsin . Along with the Hawkeye State, Nebraska, Wisconsin and Illinois were also hit by tornadoes, heavy rain and power outages, BBC reported.\n\nOverhead footage showed widespread damage hours after the tornadoes tore through rural Iowa, including entire trees being shredded from their roots. Greenfield, around 40 miles from the death in Adams County, was among the hardest hit, as a tornado that developed around 5pm leveled hundreds of homes and left several people injured, Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt. Alex Dinkla said. At a press conference, Dinkla estimated that over a dozen people were hospitalized, but could not offer an exact number. He added that all known residents were accounted for, but searches were still ongoing through the wreckage.\n\nA local hospital was hit by the fierce tornadoes, forcing staff and patients to evacuate the ransacked buildings and set up field hospitals at nearby high schools. Massive wind turbines were also destroyed by the gusts, with at least three turbines destroyed in Adams County. MidAmerican Energy Company said it owned several more that were destroyed in Adair County. While aiding injured residents, the Adair County Memorial Hospital also 'sustained tornado damage', officials said, that forced it to transfer patients to other nearby medical centers.\n\nGreenfield instated a mandatory curfew from 10pm to 7am as the aftermath is surveyed, however officials said the true extent of the devastation may not be clear until Wednesday morning. Heavy cleanup crews have been spotted across the state, with unaffected counties including Guthrie and Madison reportedly enlisted to help clear damage in Greenfield. Early reports said multiple tornadoes were also reported in Montgomery County, and Meteorologists warned that the storm system across the Midwest may generate several more catastrophic-strength tornadoes.\n\nIn total across the Midwest, over 25million people were under at least a Level 3 severe thunderstorm warning on Tuesday evening. Midwesterners are now preparing for yet another storm that is expected to roll through central Texas all the way to upstate New York this week. The system is expected to bring hail, damaging winds and tornadoes, with a severe weather threat in parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas.\n\nWind damage and hail, possibly golf ball sized or larger, are the primary concerns, but meteorologists warn a few tornados are also expected. Northern Texas, southeast Oklahoma, northern and central Arkansas, southern Missouri and western Tennessee are most likely to be hit by twisters. Strong storms will fire up today across the Midwest, western New York and Pennsylvania, but the threat of severe weather will continue into tomorrow. Forecasters are primarily concerned about regions in northern Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, northwest Louisiana, southwest Missouri and southern Kansas.\n\nThe risk of strong winds tomorrow is greatest from Wichita, Kansas to Oklahoma City, Dallas and Little Rock. AccuWeather forecasters have predicted winds could reach speeds of 60 to 70mph. A corridor from the Arklatex to the Mississippi, Tennessee and Ohio River valleys will be hit with rounds of heavy rain today and tomorrow. The area will see between 2 to 4 inches of rain over a 48-hour period, putting residents at a risk for flash flooding. Parts of the Midwest, as well as regions in the south and east, could also see scattered, severe thunderstorms from Friday and throughout the Memorial Day weekend.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? {"uri": "2024-05-364155834", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "06:09:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T06:09:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T05:44:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/tornado-spawning-storms-left-multiple-people-dead-in-iowa-and-are-now-threatening-cities-from/article_4ccd7cb4-c4d3-5695-909b-35e883011f08.html", "title": "Tornado-spawning storms left multiple people dead in Iowa and are now threatening cities from Texas to New York", "body": "(CNN) -- Some Iowa communities will be waking up Wednesday to sift through the rubble of now-unrecognizable homes and mourn the deaths of neighbors who were killed by a series of tornado-spawning storms that tore through the Midwest yesterday and are now setting their sights on a much broader swath of the US.\n\nMultiple fatalities and some injuries have been reported in the small city of Greenfield, Iowa - about 50 miles southwest of Des Moines - after a tornado carved a devastating path through the community Tuesday evening, Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt. Alex Dinkla told CNN. Dinkla did not elaborate on the number or nature of the deaths.\n\n\"There is basically nothing left,\" Clel Baudler, a former Iowa state representative who lives a half mile from Greenfield, told CNN on Tuesday. Video taken by CNN affiliate KCCI shows homes and other structures have been obliterated and the community is blanketed with heaps of debris, tossed cars and uprooted trees.\n\nAt least 17 tornado reports were generated in Iowa Tuesday - part of a parade of storms that has been marching across the US this week, leaving widespread power outages, structural damage and some flooding in their wake.\n\nPower outages across Iowa, Wisconsin and Illinois left nearly 200,000 homes and businesses in the dark as of Tuesday night, according to PowerOutage.us. Even more outages are anticipated as Wednesday's storms roll through the East.\n\nOn Wednesday, the severe thunderstorm threat weakens slightly but is expected to unleash harsh winds, hail and some tornadoes along a sprawling 1,500-mile expanse from Texas to western New York.\n\n\"Severe thunderstorms posing a risk for damaging gusts and hail will be possible from central Texas into the Ohio Valley and lower Great Lakes area on Wednesday. The greatest threat of damaging hail and wind is forecast from north Texas across the Ozarks,\" the Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nA handful of tornadoes could strike from Texas to Kentucky, but hail and powerful winds are possible anywhere along the storms' path.\n\nNearly 11 million people are under an enhanced risk, Level 3 of 5, risk of thunderstorms across northern Texas, southern Oklahoma, southern Missouri and much of Arkansas, according to the Storm Prediction Center. This area includes the populous Texas cities of Dallas, Forth Worth and Arlington.\n\nThough under a less severe risk Wednesday, cities including Nashville, St. Louis, Memphis, Cleveland, Tulsa and Columbus should be storm-aware.\n\nTornadoes tear deadly and destructive path through Iowa\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds issued a disaster emergency proclamation Tuesday for 15 counties as a potent line of thunderstorms prompted rare, escalated levels of tornado watches across parts of Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Illinois.\n\nWestern Iowa bore the brunt of the storms' catastrophic impacts. Violent winds and possible tornadoes flattened buildings in Greenfield, toppled a hulking wind turbine in Prescott and reduced several people's homes to mountains of jagged debris.\n\nIn addition to the fatalities reported in Greenfield, at least one other person was killed as storms passed through nearby Adams County, local officials said.\n\nMore than two dozen homes were damaged or destroyed in Montgomery County, including some \"critical public facilities,\" emergency management officials said. No injuries have been reported but damage assessments are still ongoing.\n\nValerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, pleaded with God to protect her home and her family before she rode out the storm in her basement, she told CNN affiliate KCCI.\n\n\"I was in the furnace room and then I heard (the storm) like a train,\" she said, describing insulation flying off of basement windows. \"I heard it and I knew it was hitting.\"\n\nWarrior said the scale of damage is \"devastating\" to see, but she is confident residents will pull each other through the crisis.\n\n\"They'll get through it. You already see people out helping each other, working together. And that's what they do, people come together when a tragedy happens. People come together to support and encourage each other.\"\n\nFighting back tears, Warrior looked out across a rubble-strewn lawn and tried to crack a smile.\n\n\"We'll rebuild, we'll rebuild.\"\n\nCNN's Jessica Jordan, Sara Smart and Amy Simonson contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. There are houses completely gone, so it's really devastating,' Rae said.\n\n'Everybody's out right now just checking on each other- this town is full of a lot of really good-hearted people, so send us your prayers because there is a lot of devastation here right now.'\n\nAerial footage showed where the tornados tore through the town as homes were leveled and trees were shredded down to their stumps on Tuesday\n\nWendi Rae, a reporter from Greenfield, posted an emotional video and horrific pictures of the aftermath that has taken over her hometown\n\nIowa Police confirmed that multiple people died in the deadly weather front. One death occurred in Adams County, around 90 miles southwest of Des Moines, when a woman was ejected from a vehicle during the brutal storm.\n\nRae's video showed the destruction in the small town with a population of a little more than 2,000 people.\n\nRead More Incredible footage shows destruction as deadly tornadoes rip through Iowa and kill multiple people: 15 counties declared disaster zones with hospital forced to evacuate, homes toppled and 25 million under severe warnings\n\nShe explained that her family's house is 'relatively OK,' but that others in the area weren't as fortunate.\n\nAs she walked along the highway, residents were seen trying to start the massive clean up process.\n\nPiles of wood replaced houses, trees were seen sliced in half and furniture was scattered across the neighborhood.\n\nRae also posted photos of the disastrous aftermath, as one showed a red car, covered in dust and dirt, flipped on its hood, as a seat cushion dangled from a nearby tree.\n\nAnother image showed the inside of a home with beat up walls, disheveled furniture and wood and branches breaking through the window.\n\nOne image captured an American flag slanted, hanging off of a wooden post, as piles upon piles of debris surrounded it.\n\n'Please pray for my hometown! The damage is absolutely devastating. There are no words,' Rae captioned the post.\n\nRae posted an image of a red car flipped onto its hood as seat cushions dangled in a nearby tree\n\nEntire neighborhoods were flattened by several deadly twisters that gripped the region as Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds placed 15 counties under disaster emergency proclamations.\n\nCarnage is expected to continue through the Midwest as a storm system develops - with over 25 million people currently under severe weather warnings, stretching from Missouri to Wisconsin.\n\nAlong with the Hawkeye State, Nebraska, Wisconsin and Illinois were also hit by tornadoes, heavy rain and power outages, BBC reported.\n\nOverhead footage showed widespread damage hours after the tornadoes tore through rural Iowa, including entire trees being shredded from their roots.\n\nGreenfield, around 40 miles from the death in Adams County, was among the hardest hit, as a tornado that developed around 5pm leveled hundreds of homes and left several people injured, Iowa State Patrol spokesperson Sgt. Alex Dinkla said.\n\nOne image captured an American flag slanted, hanging off of a wooden post, as piles upon piles of debris surrounded it\n\nRae shared an image from inside a home with beat up walls, disheveled furniture and wood and branches breaking through the window\n\nAt a press conference, Dinkla estimated that over a dozen people were hospitalized, but could not offer an exact number. He added that all known residents were accounted for, but searches were still ongoing through the wreckage.\n\nA local hospital was hit by the fierce tornadoes, forcing staff and patients to evacuate the ransacked buildings and set up field hospitals at nearby high schools.\n\nMassive wind turbines were also destroyed by the gusts, with at least three turbines destroyed in Adams County. MidAmerican Energy Company said it owned several more that were destroyed in Adair County.\n\nRead More Midwest braced for battering as maps show dangerous storms will last for days from Texas to Arkansas after deadly tornadoes ripped through Iowa killing multiple and flattening entire cities\n\nWhile aiding injured residents, the Adair County Memorial Hospital also 'sustained tornado damage', officials said, that forced it to transfer patients to other nearby medical centers.\n\nGreenfield instated a mandatory curfew from 10pm to 7am as the aftermath is surveyed, however officials said the true extent of the devastation may not be clear until Wednesday morning.\n\nHeavy cleanup crews have been spotted across the state, with unaffected counties including Guthrie and Madison reportedly enlisted to help clear damage in Greenfield.\n\nEarly reports said multiple tornadoes were also reported in Montgomery County, and Meteorologists warned that the storm system across the Midwest may generate several more catastrophic-strength tornadoes.\n\nIn total across the Midwest, over 25million people were under at least a Level 3 severe thunderstorm warning on Tuesday evening.\n\nHouses and cars are seen damaged outside of Adair County Health System hospital in Greenfield\n\nThe remains of a tornado-damaged wind turbine touch the ground in a field on Tuesday near Prescott, Iowa\n\nMidwesterners are now preparing for yet another storm that is expected to roll through central Texas all the way to upstate New York this week.\n\nThe system is expected to bring hail, damaging winds and tornadoes, with a severe weather threat in parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas.\n\nWind damage and hail, possibly golf ball sized or larger, are the primary concerns, but meteorologists warn a few tornados are also expected.\n\nNorthern Texas, southeast Oklahoma, northern and central Arkansas, southern Missouri and western Tennessee are most likely to be hit by twisters.\n\nStrong storms will fire up today across the Midwest, western New York and Pennsylvania, but the threat of severe weather will continue into tomorrow.\n\nForecasters are primarily concerned about regions in northern Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas, northwest Louisiana, southwest Missouri and southern Kansas.\n\nJune Handsaker consoles his brother Larry Handsaker after a tornado damaged his house in Nevada, Iowa\n\nA car is damaged by flying debris during the tornados in Greenfield\n\nStrong storms will strike across central Texas and all the way to upstate New York this week, forecasters have warned. The threat of severe weather is greatest in parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas\n\nThe risk of strong winds tomorrow is greatest from Wichita, Kansas to Oklahoma City, Dallas and Little Rock.\n\nAccuWeather forecasters have predicted winds could reach speeds of 60 to 70mph.\n\nA corridor from the Arklatex to the Mississippi, Tennessee and Ohio River valleys will be hit with rounds of heavy rain today and tomorrow.\n\nThe area will see between 2 to 4 inches of rain over a 48-hour period, putting residents at a risk for flash flooding.\n\nParts of the Midwest, as well as regions in {"uri": "2024-05-364867060", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:35:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:35:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:30:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://eu.press-citizen.com/story/weather/2024/05/22/how-did-tornadoes-form-across-iowa-what-nws-weather-conditions-say-tornado-map/73801071007/", "title": "How did tornadoes form across Iowa on Tuesday? What we know about the weather conditions", "body": "Multiple tornadoes touched down in Iowa on Tuesday night and devastated communities across the state. Wednesday, Iowans are assessing the damage and beginning to clean up.\n\nHere's what we know about the storm system that swept across the Midwest.\n\nIowa tornado map: Where did tornadoes reported in Iowa on Tuesday?\n\nNo tornadoes will officially be confirmed until the National Weather Service is able to send survey crews out into Iowa. On social media, the Des Moines office said three survey teams will be in the field on Wednesday. The National Weather Service in Omaha is also sending teams into southwest Iowa to complete surveys.\n\nUnofficial reports from trained weather spotters throughout Tuesday included: A cluster of sightings in southwest Iowa in Cromwell, Prescott, Corning, Carbon, Red Oak and Villisca. Greenfield in southwest Iowa appeared to be a particularly hard hit. In central Iowa there were unconfirmed reports in Nevada, rural Story County and southeast of Polk City.\n\nUpdates: Tornado, storm damage still being felt in Iowa as clean up begins\n\nWhat caused the storm system that produced deadly tornadoes in Iowa?\n\nA surface low-pressure system swept across the Midwest on Tuesday, triggering multiple storm formations, said Allan Curtis, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Des Moines.\n\nThat's not what made the system, unusual, though. The dangerous storms were driven by the way all of the \"ingredients\" lined up on Tuesday, he said.\n\nMore details: How do tornadoes form? Explaining the severe weather after dozens of recent Iowa tornadoes\n\n\"[We need] cold fronts, moisture and humidity. We had some sunshine that kind of helped give things more energy,\" Curtis said. \"A big part and this is a little less intuitive for the public, we also look up into the atmosphere. We need some strong winds up there to kind of help keep those kind of storms going.\"\n\nThese types of storm systems are easy to spot in advance, Curtis said. By Monday, NWS meteorologists were forecasting an enhanced (Level 3) risk for severe weather, and began alerting the public via radio, online updates and social media. That increased to a moderate risk (Level 4) by Tuesday morning, hours before deadly storms hit the state.\n\nMore: What is a PDS watch? Understanding the label that describes 'rare situations' for tornadoes\n\nWhen did severe weather enter Iowa on Tuesday?\n\nAn early wave of severe thunderstorms entered the state late Monday night and early Tuesday morning. A few severe thunderstorm and tornado warnings were issued in southwest Iowa shortly after midnight.\n\nAs forecast, another round of severe storms developed in Nebraska in the afternoon, bringing the most dangerous storms to Iowa, Curtis said.\n\nBy 1:30 p.m. storms had crossed the Mississippi River into southwest Iowa, he said. Tornadoes were seen on the ground soon after in places like Prescott and Corning.\n\nGreenfield, where storms were particularly severe, had tornadoes on the ground by 3:30 p.m. Around 4:50 p.m., severe weather had crossed the Des Moines metro and a damaging tornado touched down near Nevada in Story County. The storm was fast-moving, as it exited the state by 7 p.m.\n\nWhat damage assessments do we have for Tuesday's Iowa tornadoes?\n\nNWS Des Moines currently has teams out in the field doing damage assessment, Curtis said. One is stationed near Story County, another team is dedicated to Greenfield and the final is near Adams County.\n\n\"The focus right now is just trying to get that assessment done but also be out of the way for [the community] to do their recovery,\" Curtis said.\n\nNWS says Iowa tornadoes highlight the importance of being weather aware\n\nThis spring has been active for storm systems, but Curtis said that isn't stopping anytime soon, we aren't out of severe weather season, \"by any stretch.\"", "source": {"uri": "press-citizen.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Iowa City Press-Citizen"}, Alex Dinkla told CNN.\n\nHowever, he did not give an exact number or any details regarding the fatalities.\n\n\"There is basically nothing left,\" said Clel Baudler, a former Iowa state representative who lives a half mile from Greenfield.\n\nValerie Warrior, a resident in Greenfield, told local CBS affiliate KCCI-TV that she was out riding her bike when the initial tornado touched down.\n\n'There's houses down all over the place,' Warrior said.\n\nShe says she frantically rode back to her basement, where she remained and waited out the tornado.\n\nBut when she came out, she saw the town she loves and calls home, utterly destroyed.\n\n\"Devastating,\" she said.\n\nThis tornado comes off the heels of multiple intense storms happening throughout the nation in the past week, including three other tornadoes in Minnesota, Nebraska, and Colorado.\n\nOver the last forty years, The average number of yearly, billion-dollar natural disasters has increased from about three per year in the 1980s to roughly 18 a year from 2017 to 2021, according to a report by the National Centers for Environmental Information.\n\nThis can mainly be attributed to climate change, according to NASA.\n\n\"As Earth's climate changes, it is impacting extreme weather across the planet,\" NASA's website says.\n\n\"The human-caused rise in greenhouse gases has increased the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.\"\n\nFrom record-breaking heat waves to extreme rain, severe floods, long droughts, wildfires, tornados, and powerful hurricanes are all becoming more frequent and Multiple people are dead and injured as a result, said Alex Dinkla, the public information officer for the Iowa State Patrol, on Tuesday evening. Authorities have yet to release the number of fatalities.\n\nThe tornado was so powerful it blew debris 40,000 feet into the air, with people several miles away finding wreckage in their yards.\n\n\"This town has a long road ahead of them, but if their actions today are any indication of what lies ahead, they will emerge stronger and more united than ever before,\" Sgt Dinkla said.\n\nThe tornado brought extensive damage to the small town.\n\nFormer state representative Clel Baudler, who resides near Greenfield, told The Des Moines Register that officials are now focused on rescue efforts.\n\n\"Ambulances are running north and south like crazy,\" Mr Baudler said. \"It's all rescue and recovery right now.\"\n\nResident Carl Faust said he and his wife took shelter in their home as the tornado wrecked their town.\n\n\"I got down five steps to the basement, and the house started popping,\" Mr Faust told The Des Moines Register.\n\nThe Iowa governor, Kim Reynolds, said on Tuesday she is \"committed to providing the full resources of the state to support the response and recovery effort\".\n\nSome 1,400 people in Adair County, which houses Greenfield, are without power as of Wednesday morning, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMeanwhile, at least 32 other tornadoes spawned in the state on Tuesday. Almost all the tornadoes hit central and western Iowa, within 50 miles of the state capital Des Moines, reports local outlet Fox 9.\n\nIowans will see a reprieve on Wednesday as the severe weather begins to subside. Central Iowa is under a hazardous weather outlook warning for non-severe thunderstorms, while some counties are under flood warnings.\n\nHowever, severe thunderstorms are now threatening much of eastern Texas, southeastern Oklahoma and northwestern Arkansas, according to the National Weather Service (NWS).\n\nThese storms will bring the possibility for large hail, damaging wind gusts and tornadoes in the region, the NWS warns. Heavy rainfall may also contribute to flooding. Severe weather will peak on Wednesday afternoon in Oklahoma and Arkansas, while eastern Texas should be on alert through 1am on Thursday.\n\nSevere thunderstorms in Texas will continue on Thursday, the NWS says.\n\nOn Monday, Kansas also saw significant damage as a brutal storm passed through the state. Power lines were downed, and homes, businesses and vehicles were damaged as heavy gusts of winds tore through Russell County, officials said.\n\nSeven people also died in Houston, Texas, last week after severe weather hit the region. {"uri": "8140244626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "11:26:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T11:26:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T11:25:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/deadly-tornado-devastates-iowa-town-severe-weather-moves-south-rcna153430", "title": "Deadly tornado devastates Iowa town as severe weather moves south", "body": "Pictures from Greenfield, Iowa, show entire streets turned to wreckage, amid piles of debris, broken trees and demolished cars.\n\nCentral Iowa was reeling Wednesday morning after what police described as a \"devastating\" tornado laid waste to rural communities and killed an unknown number of people.\n\nIowa State Police confirmed a number of people had died in the town of Greenfield Tuesday, a community of about 2,000 people 40 miles southwest of Des Moines.\n\nSgt. Alex Dinkla said in a news conference that at least 12 people were treated in hospitals -- although the town's Adair County Memorial Hospital was also damaged, forcing first responders to take victims to facilities elsewhere.\n\nThe severe weather is expected to move away from the Midwest and toward the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said, with large hail, wind damage and tornadoes likely across Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas.\n\nAerial footage from Greenfield, Iowa, shot late Tuesday showed entire streets that were in the path of the tornado turned to wreckage, with piles of debris among broken trees and demolished cars.\n\nA man in nearby Red Oak, Montgomery County, captured footage of an enormous funnel cloud moving through the area as sirens wailed and intense rain fell.\n\nMontgomery County Emergency Management said in a statement that multiple confirmed tornadoes damaged at least 28 homes, with the damage ranging from \"affected to destroyed.\"\n\nWind turbines were left in ruin near Prescott, Iowa. And the wind was strong enough near the town of Nevada, Iowa, to topple a semi-truck which had stopped on a highway due to the extreme conditions. There has been no report of related casualties.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds declared a disaster in 15 counties and was due to visit the area on Wednesday.\n\nThe situation is so severe in Iowa that the NWS said it would deploy three teams from its Des Moines office to survey the tornado damage, with the results expected Wednesday night.\n\nElsewhere, in Colorado large hailstones stripped the cladding from buildings and shattering car windows -- NBC affiliate KUSA of Denver reported that the hail was at times baseball-sized.\n\nIn Omaha, Nebraska, cars were swept away by raging flood waters caused by between 4 and 8 inches of rain, leaving some stranded.\n\nNBC affiliate WOWT of Omaha spoke to local man Mike Troy, a school football coach, whose home was on a newly-created island. The water was not considered deep enough to justify a rescue, he said.\n\nMore than 70,000 energy customers were still without power in Texas after a torrid few days of severe weather as of 6 a.m. ET, according to energy connection tracker PowerOutage.us, while 67,000 were also without power in Wisconsin.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], However, the exact number is still being determined.\n\n\"We do have confirmed fatalities,\" Dinkla stated. He added that authorities believe they have accounted for all residents in the town. Alex Dinkla said at a news conference that at least 12 people were treated in hospitals -- although the town's Adair County Memorial Hospital was also damaged, forcing first responders to take victims to facilities elsewhere.\n\nThe severe weather is expected to move away from the Midwest and toward the southern Plains and the Mississippi Valley on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said, with large hail, wind damage and tornadoes likely across Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas.\n\nAerial footage from Greenfield, shot late Tuesday, showed entire streets that were in the path of the tornado turned to wreckage, with piles of debris among broken trees and demolished cars.\n\nA man in nearby Red Oak, Montgomery County, captured footage of an enormous funnel cloud moving through the area as sirens wailed and intense rain fell.\n\nThe Montgomery County Emergency Management said in a statement that multiple confirmed tornadoes damaged at least 28 homes, with the damage ranging from \"affected to destroyed.\"\n\nWind turbines were left in ruin near Prescott, Iowa. And the wind was strong enough near the town of Nevada, Iowa, to topple a semitruck which had stopped on a highway because of the extreme conditions. There has been no report of related casualties.\n\nIowa Gov. Kim Reynolds declared a disaster in 15 counties and was due to visit the area Wednesday.\n\nThe situation is so severe in Iowa that the weather service said it would deploy three teams from its Des Moines office to survey the tornado damage, with the results expected Wednesday night.\n\nElsewhere, in Colorado large hailstones stripped the cladding from buildings and shattered car windows -- NBC affiliate KUSA of Denver reported that the hail was at times the size of a baseball.\n\nIn Omaha, Nebraska, cars were swept away by raging floodwaters caused by between 4 and 8 inches of rain, leaving some stranded.\n\nNBC affiliate WOWT of Omaha spoke to Mike Troy, a local man and school football coach, whose home was on a newly created island. The water was not considered deep enough to justify a rescue, he said.\n\nMore than 70,000 energy customers were still without power in Texas after a torrid few days of severe weather as of 6 a.m. ET, {"uri": "2024-05-364024434", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "03:07:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T03:07:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:38:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/fatal-storms-pummel-iowa-reducing-parts-of-one-town-to-rubble/article_1f40e2da-7ea2-52b6-847f-fb0ee1e869c6.html", "title": "Fatal storms pummel Iowa, reducing parts of one town to rubble", "body": "By Brad Brooks and Steve Gorman\n\n(Reuters) - Severe thunderstorms, apparently spawning tornadoes, raked Iowa on Tuesday afternoon, leaving parts of one town in shambles, toppling several wind turbines and killing at least one person, according to authorities and local media.\n\nVideo of the storm's aftermath aired by television station KCCI, a CBS affiliate in the state capital of Des Moines, showed several homes reduced to piles of rubble in Greenfield, Iowa, a town of about 2,000 roughly 60 miles (97 km) to the southwest.\n\n\"I've lived here all my life. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, said in a KCCI interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nKCCI reported the damage to Greenfield was apparently caused by a tornado.\n\nOther video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nKCCI reported that Adair County Hospital in Greenfield was damaged and was evacuated, citing a hospital spokesperson.\n\nAt least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAlso in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. It said several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin.\n\nEarlier in the day, the weather service confirmed at least one tornado over Rollingstone, Minnesota.\n\n(Reporting by Brad Brooks in Longmont, Colorado, and Steve Gorman in Los Angeles; Editing by Sonali Paul)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update\n\nYour morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters.\n\nSuccess! Kim Reynolds. The disaster proclamation activates the Iowa Individual Assistance Grant Program and the Disaster Case Advocacy Program for storm victims. One man was killed April 26 when a tornado hit the small Pottawattamie County town of Minden. Kim Reynolds (R) has issued an emergency disaster proclamation for 15 counties, which makes available state resources for cleanup. \"That will allow DOT to get on the ground and help remove any debris and eliminate any barriers they might have in connecting with state resources,\" she said in a May 22 news conference.\n\nShe said the state is also seeking a federal major disaster declaration.\n\nEldon Ray, sales manager for Schildberg Construction, Inc., which provides aggregate material, said part of the roof was torn off the 80-year-old company's office in Greenfield, roughly 60 miles southwest of Des Moines,\n\n\"It took our office completely out,\" he said. \"We took a direct hit. Luckily, no one was hurt.\" Ray was at his desk at about 3:30 p.m. when the tornado hit.\n\n\"All of the windows busted out,\" he said. \"I closed my eyes and covered my head. It seemed like it lasted forever.\"\n\nEldon Ray was sitting at his desk when the tornado hit, devastating Schildberg Construction Co.'s Greenfield, Iowa, office.\n\nPhoto courtesy of Eldon Ray\n\nThe day after the tornado, Ray said the company was salvaging what they could and working from other of their office locations while hoping to be back in business within about a week.\n\nHe said wind turbines, owned by Des Moines-based MidAmerican Energy Co., also were destroyed. \"I drove by them and for seven or eight miles they were bent over, completely flat,\" he said.\n\nTina Hoffman, MidAmerican Energy's vice president of corporate communications, confirmed that the tornado struck two of its wind farms in Adair County.\n\n\"A tornado struck and collapsed five wind turbines at MidAmerican's Orient wind farm and one at the Arbor Hill wind farm,\" she said in a statement. \"Several turbines registered wind speeds over 100 mph as the tornado approached, before we lost contact with our sensors and the turbines were destroyed.\"\n\nShe said the company, which has operated wind farms since 2004, has previously lost only one other wind turbine, also due to a tornado.\n\nShe said manufacturers design the turbines to withstand severe thunderstorms and high wind events, \"but, as we've seen from the damage sustained throughout several Iowa counties, few structures can withstand a direct hit by a powerful tornado such as what we experienced on Tuesday,\" she said.\n\nThe company is inspecting all of its wind facilities in areas affected by the tornado before resuming operations, she saiid. Wind technicians took cover and were not injured during the storm, she said.\n\nSgt. Alex Dinkla, the Iowa State Patrol public information officer, confirmed there were fatalities and injuries resulting from the storm, but didn't specify numbers because it is still considered a search-and-rescue effort.\n\nGov. As of Wednesday morning, the authorities were still unable to provide a definitive estimate of the number of fatalities, in spite of the fact that they had stated that they did not wish to reveal a number until they were positive.\n\nWorkers in the small city, which had a population of 2,000 people, were still sorting through trash on Wednesday. This harsh weather caused injuries to at least twelve people, according to officials that responded to the situation. As far as the National Weather Service is concerned,\n\nHowever, they assert that the evaluation is still in progress and that there is a possibility that things will shift in the days to come. Tornadoes with winds of 136 to 165 miles per hour are classified as EF-3 tornadoes.\n\nResidents in the area have been relocated to shelters as a result of the damage that occurred to the local hospital. Additionally, a nearby school has been transformed into a temporary hospital. During the previous evening, the authorities had been using a lumberyard as a center for triage.\n\nAs per the findings of the FOX Weather Storm Tracker Brandon Copic, the majority of the village has been completely obliterated, according to his assessments of the situation. It has been largely decimated in this town. There is no other way to express this feeling than by the way it is expressed. In most of this town, there is a sense of desolation.\n\nThe Department of Transportation (DOT) Facility, which is located east of Greenfield, is accepting donations of food and water from anyone who wishes to show their support for the community they are a part of. For your convenience,\n\nIn addition to Greenfield, the National Weather Service in Des Moines received reports of tornadoes from Macksburg, Winterset, Norwalk, Alleman, Cambridge, Nevada, and Pleasant Hill during the late afternoon.\n\nThese reports were received from a variety of locations. The majority of these regions are located to the west of Des Moines, and each of them is within fifty miles of the city.\n\nA tornado that was approaching Carbon, Iowa, which is located around 60 miles east of Omaha, was captured on camera by FOX Weather earlier in the day. These allegations are in addition to the ones that have already been described. Another video shows what appears to be a tornado in the Red Oak, Iowa region. The tornado was captured on surveillance footage.\n\nAn further video was uploaded by a professional weather chaser that showed a tornado causing damage to a windmill in the vicinity of Williamson, {"uri": "8140964480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "19:47:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T19:47:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T19:45:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://people.com/multiple-people-dead-after-tornado-strikes-small-town-in-iowa-8652582", "title": "Multiple People Dead, Dozens Injured After Tornado Strikes Small Town in Iowa: 'It's Awful'", "body": "Abigail Adams is a Human Interest Writer and Reporter for PEOPLE. She has been working in journalism for seven years.\n\nMultiple people have been killed and dozens more injured after a tornado ripped through Iowa, according to authorities.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a tornado warning for the deadly storm system just after 3:30 p.m. local time on Tuesday, May 21.\n\nInitial storm surveys confirmed the tornado in Greenfield -- a town of about 2,100 people, according to U.S. Census data -- caused \"at least EF-3 damage,\" according to the agency.\n\nIowa State Patrol Sgt. Alex Dinkla confirmed the tornado caused \"fatalities and injuries within the community of Greenfield,\" but did not offer specific numbers, according to a news release from the Iowa Department of Public Safety.\n\nAmong those killed are an unidentified couple and a third individual, according to The Weather Channel. Cynthia Jenson, a cousin of one of the victims, said she knew all three individuals.\n\n\"It was heartbreaking,\" Jenson told the station while describing the damage she witnessed. \"I mean, there are houses that are gone that you always saw. You knew the landmarks in town to get to where you needed to go. So yeah, it's awful.\"\n\nDrone footage captured by professional storm chasers Reed Timmer and Mike Scantlin showed the massive twister barrelling through the small town.\n\nSeveral wind turbines were knocked down by the twister, which storm chasers also filmed.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\nThe Adair County Memorial Hospital sustained damage as well, though teams still \"worked swiftly to assist the injured,\" according to Dinkla.\n\nThe Greenfield Community School District is serving as both a reunification point and a temporary shelter following the storm, according to the sergeant.\n\n\"This town has a long road ahead of them, but if their actions today are any indication of what lies ahead, they will emerge stronger and more united than ever before,\" Dinkla told reporters Tuesday evening.\n\nA food and water donation site has been established at the Department of Transportation (DOT) Facility at 2313 Highway 92, Dinkla added.\n\n\"The community of Greenfield has shown incredible unity during this challenging time, with neighbors and friends displaying remarkable compassion, empathy, and support,\" Dinkla said at Tuesday's press conference.\n\nAt least 20 tornadoes touched down across the Midwest on Tuesday, according to ABC News. At least 18 twisters were recorded in Iowa, CNN reported.\n\nTornadoes have been ravaging the Midwest and Southern states since March, and more are expected on Wednesday. This time, the highest risk for twisters is in portions of central and eastern Texas, southwest Arkansas and northwest Louisiana, according to the NWS Storm Prediction Center.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8139517811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "02:38:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T02:38:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T02:38:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2945975-severe-thunderstorms-wreak-havoc-in-iowa-topple-wind-turbines-claim-life", "title": "Severe Thunderstorms Wreak Havoc in Iowa, Topple Wind Turbines, Claim Life | Science-Environment", "body": "Severe thunderstorms, causing tornadoes, hit Iowa on Tuesday, significantly damaging Greenfield and surrounding areas. The storm led to one fatality, multiple destroyed homes, and damaged infrastructure, including wind turbines and a hospital. Governor Kim Reynolds declared a disaster emergency for 15 counties, facilitating state resource deployment for recovery.\n\nSevere thunderstorms, apparently spawning tornadoes, raked Iowa on Tuesday afternoon, leaving parts of one town in shambles, toppling several wind turbines and killing at least one person, according to authorities and local media.\n\nVideo of the storm's aftermath aired by television station KCCI, a CBS affiliate in the state capital of Des Moines, showed several homes reduced to piles of rubble in Greenfield, Iowa, a town of about 2,000 roughly 60 miles (97 km) to the southwest. \"I've lived here all my life. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, said in a KCCI interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nKCCI reported the damage to Greenfield was apparently caused by a tornado. Other video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nKCCI reported that Adair County Hospital in Greenfield was damaged and was evacuated, citing a hospital spokesperson. At least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm. Also in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. It said several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin. Earlier in the day, the weather service confirmed at least one tornado over Rollingstone, Minnesota.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated {"uri": "8140940416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "19:24:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T19:24:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T19:24:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/iowa-crews-search-for-survivors-after-deadly-tornadoes/article_f228f673-f6a1-52b1-b70d-f008a93cd348.html", "title": "Iowa crews search for survivors after deadly tornadoes", "body": "By Brendan O'Brien\n\n(Reuters) - Rescue teams in Iowa searched through the ruins of homes and buildings in Greenfield on Wednesday, looking for survivors of a deadly tornado that tore through the town the day before.\n\nAuthorities were still determining how many people were killed, injured and displaced by the twister in the farming town of 2,000 located about 60 miles (97 km) west of Des Moines, Sergeant Alex Dinkla, a spokesperson with the Iowa State Patrol, told a news conference.\n\n\"It is still a search mission as far as we are looking to make sure all residents are accounted for,\" he said. \"When we have this many homes that have been destroyed, fully demolished, we want to make sure every person is accounted for.\"\n\nImages from Greenfield showed a path of utter destruction, with homes reduced to splinters, debris strewn everywhere and several large wind turbines toppled.\n\n\"It's horrific. It's hard to describe,\" said Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds, who declared a disaster emergency for 15 counties.\n\nThe twister that touched down in Greenfield was among a swarm of tornadoes that were reported in southwestern Iowa on Tuesday evening. At least one person, a woman in nearby Adams County, was killed in the storms, the county's medical examiner said.\n\nReynolds said state officials were working to send a request for President Joe Biden to approve a disaster declaration in order to get federal assistance for state residents.\n\nAmong the buildings damaged in Greenfield was a hospital, forcing authorities to create a makeshift medical care center at the lumberyard and send some of the injured to other area facilities.\n\nState Representative Ray Sorensen said several residents used their own vehicles to transport those who were injured to safety moments after the storm struck.\n\n\"We pulled a guy from the rubble and put him on a little makeshift stretcher we made and threw him in the back of a truck,\" he said.\n\nTornadoes along with severe storms packing large hail and damaging winds were likely again on Wednesday across the Southern Plains as well as Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas, the National Weather Service warned.\n\n(Reporting by Brendan O'Brien in Chicago; Editing by Sandra Maler)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8140644669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "15:37:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T15:37:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T15:36:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/heres-help-greenfield-iowa-recover-150337941.html", "title": "Here's how you can help Greenfield Iowa recover from Tuesday's tornado", "body": "Unimaginable damage is how the Adair County Sheriff's Department described the result of the tornado that hit Greenfield, Iowa, Tuesday evening. The city is collecting monetary donations and looking for equipment to help aid in the town's recovery.\n\nMultiple fatalities and at least a dozen injuries have been reported in Greenfield. It's not yet known how strong the tornado was or the full extent of the damage. But, much of the town of about 2,000 people has been damaged.\n\nBefore you offer a hand to Greenfield, the best thing you can do is follow the procedure. Here's how you can help Greenfield, Iowa, in the aftermath of the tornado.\n\nThe Adair Sheriff's Department said in a Facebook post in the early hours of Wednesday morning that access to Greenfield must be limited to ensure aid can enter the town. Anyone trying to enter the town must provide identification and nonresidents may be turned away.\n\n\"In speaking with those who responded to the tornado that struck towns in western Iowa earlier this spring, these steps are needed to prevent a tremendous amount of nonessential people from slowing down the progress of those who are essential to clean up, especially utility crews trying to restore power to the city,\" according to the Facebook post.\n\nThere are state troopers at most entrances to Greenfield. The emergency proclmation also imposes a curfew for the city between 10 p.m. to 7 a.m. After those hours, you will need identification to prove you are essential help.\n\nMore: Where is Greenfield, Iowa? Here's what we know about the deadly tornado\n\nBefore you can help on the grounds in Greenfield, you must be credentialed to easily enter city limits, according to the Adair Sheriff's Office.\n\nVisit the Iowa DOT Maintenance shed at 2313 State Highway 92, just east of Greenfield, for credentialing. The process began at 9 a.m. Wednesday. A large red Hy-Vee semi-trailer is expected to be the hub for credentialing, according to the Adair County Sheriff's Department.\n\nOnce you approach a checkpoint, you will need identification showing a Greenfield address or a specific location you are going to help. Be prepared to call someone at the address to verify where you are going, according to the Adair County Sheriff's Office.\n\nUpdates: Tornado, storm damage still being felt in Iowa as clean up begins\n\nThe Adair County Sheriff's Office asked anyone willing to lend manpower or equipment for cleanup efforts to comment their contact information on a Facebook post made by the department on Tuesday. The department asked that volunteers refrain from calling the dispatch number because lines are busy.\n\nAnyone who doesn't want their direct number on the Facebook post can directly message the sheriff's office Facebook page, according to the post.\n\nThere is a community shelter in Greenfield at the Nodaway Valley Community High School at 410 NW. 2nd St. The American Red Cross sent a trailer of supplies including water and blankets Tuesday evening.\n\nIowa's American Red Cross Division posted to their Facebook that the agency is actively working with local emergency management in impacted areas from the severe weather on Tuesday. The American Red Cross is supporting the independent community shelter, according to the social media post.\n\nThe aid organization is still assessing the needs of the community to determine how to help.\n\nFNB Bank and Union State Bank, two local banks in Greenfield, are accepting monetary donations for tornado damage from Tuesday.\n\nDonations can also be made to Greenfield's foundation at greenfieldiafoundation.org.\n\nThe Red Cross is also accepting donations at redcross.org/ia.\n\nThe red cross has a hotline for anyone in need of assistance from the severe weather, according to the organizations Facebook post.\n\nYou can call 1-800-RED-CROSS or 1-800-733-2767.\n\n\"We will continue to prove comfort and support to our fellow Iowans in the coming days and weeks,\" the Red Cross Facebook post stated.\n\nKate Kealey is a general assignment reporter for the Register. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, said in a KCCI interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nKCCI reported the damage to Greenfield was apparently caused by a tornado.\n\nOther video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nKCCI reported that Adair County Hospital in Greenfield was damaged and was evacuated, citing a hospital spokesperson.\n\nAt least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAlso in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. Alex Dinkla confirmed the tornado caused \"fatalities and injuries within the community of Greenfield,\" but did not offer specific numbers, according to a news release from the Iowa Department of Public Safety.\n\nRelated: 3 Dead After Tornadoes Hit Tennessee, North Carolina: 'All Hell Breaking Loose'\n\nAmong those killed are an unidentified couple and a third individual, according to The Weather Channel. Cynthia Jenson, a cousin of one of the victims, said she knew all three individuals.\n\n\"It was heartbreaking,\" Jenson told the station while describing the damage she witnessed. \"I mean, there are houses that are gone that you always saw. You knew the landmarks in town to get to where you needed to go. So yeah, it's awful.\"\n\nDrone footage captured by professional storm chasers Reed Timmer and Mike Scantlin showed the massive twister barrelling through the small town.\n\nSeveral wind turbines were knocked down by the twister, which storm chasers also filmed.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\nThe Adair County Memorial Hospital sustained damage as well, though teams still \"worked swiftly to assist the injured,\" according to Dinkla.\n\nThe Greenfield Community School District is serving as both a reunification point and a temporary shelter following the storm, according to the sergeant.\n\nRelated: At Least 5 People, Including a Baby, Dead After Tornadoes Hit Oklahoma and Iowa\n\n\"This town has a long road ahead of them, but if their actions today are any indication of what lies ahead, they will emerge stronger and more united than ever before,\" Dinkla told reporters Tuesday evening.\n\nA food and water donation site has been established at the Department of Transportation (DOT) Facility at 2313 Highway 92, Dinkla added.\n\n\"The community of Greenfield has shown incredible unity during this challenging time, with neighbors and friends displaying remarkable compassion, empathy, and support,\" Dinkla said at Tuesday's press conference.\n\nRelated: 1 Dead in Oklahoma as Tornadoes Touch Down in Multiple States amid Severe Weather Outbreak\n\nAt least 20 tornadoes touched down across the Midwest on Tuesday, according to ABC News. I'm just praying that everyone was safe, that everybody's safe, and nobody got hurt,\" Valerie Warrior, a Greenfield resident, said in a KCCI interview, standing near some of the demolished dwellings. \"It was scary, very scary.\"\n\nKCCI reported the damage to Greenfield was apparently caused by a tornado.\n\nOther video showed smashed vehicles and heavy damage to a gasoline station in Greenfield, the county seat of Adair County, which along with adjacent Adams County appeared to have borne the brunt of the Iowa storms in the southwestern corner of the state.\n\nKCCI reported that Adair County Hospital in Greenfield was damaged and was evacuated, citing a hospital spokesperson.\n\nAt least one person, a woman in Adams County, was listed as a storm-related fatality, the county's medical examiner Lisa Brown said. She spoke to Reuters by phone but said she could not yet provide more details.\n\nIowa Governor Kim Reynolds declared a \"disaster emergency\" for 15 counties, including Adair and Adams, allowing state resources to be readily utilized in responding to the storm.\n\nAlso in Adams County, at least three wind turbines standing about 25 stories high were nearly snapped in half, with one catching fire, KCCI reported. It said several other wind turbines were damaged in Adair County.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado warnings and severe thunderstorm advisories for much of Iowa and several other Midwestern states on Tuesday, including parts of Minnesota, and Wisconsin.\n\nEarlier in the day, the weather service confirmed at least one tornado over Rollingstone, Minnesota.\n\n(Reporting by Brad {"uri": "8140159760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "10:36:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T10:36:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T10:34:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://weisradio.com/2024/05/22/iowa-state-police-confirm-fatalities-injuries-as-tornadoes-rip-through-counties/", "title": "Iowa State Police confirm fatalities, injuries as tornadoes rip through counties - WEIS | Local & Area News, Sports, & Weather", "body": "(NEW YORK) -- Millions of people in states from the Great Plains to the Midwest were under the threat of tornadoes Tuesday, including Iowa, where several twisters touched down near Des Moines, causing major damage.\n\nA \"devastating\" tornado hit the town of Greenfield, Iowa, located southwest of Des Moines, causing fatalities and injuries in the area, Sgt. Alex Dinkla of the Iowa State Patrol said at a news conference Tuesday night.\n\nThe Adair County Memorial Hospital team, which serves Greenfield, sustained tornado damage, Dinkla said, but still managed to treat patients and transport some to nearby hospitals for further care.\n\nSearch efforts were underway Tuesday night, with officials working to provide a clear and accurate count of those affected, the officer said.\n\n\"We believe we have everyone accounted for, but we are conducting extensive searches to be thorough,\" he said.\n\nThe National Weather Service had issued tornado watches for parts of Nebraska, Iowa, South Dakota, Missouri, Arkansas, Wisconsin, Illinois, Minnesota, Kansas and Oklahoma through Tuesday night.\n\nNearly the entire state of Iowa was under a \"Particularly Dangerous Situation,\" according to the National Weather Service, which issued several tornado warnings.\n\nOn Tuesday, Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds authorized a proclamation of disaster emergency for 15 counties across the state.\n\nThe counties include Adair, Adams, Cass, Clay, Hardin, Harrison, Jasper, Kossuth, Marshall, Montgomery, Page, Palo Alto, Pottawattamie, Tama and Warren.\n\nSeveral videos obtained by ABC affiliate station WOI-TV in Des Moines, captured a large funnel cloud on the ground in Greenfield.\n\nOn Tuesday, WOI reporter Dana Searles, surveying the damage in Des Moines, said, \"This small community has a big chunk destroyed, but about half of it is still intact. From what I've seen, I'd estimate that maybe 75% of it is near to the ground right now.\"\n\nDamaging winds of 70 to 90 mph were forecast for Des Moines, Chicago and Milwaukee from Tuesday afternoon and into the evening.\n\nSevere weather is in full swing across the Great Plains and the Midwest, with more than 100 severe storms reported Monday from Colorado to Michigan.\n\nAt least three tornadoes were reported Monday in Minnesota, Nebraska, and Colorado, but there was no significant damage.\n\nIn Yuma, in northeast Colorado, hail ranging from golf ball to softball size pummeled the area, causing damage to cars and buildings. At one point, the hail was so deep it caused multiple vehicles to get stuck, JJ Unger, a volunteer Yuma firefighter, told ABC News Tuesday.\n\n\"It was like a blizzard hitting for a half hour because of the hail,\" Unger said. \"That's the longest I've seen it hail like that.\"\n\nUnger said he and his fire crew were out spotting for possible tornadoes Monday evening when lightning struck, and hail began to pour.\n\n\"It was very intense,\" said Unger, adding that he and his crew had to pull over and seek shelter as visibility went to almost zero.\n\nUnger said that when the hail finally let up, a foot of hail was covering his fire engine and roads in the area.\n\nHe said the windshields of his pickup truck and his wife's vehicle were shattered.\n\n\"Almost every home in town has broken windows and I've heard that over a thousand cars were damaged,\" Unger said.\n\nIn Nebraska, hail measuring two inches in diameter fell in Dundy County in the southwest corner of the state, according to local emergency management officials. Winds of over 90 mph were also reported in Dundy County.\n\nAs severe weather is expected through Thursday across the Great Plains and Midwest, potential record heat is moving into Texas and the Northeast.\n\nTemperatures could flirt with 90 degrees in Philadelphia, New York City and Washington, D.C., by the middle of this week.", "source": {"uri": "weisradio.com", "dataType": "news", The National Weather Service warns of a \"long swath of severe weather potential\" that spans over a dozen states.\n\nOn Tuesday, the worst storms pummeled Iowa, Illinois and Wisconsin. But on Wednesday, the greatest concern lay elsewhere.\n\n\"The severe threat today has stretched out across more of the country today with the focus of the nastiest storms moving south across parts of Texas, Louisiana, and Arkansas,\" said Nexstar meteorologist Brian James.\n\nWhat can happen if you park under an overpass during a tornado\n\nA National Weather Service forecast map (below) showed the possibility of severe weather as far north as New York.\n\n\"Damaging winds and large hail will be the main threats for most of those impacted by the stronger storms. A few tornadoes will also be possible, mainly across parts of Texas,\" said James.\n\nTornado watches were already in effect for parts of Texas by mid-day Wednesday.\n\nThe deadly twister that killed at least one person near Greenfield, Iowa, on Tuesday came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThese are the best places to live in the US: 2024 report\n\nThrough Tuesday, there had been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa -- including the one in Greenfield -- and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 Nexstar Media, Inc. {"uri": "8140459423", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "13:37:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T13:37:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T13:37:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.radioiowa.com/2024/05/22/at-least-six-tornadoes-strike-iowa-multiple-deaths-reported/", "title": "At least six tornadoes strike Iowa, multiple deaths reported - Radio Iowa", "body": "The state patrol says there are multiple deaths and at least a dozen injuries in Greenfield after Tuesday's direct hit from a powerful tornado. There's widespread destruction in the Adair County town, with homes leveled, cars tossed and trees stripped bare.\n\nMeteorologist Brad Small, at the National Weather Service in metro Des Moines, says it's still unclear just how many tornadoes hit the state on Tuesday afternoon. \"Present indications are right now, there were at least six,\" Small says, \"but we'll send surveys teams out today which will try to hone that number down a little closer.\"\n\nThose weather service teams will focus on three primary areas of the state where the tornadoes did their worst.\n\n\"One will be near Corning in southwest Iowa, and then also up toward Greenfield, which was obviously the most impacted location in the state,\" Small says, \"and then we also appear to have had a tornado in northern Polk County, possibly starting up by Saylorville Lake or northern Johnston and that tracked into Story County.\"\n\nThat tornado damaged Johnston High School, which is closed at least for today. Back in southwest Iowa, it appears Greenfield was hit by a large tornado, but Small says they don't know yet how big it may've been.\n\n\"We'll be able to provide more details on that later in the day today, looking at some aerial photography, drone imagery and of course, get on the ground and look at the damage up close and provide the rating,\" Small says. \"Remember, the tornado ratings are damage ratings, so it's not visually what the tornado looked like. It's strictly based on the damage that occurred.\"\n\nMore storms are in the immediate forecast, but Small says they don't appear to be threatening.\n\n\"Possibly some light showers, maybe a rumble of thunder today, but nothing significant today, and Thursday during the day looks dry, but Thursday night and Friday, the chances for showers and thunderstorms are back in the forecast,\" Small says. \"The severe weather potential doesn't look too great at this time. {"uri": "8140903144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "18:51:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T18:51:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T18:51:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.wdtn.com/news/u-s-world/map-more-than-a-dozen-states-could-see-severe-storms-tornadoes-wednesday/", "title": "MAP: More than a dozen states could see severe storms, tornadoes Wednesday", "body": "(NEXSTAR) - Parts of the country hit hard by destructive storms and deadly tornadoes Tuesday hardly have time to recover before the next threat rolls in Wednesday. The National Weather Service warns of a \"long swath of severe weather potential\" that spans over a dozen states.\n\nOn Tuesday, the worst storms pummeled Iowa, Illinois and Wisconsin. But on Wednesday, the greatest concern lay elsewhere.\n\n\"The severe threat today has stretched out across more of the country today with the focus of the nastiest storms moving south across parts of Texas, Louisiana, and Arkansas,\" said Nexstar meteorologist Brian James.\n\nA National Weather Service forecast map (below) showed the possibility of severe weather as far north as New York.\n\n\"Damaging winds and large hail will be the main threats for most of those impacted by the stronger storms. A few tornadoes will also be possible, mainly across parts of Texas,\" said James.\n\nTornado watches were already in effect for parts of Texas by mid-day Wednesday.\n\nThe deadly twister that killed at least one person near Greenfield, Iowa, on Tuesday came amid a historically bad season for tornadoes in the U.S. at a time when climate change is heightening the severity of storms around the world. April had the second highest number of tornadoes on record in the U.S.\n\nThrough Tuesday, there had been 27% more tornadoes in the country than average. The preliminary count for this year of 859 is the highest since 2017 and is significantly more than the average of 676 through May 21, according to NOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma. Nearly 700 of the tornadoes have been in April and May.\n\nIowa has had the most tornadoes this year with 81, followed by Texas with 74 and Kansas and Ohio each with 66. The National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports Tuesday, with most in Iowa -- including the one in Greenfield -- and one each in Wisconsin and Minnesota.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8140731678", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "16:36:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T16:36:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T16:35:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/22/us/greenfield-iowa-tornado.html", "title": "'A Completely Different Town Now': A Community Reels From a Deadly Tornado", "body": "Ann Hinga Klein and Leah McBride Mensching reported from Iowa.\n\nNot long after the tornado hit Greenfield, Iowa, residents were already using skid loaders to clear streets. With the hospital damaged, a medical triage center started at the local lumberyard. Paramedics and police officers from across the western half of Iowa were speeding in to help.\n\n\"Everybody became little makeshift ambulances,\" said Ray Sorensen, a member of the Iowa House of Representatives who lives in Greenfield, and who said he helped with the rescues after racing back into town shortly after the storm hit on Tuesday afternoon. \"We pulled a guy from the rubble and put him on a little makeshift stretcher that we made, threw him in the back of a truck.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, the roughly 2,000 residents of Greenfield began to get a clearer look at the destruction all around. Gov. Kim Reynolds said some areas had been \"flattened into debris.\" Officials said multiple people in town died and more were injured, but had not yet said how many as search and rescue efforts continued. In nearby Adams County, one woman died from storm-related causes, according to the medical examiner.\n\nAround Greenfield, the scenes of destruction began abruptly, with lush green yards transitioning into the chaos of splintered lumber and lawns littered with household items -- a cooler, a sink. Outside the local hospital, shredded tree branches were scattered across a lawn and a board had shattered the window of a parked car.\n\nAs rescue crews sorted through the wreckage, residents were beginning to reflect on a proud community that was indelibly changed.\n\n\"It's just the skyline of the trees: there's so many old historic trees in town that are gone,\" Mr. Sorensen said. He added: \"It's a completely different town now.\"\n\nIt has been a particularly brutal spring in Iowa, which is still recovering from an outbreak of tornadoes last month that caused extensive damage in the small town called Minden, about 70 miles from Greenfield.\n\n\"I was just in Minden,\" Ms. Reynolds said at a news conference on Wednesday, \"and that was horrific. And I think there's even more debris and just more impacted here. So it is just horrific. Kim Reynolds called it \"gut-wrenching.\" She thanked weather forecasters for their early warning on the timing of the storms.\n\n\"Based on the early, advanced notice that we were able to get, many of our schools got those kids out of school early,\" she said. \"And it hit here at 3 p.m., so that would have been the time that the kids would have been on the bus and heading home, and it would have been devastating.\"\n\nShe said the destruction reminded her of a storm that hit Minden in western Iowa less than a month ago.\n\n\"That was horrific, and I think there's even more debris and more impacted here,\" she said. \"It is just horrific, it's hard to describe.\"\n\nOfficials have said multiple people died in the storm, but Reynolds says search-and-rescue is ongoing and would not confirm a number of people killed or injured.\n\n\"We're looking to make sure all residents are accounted for,\" Iowa State Patrol Sgt. At least three people were reported killed by local authorities.\n\nA series of large, violent tornadoes struck Iowa on Tuesday, causing significant destruction and fatalities in some rural communities.\n\nPortions of Iowa, northwestern Illinois, southeastern Minnesota and western Wisconsin were placed under a \"Particularly Dangerous Situation\" Tornado Watch as rounds of powerful storms raced across the region, continuing a dayslong severe weather threat across the U.S.\n\nLess than 5% of all severe weather watches are given the Particularly Dangerous Situation tag, which signified forecasters' concerns about the outbreak.\n\nHOW TO WATCH FOX WEATHER\n\nSeveral deaths were attributed to the severe weather outbreak centered southwest of the state capital of Des Moines.\n\nWATCH: WIND TURBINE BURNS IN IOWA AFTER BEING DESTROYED BY TORNADO\n\nThe FOX Forecast Center spotted debris on radar from two twisters that impacted Carbon and Corning, and debris was being reported thrown at least 15 miles from a tornado that impacted Greenfield, Iowa.\n\nGreenfield, located in Adair County, has a population of around 2,000 people and is at the heart of the county.\n\nVideo showed people searching through rubble from what was a large tornado. Due to the powerful display on radar, forecasters believe the twister was on the upper half of the Enhanced Fujita Scale.\n\nDamage appeared to be significant on the southern and eastern sides of Greenfield, around the region's medical center.\n\n\"Most of this town is gone ... there's no other way to put it. The storm was moving at 50 to 55 miles an hour. So they're coming in quickly. People had a decent warning ... and, thankfully, 99% of the people that we had talked to had a good reaction to that warning and took shelter,\" Copic said.\n\nValerie Warrior is a lifelong Iowa resident and said one of the first signs trouble was on the way to Greenfield on Tuesday was when she started receiving texts from her family members.\n\n\"So, I went downstairs, got my cat and I went into the furnace room. I was holding my cat for my whole life, and I was shaking, and I heard the train,\" Warrior told FOX Weather.\n\nWarrior said the storm lasted only about a minute, but during that time period, windows broke, trees fell, and the small town was changed forever.\n\n\"There's houses down and flattened next to me and all over the place. My house got hurt. (AP)\n\nA series of severe thunderstorms -- including numerous tornadoes and strong straight-line winds -- that hit the Midwest left at least one person dead Tuesday.\n\nNearly all of Iowa, southwestern Wisconsin, western Illinois, and northern Missouri have the greatest risk for severe weather, which is a level 4 out of 5 on the Storm Prediction Center's scale.\n\nA woman in Adams County, Iowa, died in a storm-related incident.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a \"Particularly Dangerous Situation\" tornado watch for much of Iowa, southeastern Minnesota, western Wisconsin, and northwest Illinois until 9 p.m. local time.\n\nHeavy damage occurred throughout Iowa, where radar saw debris lifted to 40,000 feet in the town of Greenfield, and pieces of sheet metal were reported to have been falling from the sky approximately 30 miles away. Damage was also reported in Carbon and Villisca, Iowa.\n\nThe storms are allegedly being caused by an area of low pressure, along with a trailing cold front, moving into Minnesota. Upper level winds are also encouraging the formation of long-lasting severe thunderstorms with rotating updrafts, which are also known as supercells.\n\nThe \"Moderate Risk\" area covers almost all of Iowa, and a broader region is in an \"Enhanced Risk\" zone, which encompasses about 23 million people, including Chicago, Milwaukee, Kansas City, Missouri, and Omaha, Nebraska. The \"Enhanced Risk zone has a lower tornado threat, but there are still significant threats of high winds and large hail. An area of approximately 51 million people live in areas with at least \"Slight Risk.\"\n\nJeremy Frankel \u2709\n\nJeremy Frankel is a Newsmax writer reporting on news and politics.", "source":
