{"uri": "2024-05-364732765", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "14:32:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T14:32:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T14:25:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://eu.amestrib.com/story/news/2024/05/22/where-did-tuesdays-tornado-touch-down-in-story-county/73792403007/", "title": "A tornado knocked down powerlines and devastated homes in Story County Tuesday night", "body": "A little more than an hour had passed Tuesday after a tornado hit June and Larry Handsacker's house off of 650th Avenue near Nevada, and their family was already on the scene, pulling valued possessions from the wreckage.\n\nWhich, in June Handsacker's case, are her dolls.\n\n\"All my dolls!\" she said, pointing to a nearly intact china cabinet just inches from where the tornado cleaved her home in half on Tuesday afternoon. \"And those were just the dolls I bought, not the ones I made.\"\n\nShe was in the dining room when the tornado passed through her home. She had left her husband in the basement for a moment to grab her phone when insulation came crashing down around her. They had to crawl over the debris to get out.\n\n\"I have over 100 porcelain dolls -- ceramic pieces I made,\" Handsacker said. \"We don't know where they are yet. It'll be a matter of getting in there.\"\n\nHer own grandparents lost their home in the five-tornado spree that touched down in Charles City in 1968, and her grandfather was trapped for three days in his car.\n\nShe said she and her husband know they're lucky they came away unscathed; they believe that God was looking out for them.\n\n\"It pays to teach Sunday school!,\" she said. \"Do you know how horrible those kids behave?\"\n\nWhere did tornadoes hit on Tuesday?\n\nNo tornadoes will officially be confirmed until the National Weather Service can send survey crews into the field.\n\nStory County officials say a tornado traveled through Cambridge, Nevada, and Colo on the eastern edge of the county Tuesday evening, knocking down power lines, damaging houses, and scattering debris throughout the area.\n\nThe Story County tornado was seen on an Iowa DOT video feed crossing Highway 30 near the intersection with S27 just east of Nevada, heading north. Officials say the storm system produced wind gusts of 70 mph.\n\nStory County Emergency Management encourages residents in need of shelter or assistance to call the Red Cross at 1-800-733-2767.\n\nOther unofficial reports from trained weather spotters throughout Tuesday included: A cluster of sightings in southwest Iowa in Cromwell, Prescott, Corning, Carbon, Red Oak and Villisca. Greenfield in southwest Iowa also appeared to be particularly hard hit. southeast of Polk City.\n\nIn Greenfield, Iowa, a tornado killed multiple residents, injured dozens of people and flattened much of the town. The exact number of those injured or killed in the tornado has yet to be determined.\n\nIn other areas of the state, wind gusts of up to 71 mph were reported, which resulted in roofs blown off, trees down and power outages. Central Iowa experienced heavy rain in the mid-morning and evening.\n\nHow much rain fell Tuesday?\n\nThe City of Ames reported 2.65 inches of rain on Tuesday, and the Boone Municipal Airport recorded 1.6 inches.\n\nNo injuries or fatalities have been reported, according to Story County Emergency Management.\n\nColo was the only community without power, according to Emergency Management Coordinator Melissa Spencer. The once familiar town was now unrecognizable.\n\nSoon after the storm passed, photographer Chris Juhn captured 6-year-old Hudson Vanatta sitting on the steps of a home that no longer exists. The boy's father is a firefighter who responded to the call for help, despite their own situation in the wake of the disaster.\n\nDRONE VIDEO REVEALS DEVASTATION IN GREENFIELD AFTER MONSTER IOWA TORNADO: 'MOST OF THIS TOWN IS GONE'\n\nAnother striking image by Juhn shows a house with its front gone, yet inside, pictures still hang on the walls, a small plant and other items remain untouched on a dresser, and binders and books sit inside a bookshelf.\n\nTragically, the storm claimed the lives of at least two individuals, and a dozen more suffered injuries, adding to the immense toll of the disaster.\n\nAdair County Memorial Hospital was also damaged in the tornado. Doctors and hospital staff worked to help the injured. However, due to the damage to the hospital, patients needing further care had to be transferred to surrounding hospitals.\n\nAlong the tornado's path, houses were reduced to rubble, and the once lush trees stood bare, stripped of their leaves and bark. FOX Weather radar data showed that the debris was propelled to an altitude of approximately 40,000 feet, equivalent to the typical cruising altitude for commercial airplanes.\n\nAnother chaotic scene unfolded southwest of Greenfield as numerous wind turbines collapsed, resulting in the large metal structures crumpling like paper. One of the turbines even caught fire, adding to the dramatic scene.\n\nOn Wednesday, the National Weather Service will dispatch three damage survey teams in response to the severe weather in Iowa. {"uri": "8140859132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-22", "time": "18:14:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-22T18:14:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-22T18:14:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.43529412150383, "url": "https://www.radioiowa.com/2024/05/22/governor-says-tornado-damage-in-greenfield-is-horrific/", "title": "Governor says tornado damage in Greenfield is 'horrific' - Radio Iowa", "body": "Governor Kim Reynolds says debris in Greenfield needs to be stabilized before volunteers will be able to enter the town to help residents recover from Tuesday's tornado strike. The governor is hoping to have damage estimates completed by tomorrow so she can submit a request for a presidential disaster declaration that would trigger federal aid.\n\n\"We're going to file for individual assistance again and public assistance,\" Reynolds said during a news conference htis morning in Greenfield. \"The hospital was damaged and so we want to make sure that we're providing resources for them as well.\"\n\nThe governor told reporters four injured people were flown out of Greenfield on helicopters to area hospitals last (Tuesday) night, but she cannot confirm the number of people who were killed or injured.\n\n\"It's still a search and rescue and we don't want to give out any misinformation. That's one of the reasons we're keeping the site secure,\" Reynolds said. \"...We wouldn't want to give out a wrong number and we're still assessing and there are properties in the country that have been impacted as well so we want to make sure we have an accurate count.\"\n\nThere's a 10 a.m. to 7 a.m. curfew in Greenfield and people have to show proof they have a Greenfield address in order to enter the community. John Cooper, Adair County's Emergency Management Coordinator, said that's an element of their \"coordinated search\" to confirm injuries and deaths in the community.\n\n\"When we have this many homes that have been destroyed and just fully demolished, we want to make sure every person, every resident is accounted for,\" Cooper told reporters. \"We're going to continue doing that and then encountered for, so we're going to continue doing that and then, once we have those numbers, we'll send that information out.\"\n\nReynolds said it appears the damage in Greenfield is worse than what she saw Minden, where 40% of homes were damaged or destroyed by a tornado last month. \"It's just gut wrenching,\" Reynolds said. \"I was just in Minden...three and a half weeks ago and that was horrific and I think there's even more debris and more impacted here. It is is horrific. It is hard to describe, until you can see it, the devastation.\"\n\nReynolds praised the work of meteorologists at the National Weather Service for advance notice of yesterday's (Tuesday's) dangerous conditions.\n\n\"Letting individuals know when it would hit and where it would hit and they were almost spot on,\" Reynolds said. \"And I tell ya the other reason that was so important...we had a lot of kids still in school and based on the early, advance notice that we got, many of our schools let out early and it hit here (in Greenfield) at three and that would have been the time the kids were on a bus and headed home and it could have been devastating.\"\n\nReynolds also thanked Greenfield's hospital staff for their response to the tornado after it damaged their facility. They established a make-shift triage center at Greenfield's lumber yard to treat people who were injured and set up the transfers for people who needed treatment in a hospital. The state education director has issued a waiver, so the district's school year is officially over. Debris was scattered in the streets of several cities.\n\nThe authorities have previously warned of the dangers of hurricanes and severe storms. That is why schools closed earlier as a precaution and public life stopped hours before the hurricanes.\n\nThe Midwest region of the United States has been experiencing severe weather for days. In Kansas, Missouri and Oklahoma, among other places, people were injured by high winds, tornadoes and hailstones the size of baseballs.\n\nIowa is part of so-called Tornado Alley: an area the size of about eight states in the United States where tornadoes occur regularly.
